articles.title: ‘A stomach of steel’: amateur investors ride out dips amid talk of an AI bubble
articles.trailText: As one youngster buys a house with his winnings, experts say risk-takers are fuelling an unsustainable market
articles.summary: Young retail investors are propping up AI megacaps by buying the dip, muting selloffs despite IMF/BoE/JPM crash warnings. 23-year-old Jacob Foot funneled savings into the Magnificent Seven via Freetrade, bought Nvidia at $25, added after Trump's 2 Apr tariffs drove $140 to $94, and now sees it near $190, funding a London home. M7 +37% vs rest of S&P 500 +15%; they are over one-third of the index; Nvidia at ~54x earnings; Microsoft and Apple briefly topped $4tn. Retail plowed a record $3bn on 3 Apr (Vanda). Short sellers lament BTFD. Economists cite inelastic flows, passive concentration, apps/social hype; Blanchard warns momentum over fundamentals.

articles.title: Ben & Jerry’s owner stopped brand developing flavour for peace in Gaza
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Co-founder accuses ice-cream brand’s parent of taking part in ‘corporate butt kissing’ of Donald Trump
articles.summary: Ben & Jerry’s co-founder Ben Cohen says Unilever blocked a pro‑Palestinian “peace” flavor approved by the brand’s independent board, calling it corporate “butt kissing” of Donald Trump and an attack on free speech. He launched a “Free Ben & Jerry’s” campaign to push a sale to mission‑driven investors. Unilever/Magnum say the brand isn’t for sale and management decided it’s not the right time. Planned Amsterdam listing of the Magnum Ice Cream Company, with London/New York secondaries, was delayed by the US shutdown. Jerry Greenfield resigned in September. Cohen will make a symbolic watermelon flavor via Ben’s Best. Ben & Jerry’s has criticized Israel and halted sales in occupied territories.

articles.title: BT ‘considering low-cost mobile brand’ as Revolut and Monzo plan launches
articles.trailText: Move into budget market could involve creating new brand in-house or buying virtual network operator
articles.summary: BT is weighing entry into the UK budget mobile market, either by creating an in-house brand or acquiring an MVNO, per FT. It would mark a shift from its EE-only mobile strategy; Plusnet remains broadband-only. MVNOs held 16.5% share in 2024 and are set to grow as fintechs move in: Revolut and Monzo plan MVNOs, with Klarna and Octopus-backed Fern Trading also exploring services, pressuring Vodafone/Three and EE. The plan is driven by CEO Allison Kirkby and backed by major shareholder Sunil Bharti Mittal after Bharti Enterprises bought Patrick Drahi’s stake. BT may revive BT-branded broadband for older users. Officially, BT says no change yet.

articles.title: HSBC warns it could take years to settle Madoff case as bank takes $1.1bn hit
articles.trailText: Lawsuit over Ponzi scheme drags on London-headquartered lender, whose profits plunge by 14%
articles.summary: HSBC took a $1.1bn provision tied to an investor lawsuit over its role administering Madoff-linked funds, warning settlement could take months or years after a Luxembourg appeal was rejected; it will file a further appeal and may contest amounts later. The charge drove Q3 pre-tax profit down 14% to $7.3bn and lifted operating costs 24% to $10bn (also reflecting restructuring severance). HSBC also booked $1bn for China/Hong Kong property stress. Stronger revenues partly offset: net interest income +15% to $8.8bn; fee income +12% to $3.5bn. CFO Pam Kaur said private-credit exposure is single-digit billions; HSBC is monitoring second- and third-order risks. Rival Barclays flagged £20bn exposure. CEO Georges Elhedery reiterated simplification.

articles.title: Steeper UK productivity cut of more than £20bn makes tax rises more likely
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves faces bigger-than-expected hit in 26 November budget from revised OBR forecast
articles.summary: UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves faces a £20bn–£30bn fiscal hole after the OBR prepares a steeper productivity downgrade—about 0.3pp off trend growth—implying c£21bn higher borrowing by 2029-30 (IFS: £7bn per 0.1pp). JP Morgan warns the hit could near £27bn, partly offset by lower gilt yields or higher labour supply. The squeeze makes manifesto pledges not to raise income tax, VAT or NI harder to keep; Reeves has explored income tax rises and plans to raise £2bn by lifting NI on professional partnerships (doctors, lawyers, accountants). OBR gives its outlook Friday; full forecast due 26 Nov. Reeves, in Riyadh, blames post-crisis/Brexit weakness.

articles.title: After my car was damaged in a Tesco car wash it has washed its hands of my complaint
articles.trailText: The tail spoiler and brake light were ripped off needing £750 repair, but it claims there was no fault with the machine
articles.summary: After an automated wash at a Tesco superstore ripped off a car’s tail spoiler and brake light (estimated £750 repair) in Dumfries & Galloway, Tesco denied liability, citing a contractor’s maintenance report finding no fault—yet refused to share it due to “company policy.” Google shows similar complaints; drivers receive identical solicitor letters citing disclaimers and claiming no defects or other complaints. Tesco denies a blanket rejection policy, says daily checks found the wash OK. Options: claim on insurance or pursue legal action—send a letter before action (14 days), then file via Scotland’s simple procedure or an England/Wales county court, with photos, payment proof, and repair quotes.

articles.title: CSL share price plummets amid shareholder revolt over executive pay plans
articles.trailText: US vaccination forecast leads to fall in stock price, while board survives spill in ‘second strike’ over pay concerns at AGM
articles.summary: CSL’s AGM delivered a second strike on pay, with >40% of votes against the remuneration report, but shareholders decisively rejected a board spill, keeping directors in place. The backlash came as shares fell 15% Tuesday, deepening a >35% YTD slide, after forecasts of weaker US flu vaccination (-12% overall; -14% aged 65+) hit outlook. Chair Brian McNamee called the US drop remarkable. Investors decry a pay–performance mismatch and the costly 2022 Vifor acquisition; CSL has been cited as paying more in CEO bonuses than Australian company tax. CEO Paul McKenzie earned US$6.06m; predecessor Paul Perreault once topped US$45m. CSL defends global-market pay even as Australia’s two-strikes rule pressures remuneration.

articles.title: RBA governor dismisses jobs fears but hints at rates hold after inflation uptick
articles.trailText: Michele Bullock plays down concerns about rising joblessness as economists pencil in February for next reduction in borrowing costs
articles.summary: RBA governor Michele Bullock downplayed September’s jump in unemployment, saying the labour market won’t “fall off a cliff,” and flagged holding rates. Joblessness rose to 4.5% while inflation ran hotter. Market odds of a cut next Tuesday plunged to ~10% from ~60%, though December still ~80%. ABS data Wednesday is expected to lift headline CPI to ~3% YoY as power-bill subsidies roll off (electricity +9% q/q, +24% y/y). Trimmed-mean seen ~1% q/q; annual may stall at 2.7% or rise to 2.8% (Barrenjoey). The board will update forecasts; outcome is data-dependent. Many economists, including CBA’s Belinda Allen, now pencil the first cut for February; soft-landing risks flagged.

articles.title: Cobar: two people killed in Endeavour mine explosion in far western NSW
articles.trailText: Woman and man confirmed dead and another woman airlifted to hospital after blast at Endeavour mine
articles.summary: Two workers died and a third was injured in an underground explosion at Polymetals' Endeavour mine near Cobar, NSW, at about 3.45am Tuesday. A man in his 60s died at the scene; two women in their 20s were brought to surface; one later died, the other was airlifted to Orange hospital with hearing damage and shock, stable. All three lived in Cobar. The NSW Resources Regulator launched an investigation; the Mine Workers' Alliance urged transparency. Operations and ASX trading in Polymetals were suspended. The silver-zinc-lead mine, 40km north of Cobar, was acquired in 2024 and is the Cobar basin's second-largest project. Officials offered condolences and stressed safety.

articles.title: Shrinkflation hits everyday staples, piling more pressure on households
articles.trailText: Which? finds products shrinking while supermarkets keep prices flat or rising
articles.summary: Consumer watchdog Which? flags new shrinkflation: brands cut pack sizes or recipes while supermarkets keep or lift prices. Aquafresh Complete Care fell from 100ml to 75ml yet rose from £1.30 to £2 at Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Ocado — a 105% per‑100ml increase (owner Haleon cites cost pressures). Gaviscon liquid shrank 600ml→500ml with Sainsbury’s price held at £14 (+20% per 100ml). Nescafé Original dropped 200g→190g at Tesco, Morrisons and Asda (~+5% per 100g; Nestlé notes higher coffee costs). Quality Street tubs 600g→550g and price £6→£7 at Morrisons (+27% per 100g). McVitie’s Club/Penguin now have more palm/shea oil than cocoa. Which? urges clearer, prominent unit pricing. Separately, BRC/NIQ say shop-price inflation eased to 1% in Oct, led by packaged foods 2.9% (4.2% prior) and non‑food −0.4%, while fresh food rose to 4.3%.

articles.title: First banker jailed over Libor interest rate rigging to sue UBS for $400m
articles.trailText: Tom Hayes claims he was ‘hand-picked scapegoat’ for the Swiss bank as it tried to avoid regulatory scrutiny
articles.summary: Tom Hayes, first banker jailed in the Libor scandal, has sued UBS for $400m (£300m) in Connecticut, alleging malicious prosecution: that the bank scapegoated him, misled US authorities, and labeled him an "evil mastermind" to protect senior executives and minimize fines. Hayes served 5.5 of an 11-year term for alleged 2006-10 Libor rigging; the defunct benchmark priced trillions, and the wider probe yielded nearly $10bn in penalties for a dozen firms. In July, the UK supreme court quashed his convictions for jury misdirection but didn’t exonerate him. He seeks damages for ruined reputation and personal losses. UBS declined comment.

articles.title: UK in £8bn deal to sell Typhoon jets to Turkey despite human rights concerns
articles.trailText: Starmer’s announcement on visit to Ankara comes as jailed opposition leader Ekrem İmamoğlu faces fresh charges
articles.summary: UK PM Keir Starmer signed an £8bn deal in Ankara to sell 20 Eurofighter Typhoons to Turkey, calling it a NATO security boost. BAE will assemble the jets in the UK; first deliveries due 2030, securing about 500 jobs at Warton and supporting Samlesbury and the wider UK‑Germany‑Italy‑Spain supply chain. The sale proceeds despite rights concerns as jailed opposition leader Ekrem İmamoğlu faces fresh espionage‑linked charges; Tele1 editor Merdan Yanardağ and ex‑campaign chief Necati Özkan were also arrested and same‑sex marriage criminalisation mooted. Amnesty urged conditions; No 10 says concerns were raised. The order sustains Warton’s line. BAE’s CEO hailed the jet’s export‑led economic impact.

articles.title: Exxon sues California over climate laws, alleging free speech violations
articles.trailText: Oil firm asks court to block enforcement of laws that would require disclosure of planet-heating carbon emissions
articles.summary: Exxon sued California in federal court (E.D. Cal.) to block two 2023 Climate Accountability Package laws requiring large firms to disclose global greenhouse-gas emissions (via GHG Protocol) and climate-related financial risks starting 2026, alleging compelled speech and First Amendment violations. Exxon says it already reports using Ipieca standards and claims the state’s frameworks are misleading, extraterritorial, and conflict with federal securities disclosure rules by forcing speculation on future risks. Newsom’s office called the suit an attack on transparency. Similar business lawsuits failed to win an injunction; trial set Oct 2026. Environmental groups say the rules curb greenwashing. SEC dropped defending federal climate disclosure rules in March.

articles.title: US debt set to soar above Italy and Greece after Trump’s ‘big, beautiful bill’
articles.trailText: While the European countries have brought their spending under control, the US president’s tax cuts and defence spending will lead to increased borrowing
articles.summary: IMF forecasts put US federal debt at 143% of GDP by 2030, up from 125%, overtaking Italy (~137%) and Greece (146%→130%). The rise is driven by Trump’s tax cuts (“big, beautiful bill”) benefiting mainly middle/high earners, and higher defense outlays, including a proposed $1tn “golden dome” shield. The US is set to run deficits above 7% of GDP for five years; spending increases could push the annual shortfall up by $7tn by Jan 2029. Italy and Greece plan primary surpluses; Italy’s deficit is seen at 2.9% this year, with growth ~0.5%, falling population and 200,000 emigrants. Analysts call the crossover symbolic but caution Italy remains vulnerable.

articles.title: Oil and gas firm Petrofac files for administration, putting thousands of jobs at risk
articles.trailText: North Sea contractor says move applies only to its ultimate holding company and it will continue to trade
articles.summary: Petrofac has applied to put its ultimate holding company into administration, likely under Teneo, while operating units continue trading. The North Sea contractor employs 7,300 globally, including ~2,000 in Aberdeen, whose jobs are at risk. The move follows TenneT cancelling a Dutch offshore wind contract over missed obligations, making a solvent restructuring unviable. Petrofac’s debts approach $4bn, after a 2021 SFO bribery case ($100m penalties) and pandemic setbacks. DESNZ says the UK arm is not in administration and remains operational; sale interest is possible. Shares were suspended in May; value ~£20m. The crisis heightens pressure over Labour’s plan to halt new North Sea licences.

articles.title: UK watchdog raises competition concerns over Greencore-Bakkavor deal
articles.trailText: Proposed £1.2bn takeover of Tesco, M&S, Sainsbury’s, Waitrose and Asda supplier is being examined by CMA
articles.summary: The UK CMA said Greencore’s £1.2bn acquisition of rival Bakkavor could substantially lessen competition in supermarket own-label chilled sauces, the only issue identified in its phase-1 review. No concerns were found in Italian chilled ready meals or own-label salads. The firms have until 3 November to propose remedies or face a phase-2 probe. RBC estimates chilled sauces are ~1% of the combined group’s £4bn revenue. Greencore (Britain’s biggest sandwich maker) and Bakkavor (pizzas, salads, snacks supplier to Tesco, M&S, Sainsbury’s, Waitrose, Asda) still target completion in early 2026; Greencore shares fell ~2%.

articles.title: AI can help authors beat writer’s block, says Bloomsbury chief
articles.trailText: Publisher last week reported jump in revenue in academic and professional arm thanks to AI licensing deal
articles.summary: Bloomsbury CEO Nigel Newton says AI will help authors beat writer's block—drafting first paragraphs/chapters across creative arts—while cautioning against AI-written books, arguing readers gravitate to trusted "big-name" authors amid rising shoddy content. Financially, Bloomsbury's H1 academic/professional revenue rose 20% on an AI licensing deal, lifting shares up to 10%, while consumer revenue fell ~20% without a new Sarah J. Maas release (her TikTok-boosted series has sold 70m English copies). Founded in 1986 by Newton, who signed JK Rowling; London-based Bloomsbury employs ~1,000. Context: authors' legal fights with AI continue; Anthropic settled for $1.5bn in September.

articles.title: Supermarkets tell Reeves tax rises could push food prices higher
articles.trailText: Households would ‘inevitably feel the impact’ of a surtax on business rates, say retailers in letter to chancellor
articles.summary: UK supermarkets warned Chancellor Rachel Reeves that including large grocers in a new business‑rates surtax on properties with rateable value above £500,000 at the 26 November budget would raise costs and push food prices higher, prolonging elevated food inflation into 2026. Bosses from Tesco, Asda, Sainsbury’s, Morrisons, Aldi, Lidl, M&S, Waitrose and Iceland signed the letter, citing April’s £25bn employer NICs hike and a 6.7% national living wage rise. The BRC urged exempting supermarkets—shifting burden to offices/industrial sites at no taxpayer cost. Headline inflation is 3.8%; food inflation eased to 4.5% in September. Treasury: boosting incomes, cutting some shop rates.

articles.title: Does your boss have the right to time your bathroom breaks when you work from home? | Gene Marks
articles.trailText: For remote work arrangements to be successful, managers and employees need to meet somewhere in the middle
articles.summary: Gene Marks uses a viral New York Post anecdote—a manager imposing a five-minute rule requiring WFH staff to notify the team whenever stepping away, even for the bathroom—to critique micromanagement. He calls the policy absurd, yet says it exposes unresolved tensions over remote productivity. Older small-business owners and some CEOs (JPMorgan’s Jamie Dimon, Amazon’s Andy Jassy) argue office work yields more output; studies are mixed. Marks urges a middle ground: employees should treat WFH as an earned benefit—be reachable, hit goals, accept IT oversight, avoid Monday/Friday optics, stay professional at home—while employers stop surveillance, skip monitoring software, and trust that autonomy and flexibility (especially for caregivers) boost success.

articles.title: Trump sanctions have swift impact but will world stop buying Russian oil and gas?
articles.trailText: Analysts say president’s war on Russia’s fossil fuel revenues is a chance to bring peace to Ukraine and profit to US
articles.summary: Trump sanctioned Rosneft and Lukoil, threatening dollar access for buyers, to choke Russia’s war funds. Oil jumped 6%; reports said Indian refineries and Chinese SOEs paused Russian cargoes. Asia took 86% of Russia’s crude Jan–Sep; losing India/China could cut $7.4bn revenue and $3.6bn taxes monthly; India’s state refineries’ imports fell 38% in Sept. Russia’s fossil earnings hit post‑invasion low, aided by “shadow tankers.” China blasted “economic coercion”; Modi gave no pledge. EU is largest buyer of Russian LNG and pipeline gas but plans a 2027 phaseout; US LNG supplies 55%. Enforcement will decide. Hungary and Slovakia lead EU gas buys.

articles.title: Peer trying to derail UK smoking ban discussed bill with relative at tobacco firm
articles.trailText: Lord Strathcarron says he and an in-law ‘high up’ at British American Tobacco discussed bill, which he aims to weaken
articles.summary: UK peer Lord Strathcarron, who tabled 1 May amendments to scrap the Tobacco and Vapes Bill's generational sales ban (for anyone born after 2008) and instead raise the age to 21, discussed the bill with an in-law "very high up" at British American Tobacco. His stance mirrors BAT lobbying; tobacco firms have threatened legal action. He hadn't declared the link, calling the relative "barely family". He called cigars "harmless" and disclosed a separate tie: a minority investor in one of his firms makes vapes. He says peers rely on lobbyists and works with Action on World Health (co-founded by Nigel Farage), Free Speech Union and Big Brother Watch; he met an industry representative at the July British Grand Prix. BAT denies awareness and says a generational ban would fuel illicit trade. AWH denies bill talks. The Lords code requires declaring relevant interests.

articles.title: The world dropped the ball on critical minerals and China pounced. Is it too late for Australia and the US to close the gap?
articles.trailText: In the wake of Covid, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and China’s assertion in global markets, western countries have realised they can’t afford such concentrated supply chains
articles.summary: Australia and the US unveiled a $13bn pact to seed domestic rare-earths and critical minerals, aiming to break China's chokehold (roughly 70% mining, 90% processing). Triggered by supply shocks and tariffs, China's June export halt even paused Ford's Chicago line; magnet exports are now restricted. Canberra will back Alcoa's WA gallium project (from 2026; China supplies 98%) and invest $100m in Arafura's Nolans NdPr project (135km north of Alice Springs), already with $1.2bn support, targeting 4% of global NdPr by 2032. ASX rare-earth stocks have tripled. Experts warn catch-up needs guaranteed buyers, price floors, and full-chain refining despite pollution; 80% foreign ownership heightens returns scrutiny.

articles.title: ‘If you use chocolate, you’re in crisis’: the surprise ingredients being used to beat costs
articles.trailText: As costs and demand for chocolate rises – but cocoa yields fall – companies are innovating with surprising alternatives
articles.summary: Cocoa costs have surged (quadrupled in three years; UK shopper prices +15.4% to August) as climate and deforestation squeeze Ghana/Ivory Coast supply, triggering reformulations and “chocolate flavour” downgrades (Penguin, Club, KitKat White, White Digestives). Alternatives surge: UK’s Win-Win ferments rice/cereals/legumes to mimic cocoa; Barry Callebaut with Zurich UAS trials cell-cultured cacao; Planet A’s ChoViva ferments oats/sunflower (up to 90% less carbon and water), supplying Aldi/Lidl at >10,000t/yr; Voyage Foods uses grape seeds/sunflower protein/shea, raising $40m. Health: cocoa-free isn’t inherently healthier; dark chocolate’s flavanols benefit heart/gut. Cocoa contents: G&B 85%, Aldi dark 55%, Hotel Chocolat milk 40%, Tony’s 32%, Cadbury 20%, McVitie’s digestives 30%, Jaffa 19%, Oreo 4.5%, Wagon Wheels flavouring.

articles.title: Buy now, pay later holiday purchases leaving travellers exposed to losses
articles.trailText: BNPL offers are becoming more popular but when it comes to booking a holiday or a flight, consumers need to weigh up the risks
articles.summary: BNPL is surging for travel, with Travelodge’s “stay now, pay later” via Klarna, Clearpay and PayPal, “fly now pay later” at agents, and Airbnb-Klarna for £35-£4,000 bookings. Google searches for BNPL flights/hotels are rising. But experts warn BNPL lacks credit-card section 75 protection, so if trips go wrong or providers go bust you must pursue refunds yourself; instalments may keep leaving your account for weeks. Missed payments can incur fees and harm credit. Limits vary by provider; terms and dispute processes are patchy—read the small print. Charges can continue post-travel. FCA regulation from July 2026 will bring BNPL under section 75 and Financial Ombudsman coverage.

articles.title: Co-op staff told to boost promotion of vapes after costly cyber-attack, document shows
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Approach complies with law but some workers question whether it contradicts standing as ‘ethical’ retailer
articles.summary: The Co-op is pushing prominent vape displays, ads and a wider range (including nicotine pouches) to recover sales lost after an April cyber-attack. An internal “Powering Up: Focus Sprint: Cigs, Tobacco and Vape” memo cites £1m weekly missing sales, 100,000 fewer transactions, and at least 40% of customers forming new shopping habits elsewhere. Staff question the move’s fit with the grocer’s ethical image. The strategy is legal, the Co-op says, and supports smoking cessation. A tobacco/vapes bill will ban vape advertising and curb flavours/packaging. The hack wiped £200m+ from sales; full-year profit hit forecast at £120m. Part of a store-wide Power Up programme across categories.

articles.title: Nigel Farage seeks influence over Bank of England in same vein as Trump and US Federal Reserve
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader suggests he would replace Bank of England governor if he became prime minister
articles.summary: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage said he would replace Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey if he became PM, echoing Donald Trump’s bid to sway the independent US Federal Reserve. Though Bailey’s eight-year term ends March 2028 and the next UK election is due by 15 Aug 2029, Farage wants more political control of a BoE made independent in 1997 by Gordon Brown. He and MP Richard Tice met Bailey, urging a halt to bond sales and lower interest paid to banks; Tice wants Treasury appointees on the MPC. Farage, a crypto and gold promoter, welcomed Bailey’s shift on stablecoins; the BoE called the meeting 'productive'.

articles.title: US prices rose at a 3% annual rate in September, slightly beating forecasts
articles.trailText: Increase was largely driven by a 4.1% increase in gasoline prices despite Trump’s campaign pledge to ‘end inflation’
articles.summary: U.S. CPI rose 3.0% y/y in September, up 0.3% m/m, slightly under economists’ 0.4%/3.1% forecasts. Gasoline (+4.1% m/m) drove the increase. CPI was 2.9% y/y in August. The shutdown delayed the BLS release about two weeks; SSA will use it to set a 2.8% 2026 Social Security COLA. With hiring soft (22,000 jobs added in August), the Fed, after a September cut, is expected to ease again next week. A Guardian poll finds households face $100–$749 higher monthly costs. Despite Trump’s claims, tariffs are lifting prices on furniture, appliances, toys; Dean Baker warns 2% inflation is unlikely absent a downturn.

articles.title: NatWest boss warns against higher bank taxes as lender’s profits rise 30%
articles.trailText: CEO says fiscal discipline should be balanced with ‘policies that create stability, consistency and support growth’
articles.summary: NatWest CEO Paul Thwaite urged Chancellor Rachel Reeves not to raise bank taxes in the 26 Nov budget, despite NatWest’s Q3 profit jumping 30.4% to £2.18bn (from £1.67bn). He warned higher levies, floated to help plug a £30bn fiscal gap—including mooted taxes on banks, property and landlords—would deter long‑term capital and hurt growth. NatWest, fully privatised this year, lifted 2025 income guidance to £16.3bn (ex‑notables); shares rose 2.9%. Thwaite echoed Lloyds’ Charlie Nunn, opposing an IPPR‑backed banking windfall tax tied to QE gains, citing UK competitiveness and banks’ role in funding mortgages and businesses.

articles.title: Dash for gold helps drive retail sales in Great Britain to three-year high
articles.trailText: Demand at online jewellers and release of iPhone 17 lead to bigger-than-expected rise in volumes in September
articles.summary: UK retail sales volumes rose 0.5% m/m in September, the highest since July 2022 and a fourth straight gain, defying forecasts for a 0.2% fall. Computer/telecom retailers benefited from the iPhone 17 launch; online sales rose for an eighth month, driven by internet jewellers amid a 1970s-scale gold rally. Non‑food stores led (+0.9%); total volumes +1.5% y/y but remain 1.6% below Feb 2020. August was revised to +0.6%. Q3 volumes rose 0.9% q/q after a warm summer and Euro 2025 lift. ONS delays stoked data-quality worries. Despite momentum, high inflation, soft jobs and looming 26 Nov budget/Black Friday may curb spending.

articles.title: Car production slumps to a 73-year low after JLR cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Shutdown contributes to 27% slump across the UK sector, which says it remains under ‘immense pressure’
articles.summary: UK car production fell 27% in September to 51,100 (from 70,000 a year earlier), the lowest September since 1952, after a cyber-attack forced Jaguar Land Rover to shut systems for a month and halt output until early October, SMMT said. Year-to-date output is down 8%; van production has plunged nearly 40% after Stellantis closed its Luton plant. The Cyber Monitoring Centre estimates the JLR hack cost the UK economy about £1.9bn. While JLR’s restart is progressing, the sector remains under “immense pressure” amid Chinese competition, EV retooling costs, weak demand, and chip risks from the Dutch move on Nexperia.

articles.title: Battle between Netherlands and China over chipmaker could disrupt car factories, companies say
articles.trailText: Volvo, VW and Nissan among companies that could face supply problems due to Dutch takeover of Nexperia
articles.summary: Automakers warn that the Netherlands’ move to take control of China-owned Nexperia (via a cold-war era law, after US concerns about owner Wingtech) and Beijing’s retaliatory ban on Nexperia exports risk fresh chip shortages. JAMA (Nissan, Toyota, Honda, Mazda) and Germany’s VDA cite potential production halts; VDA says members got a 10 Oct notice on constrained supply and has pressed Berlin/EC for fixes. VW uses some Nexperia parts; impact possible. Volvo’s CEO expects rivals’ shutdowns. SMMT flags UK risk. Nexperia makes chips in NL, mostly packaged in China. Tensions rise ahead of a possible Trump–Xi meeting in Korea amid rare-earth curbs.

articles.title: Oil price jumps and FTSE 100 hits new high after Trump puts sanctions on Russian firms
articles.trailText: Assets in US belonging to Rosneft and Lukoil frozen as shares in Shell and BP rise by 3%
articles.summary: Oil jumped after Trump sanctioned Rosneft and Lukoil, freezing US assets and banning US dealings, with threatened secondary sanctions on banks facilitating Russian oil trades, to pressure Moscow over Ukraine. Brent +5.7% to $66.13; Shell, BP +~3%, lifting FTSE 100 to record 9,594.82. Moscow’s MOEX/RTS -~3.6%. Chinese majors PetroChina, Sinopec, CNOOC, Zhenhua paused seaborne Russian buys; India’s Reliance to cut/halt imports. EU banned Russian LNG, sanctioned Chinaoil Hong Kong and refiners Liaoyang, Shandong Yulong (600kb/d). UK also sanctioned both. Trump canceled a Putin summit. His first Russia sanctions since returning in January. Biggest oil rise since July.

articles.title: Dining out ‘under pressure’ as Britons cut back due to price rises, says YouGov
articles.trailText: Survey finds 38% of people are eating out less often than a year ago, with many citing higher prices as main reason
articles.summary: UK dining-out demand is under pressure, YouGov finds: 38% of Britons are eating out less than a year ago; among cutbacks, 63% blame higher prices. Yet 6 in 10 still dine out monthly. Nearly half have changed habits to save: 59% pick cheaper restaurants, 52% order fewer items. Inflation held at 3.8%, keeping cost-conscious choices elevated. Retailers pivot to at-home ranges (Sainsbury’s 50+ Taste the Difference; Charlie Bigham meals £29.95). Sector strain persists: Pizza Hut to shut 68 sites (1,200 jobs at risk); hospitality takes 45% of job losses. 79% see price rises; boomers notice; 36% find deals social media.

articles.title: Foxtons shares drop sharply after it warns of ‘subdued’ pre-budget sales
articles.trailText: Economic uncertainty along with possible changes to property tax are deterring buyers, says estate agent
articles.summary: Foxtons warns sales will stay subdued through year as buyers delay ahead of 26 Nov budget and slower-than-expected BoE rate cuts lift mortgage costs. Shares fell up to 11%, later -4.5%. Q3: sales revenue -7% to £12.5m; lettings +5% to £33.4m; total revenue £49m (+3% YoY); YTD £135.1m (+7%). Risk Q4 revenue below guidance. CEO Guy Gittins pivots to lettings, citing pent-up London demand; recent Reading/Watford buys performing well; more acquisitions planned; expands landlord guidance/property management amid renters’ rights bill. Treasury mulls replacing stamp duty on homes >£500k; SDLT raises ~£12bn. St James’s Place shares -4%; FUM +15% to £212bn.

articles.title: Aerospace groups link up to create European rival to Musk’s SpaceX
articles.trailText: Deal between Airbus, Leonardo and Thales will bring together some of continent’s leading manufacturers
articles.summary: Airbus, Leonardo and Thales will merge their space units into a single European company to rival SpaceX, targeting ~€6.5bn annual revenue. Ownership: Airbus 35%, Leonardo 32.5%, Thales 32.5%. Based in Toulouse, it aims to be operational in 2027 pending approvals, with mid‑triple‑digit million‑euro annual operating synergies after five years. The tie-up spans satellites and space systems. Arianespace excluded. The groups promise no immediate site closures or layoffs after recent cuts (Airbus €1.3bn charges and 2,000 jobs; Thales Alenia Space >1,000). SpaceX’s launch dominance and Starlink’s LEO network have squeezed demand for Europe’s GEO comsats.

articles.title: Lloyds profits plunge 36% as it feels impact of UK car finance scandal
articles.trailText: Bank’s drop in quarterly earnings comes after it put aside further £800m to cover expected wave of driver claims
articles.summary: Lloyds Banking Group’s Q3 pre-tax profit fell 36% to £1.17bn (from £1.8bn) after a further £800m provision for the UK car-finance commission scandal, taking its redress pot to £1.95bn. As the UK’s largest auto lender via Black Horse, Lloyds faces the biggest hit from the FCA’s proposed scheme covering 14m historic loans and potentially costing lenders £11bn from next year. CFO William Chalmers pledged compensation where harm occurred but warned the plan could overpay (about 44% of loans), misaligns with August’s Supreme Court ruling, and uses unclear harm metrics. Lloyds is consulting; legal challenge not ruled out. Barclays lifted its provision to £325m (+£235m).

articles.title: Thames Water ranked worst supplier in England as firms’ ratings hit record low
articles.trailText: Environment Agency rates eight of nine companies as poor and needing improvement
articles.summary: England's water firms received a record-low 19/36 stars from the Environment Agency, with 8 of 9 rated poor. Thames Water was worst (one star); serious pollution incidents rose from 14 to 33 amid debt-fueled underinvestment. Severn Trent scored four stars despite 62,085 spills in 2024 averaging seven hours and a £2m fine; CEO Liv Garfield got £3.2m pay. Ofwat said spills rose 27% in 2020-25 despite a pledged 30% cut. EA to replace stars in 2027 with 1-5 ratings. Government plans a super-regulator; campaigners urge public ownership and Thames special administration. Wet weather, poor maintenance and increased monitoring cited.

articles.title: Groceries via delivery apps like Uber Eats, DoorDash and Milkrun can be up to 39% more expensive
articles.trailText: Seven out of 13 items at Aldi were priced higher on DoorDash than in store, while Milkrun charged more for 11 out of 13 items from Woolworths
articles.summary: Consumer group Choice found groceries via third‑party apps cost markedly more than in‑store: items averaged 11% higher, delivery added $5–$11, and total baskets were up to 39% pricier. Uber Eats was costliest: including fees, Woolworths and Coles baskets were 39% and 35% above store prices; products alone were 12% higher. On DoorDash, 7/13 Aldi items cost more; on Milkrun, 11/13 Woolworths items did. Coles says direct online matches store pricing; Choice found it cheaper than apps even with $15 delivery. Milkrun can beat some Woolworths delivery options, but Aldi’s DoorDash rollout narrows its price edge. Platforms cite convenience/merchant‑set pricing.

articles.title: Barclays can afford Tricolor loss but risks remain in the private credit market
articles.trailText: Risky lending in an opaque, complex and leveraged part of the financial world is ringing alarm bells
articles.summary: Barclays booked a £110m loss on lending to Tricolor, a failed US subprime auto lender under DOJ fraud investigation, but avoided exposure to distressed First Brands. With £20bn private-credit exposure (of £346bn loans, US‑weighted), Q3 pre‑tax profit of £2.08bn, and £500m buybacks, the bank can absorb the hit; shares rose. JPMorgan also took a $170m Tricolor charge. Yet systemic risks linger: the IMF/BoE warn opaque, leveraged private credit shows “slicing and dicing,” limited regulatory visibility, and potential contagion. BoE governor Andrew Bailey says it’s unclear if losses are idiosyncratic; more “cockroaches” could shift sentiment. Markets have calmed after brief jitters.

articles.title: UK inflation unexpectedly remains at 3.8% for third month in a row
articles.trailText: Annual September rate confounds forecasts of a rise, as pace of food price growth slows for first time since March
articles.summary: UK CPI held at 3.8% in September 2025 (vs 4.0% expected), third straight month. Cheaper food (-0.2% m/m; food inflation 4.5% y/y from 5.1%, first slowdown since March; first monthly drop since May 2024) and flat recreation/culture (live music -8.6% m/m) offset pricier transport (+3.8% y/y; petrol, air fares). CPI has topped the 2% target for 12 months. Markets now tip a first full 25bp BoE cut in Feb 2026, with 18 Dec 2025 back in play. September CPI guides benefit uprating; state pensions likely +4.8% via triple lock. RPI 4.5% may steer duties/train fares. Reeves trails 26 Nov budget; IMF still sees highest G7 inflation in 2025–26.

articles.title: Australia’s surprise unemployment spike suggests an economy not overheating but in need of stimulus | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: Last week’s announcement that unemployment reached 4.5% in September came as a shock to the RBA, which must have been either embarrassed – or ecstatic
articles.summary: Australia’s jobless rate jumped to 4.5% in September (August revised to 4.3%), up from 3.5% in 2022—about 150,000 more unemployed—wrong‑footing the RBA, which recently cited 4.2% and forecast joblessness wouldn’t top 4.3% until 2028. Markets now assign a 74% chance of a 4 November rate cut and good odds of another by May. Employment growth is weakening and skewed to non‑market sectors (education, health, social assistance, public admin); RBA minutes claiming market‑sector strength are belied by falling market‑sector hours (Sep qtr down 0.8% vs Dec qtr 2024) while non‑market hours rose 4.2%. With inflation down to 2.4% despite prior tightness, Jericho says the economy needs stimulus, not hawkishness.

articles.title: UK energy firms call for overhaul of regulator Ofgem
articles.trailText: Energy UK claims Ofgem has overseen ‘dramatic rise in red tape’ that has pushed up bills and slowed economic growth
articles.summary: Energy UK urges a radical overhaul of Ofgem, blaming a “dramatic” rise in red tape for higher household bills and weaker growth. It says Ofgem’s headcount grew 120% and budget 200% over a decade, versus just 8% workforce growth in the sector. The trade body wants Ofgem narrowed to economic regulation of networks/infrastructure, moving consumer protection to the CMA and delivery of schemes to other bodies. The push follows the government’s water-regulator reset and comes amid warnings of steep bill rises by decade’s end. An Ofgem review launched by energy secretary Ed Miliband in Dec is pending. Ofgem says it’ll cut red tape but keep firm consumer protections.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover hack has cost UK economy £1.9bn, experts say
articles.trailText: Cybersecurity body says more than 5,000 organisations affected in most costly cyber-attack to hit Britain
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover’s late-August cyberattack has inflicted an estimated £1.9bn hit on the UK economy, the Cyber Monitoring Centre says—likely Britain’s costliest. JLR shut IT across factories and offices, managed only a limited restart in early October, and doesn’t expect full production until January. The outage cascaded through its supply chain, affecting up to 5,000 organisations; smaller suppliers laid off thousands amid cashflow crunches. JLR, owned by Tata, was losing ~£50m a week; the UK offered a £1.5bn loan guarantee and JLR prepaid for parts to support suppliers. CMC rated it a category-3 systemic event. JLR’s three UK plants make ~1,000 cars/day; dealers were also disrupted.

articles.title: Barclays plays down £20bn exposure to private credit industry
articles.trailText: CEO says bank has ‘right controls’ in place despite warnings about industry from IMF and Bank of England
articles.summary: Barclays played down its £20bn private‑credit exposure, with CEO CS Venkatakrishnan saying the bank runs a risk‑controlled shop and lends only to portfolios from large, experienced managers. Despite a £110m hit on collapsed US subprime lender Tricolor and jitters after First Brands’ failure, he said Barclays rejected First Brands exposure. He called IMF warnings “subjective” as BoE’s Andrew Bailey noted 2008‑style echoes. Exposure is small versus £346bn loans. Q3 pre‑tax profit fell 7% to £2.08bn; Barclays took a £235m car‑loan commission provision (total £325m), announced £500m buybacks, will move to quarterly payouts, and upgraded ROTE guidance.

articles.title: ‘It’s 3p on a pack of sausages’: UK food firms say packaging tax adds to inflation
articles.trailText: Green groups defend ‘essential’ levy, but Gü desserts and Belvoir drinks among those who say shoppers pick up bill
articles.summary: UK food/drink SMEs say the new extended producer responsibility (EPR) packaging tax is feeding inflation. Heck estimates ~3p per sausage pack; 2025 bill £153k. Belvoir Farm faces ~£860k (≈60% of profit), adding ~25p to a 750ml cordial. Gü’s glass ramekins drive a “massive” bill; it may switch to plastic despite 70% reported reuse. Per‑tonne fees: plastic £423; aluminium £266; glass £192; paper/card £196; raising ~£1.4bn. BRC expects >80% pass‑through; BoE says EPR could lift food prices 0.5%. Green groups (WWF, Wrap) call it essential; Defra says it shifts costs from taxpayers and will modulate fees by recyclability. DRS will cover drinks containers.

articles.title: Signs of peak inflation open door to earlier Bank of England interest rate cuts
articles.trailText: Policymakers under pressure for rethink after price growth in UK remained at 3.8% in September
articles.summary: UK CPI held at 3.8% in September, below City and BoE 4.0% peak calls, as food retailers slowed price rises. Markets are bringing forward BoE rate-cut bets, with some eyeing November/December MPCs; Capital Economics now sees February (from March). WPI Strategy’s Martin Beck says November is unlikely but the wait may be shorter, with CPI trending toward 2% in H1 next year. Offsets persist: services inflation 4.7%; food prices still 4.5% y/y. UK remains high vs peers (US 2.9%). Low-income households are squeezed (42% vs 73% keeping up). Treasury may scrap 5% energy VAT (−0.2pp CPI); Chancellor Rachel Reeves to gather cabinet.

articles.title: Eurostar to run doubledecker trains through Channel tunnel from 2031
articles.trailText: Operator signs €2bn deal with Alstom amid boom in international rail travel from UK
articles.summary: Eurostar will run double‑deck “Celestia” trains through the Channel tunnel from 2031 after a €2bn Alstom order for at least 30, up to 50. Each carries >1,000 passengers, ~20% more seats than current trains, plus space for wheelchairs/bikes. 16cm taller, they fit HS1/tunnel clearances but won’t operate on the wider UK network. Maintenance at London Temple Mills, set for a €80m upgrade creating 350 jobs. Eurostar targets 30m passengers, retiring older stock except 17 e320s; fleet up ~30% if 50 delivered. ORR weighing depot bids from Virgin, FS Italiane/Evolyn and Gemini; decision due by 31 Oct. FS pledges Ashford calls; Virgin 12 Avelias.

articles.title: Real living wage to rise by almost 7% in boost for low-paid UK workers
articles.trailText: Hourly rate to increase by 95p to £14.80 in London and by 85p to £13.45 for the rest of the country
articles.summary: UK’s voluntary Real Living Wage will rise immediately to £13.45/hour nationwide (+85p, +6.7%) and £14.80 in London (+95p, +6.9%), benefiting almost 500,000 workers at 16,000 accredited employers (over half of FTSE 100; new sign-ups: Uniqlo, University of Salford, Truro city council). Employers must implement by 1 May. Calculated from living costs by the Living Wage Foundation, it applies to 18+, unlike the statutory National Living Wage, expected ~£12.71 from April for 21+. Foundation research: 42% of low-paid used food banks in the past year; some firms also pledge “Living Hours” (≥16 weekly hours, 1-month shift notice, hours-reflective contracts).

articles.title: Water firms in England could face harsher sewage fines under new Environment Agency powers
articles.trailText: Government consults on allowing regulator to use lower civil standard of proof and introducing automatic penalties
articles.summary: Government consults on giving the Environment Agency a lower civil standard of proof for minor-to-moderate pollution, enabling more, faster fines for sewage dumping. Options include civil penalty caps of £350k or £500k; "speeding ticket" automatic penalties of £10k/£15k/£20k for clear breaches. Prosecutions currently <1% and probes take years. Ofwat leniency cited: Thames Water £123m fines on bespoke plan; creditors seek relief on up to £1bn expected fines. Regulators to be streamlined: Defra plans to abolish Ofwat, merging powers with DWI and EA; new growth duty from chancellor Rachel Reeves. Environment secretary Emma Reynolds backs tougher, automatic sanctions. Annual sector cost £50m-£67m; fines to hit shareholders, not bills.

articles.title: Wegovy maker Novo Nordisk’s chair and six other board members step down
articles.trailText: Surprise shake-up follows row with majority shareholder, which seeks ‘extensive reconfiguration’
articles.summary: Novo Nordisk’s chair Helge Lund, vice-chair Henrik Poulsen and five independent directors will quit at a 14 Nov extraordinary meeting after a clash with majority owner Novo Nordisk Foundation, which demanded an extensive board reconfiguration. The shake-up follows May’s ouster of CEO Lars Fruergaard Jørgensen amid slowing profit growth, a share-price slide and competitive pressure from Eli Lilly’s Mounjaro/Zepbound, shown to beat Wegovy on weight loss. Shares fell 1.57% Tuesday. The foundation will nominate five directors, naming ex-CEO Lars Rebien Sørensen as chair for 2–3 years, backing new CEO Mike Doustdar’s “transformation,” including 9,000 job cuts (11%).

articles.title: Why thousands are queuing for hours in central Sydney to buy gold
articles.trailText: Investors are trading out of shares and currencies and into gold – but experts are wary of a correction
articles.summary: Record queues at ABC Bullion in Sydney—about 1,000 customers daily, 400+ lining Martin Place—reflect a rush into gold as prices jump from US$3,400 in April to >US$4,300 this week (US$4,200→US$4,300 Sat–Tue). The store extended hours and hired five staff. Drivers: geopolitical risk, US policy intervention, inflation and falling rates, and equity jitters (AI bubble fears). RBC now sees US$5,000 by early 2026; funds, central banks and retail join in. Retail anecdotes include a nurse shifting A$78k from term deposits to gold, now ~A$112k; some pivot to silver. Yet gold slumped to US$4,107 overnight (−6%, worst since 2013). AMP warns of a correction.

articles.title: UK office, shop and warehouse construction plunges to 11-year low as costs soar
articles.trailText: Investment in offices falls amid uncertainty over pricing, volatile geopolitics and the economy
articles.summary: UK commercial construction hit an 11-year low, with office, retail and industrial starts down 21% to 5.85m sq m in Q3, CoStar said. High costs due to skill shortages and inflation, elevated rates since 2022 curbed activity; 2025 is on track to be weakest for starts this century. Housebuilding slowing, jeopardising Labour’s 1.5m-home pledge. Office investment fell amid pricing uncertainty and bond yields, though London deals hint at a Q4 rebound. Office take-up rose 24% YoY to 1m sq m (London +34%); vacancies 8.8% UK, 10.7% London. Warehouse vacancy doubled to 5.5% as 557,000 sq m completions outpaced demand.

articles.title: Bank of England chief warns of ‘worrying echoes’ of 2008 financial crisis
articles.trailText: Andrew Bailey says a close look is needed at the private credit market after collapse of two big US firms
articles.summary: BoE governor Andrew Bailey warned of "worrying echoes" of 2008 after collapses of US private-credit exposures at First Brands and Tricolor, urging a "drains up" probe to judge whether they are canaries or isolated. He cited resurging slicing/dicing and tranching, and cautioned against ratings-agency complacency. Deputy governor Sarah Breeden said the BoE will war-game private credit to map links to banks, noting high leverage, opacity, complexity and weak underwriting in the defaults. JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon likened the failures to "cockroaches". The IMF flagged tight bank–private credit interconnections; chief Kristalina Georgieva said the risk keeps her awake.

articles.title: Pizza Hut administration: the 68 restaurants that will close
articles.trailText: US company Yum! Brands appoints FTI as administrators to oversee deal that will preserve 1,276 jobs
articles.summary: Pizza Hut’s UK franchisee DC London Pie entered administration, appointing FTI. Yum! Brands executed a pre-pack, acquiring the UK restaurant operation and taking direct ownership. The restructuring will close 68 dine‑in sites nationwide (from London’s Finchley Lido, Greenwich and Beckton to Carlisle, Rhyl, Brighton Marina, Leeds Colton Mill, Manchester Fort, Portsmouth, Truro and Yeovil) plus 11 delivery‑only outlets (Aylesbury, Bletchley/Wolverton/Milton Keynes, Coventry North/West, Dunstable, Leighton Buzzard, Luton, Rugby, Uxbridge). About 1,210 roles are at risk; 64 restaurants are saved, preserving 1,276 jobs, providing a stable platform for the brand. Closures also span Edinburgh, Croydon, Dundee, Norwich, Hull and Inverness.

articles.title: UK borrowing reaches five-year high for September at £20.2bn
articles.trailText: Rising debt interest and welfare costs push public finances deeper into red before Rachel Reeves’s budget
articles.summary: UK public sector net borrowing hit £20.2bn in September, the highest since 2020 and £1.6bn above a year earlier, as debt interest (+£3.8bn) and welfare costs outpaced receipts. Year-to-date borrowing is £99.8bn, £7.2bn above the OBR’s March forecast; the current-budget deficit is £71.8bn versus £58.8bn forecast. Employer NICs added £3.2bn, but spending rose by over £10bn. The OBR expects lower H2 borrowing from a CGT spike, lower interest and slower benefits growth. Economists warn a near-5% of GDP deficit and tight headroom. Reeves’s 26 Nov budget may raise taxes, trim welfare, to plug a £20-£40bn gap. Gilt yields eased; consumption flat.

articles.title: Reeves has mountain to climb in budget after borrowing rise
articles.trailText: Public finances figures contain no shocks but will underline need for either hefty tax rises or spending cuts
articles.summary: UK chancellor Rachel Reeves faces a tougher pre-budget backdrop: in April–September 2025 borrowing totalled £99.8bn, £7.2bn above the OBR’s March forecast, though September’s deficit was just £100m off target. An ONS VAT error and stronger receipts prompted a £4.2bn downward revision, but inflation and wage growth both boost income tax via fiscal drag and swell index-linked gilt costs. The current budget deficit is £71.8bn YTD, £10.6bn (17.2%) higher year on year. September borrowing was £20.2bn, the highest since the pandemic. With U-turn impacts still to come, Reeves must hit a balanced current budget by year five, implying hefty tax rises or tighter departmental spending; the IMF flags the UK’s largest planned primary deficit cut in the G7/G20.

articles.title: Labour’s clean energy plan needs a revamp: get real on costs and ignore the artificial deadline | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Would long-term strategy be imperilled if, say, only 80% of UK electricity generation was low carbon by 2032? Hardly
articles.summary: Nils Pratley argues Labour must rethink its 2030 95% clean-power sprint: it will not cut household bills £300 unless gas prices plunge, and may raise them. Energy chiefs (Octopus, E.On, EDF) told MPs non-commodity charges will add ~£300/year, with prices 20% higher even if wholesale halves—driven by £80bn grid build, Sizewell C levies and Ofgem returns. Electricity demand is 9% below 2019. Miliband’s mooted 5% VAT cut would shift costs to taxpayers (~£2.5bn). Pratley urges ditching the arbitrary deadline, cutting constraint costs (~£4bn by 2030), aligning grid to demand, and slowing offshore wind—buy ~4GW in AR7 (cap £113/MWh).

articles.title: Pizza Hut to close 68 UK restaurants, putting up to 1,200 jobs at risk
articles.trailText: Firm behind venues falls into administration but Yum! Brands buys remainder of operation in Britain
articles.summary: Pizza Hut will shut 68 UK dine-in restaurants plus 11 delivery-only sites, putting up to 1,200 jobs at risk, after franchisee DC London Pie entered administration and appointed FTI. Yum! Brands bought the remainder in a pre-pack, taking direct control of 64 sites and safeguarding 1,277 roles. HMRC filed a winding-up petition on 11 September. The move follows Directional Capital’s purchase of the UK franchise nine months ago. Pizza Hut has struggled with inflation-hit demand, higher energy costs and a 2024 national insurance rise, after prior pandemic-era closures and marketing controversies. Founded in the UK in 1973, the chain peaked near 700 sites by 2006 but has been squeezed by intense casual-dining competition.

articles.title: SlimFast’s European arm sold after struggling to compete with weight-loss drugs
articles.trailText: Typhoo tea owner Supreme acquires business from Irish nutrition and food firm Glanbia for £20m
articles.summary: Typhoo tea owner Supreme has bought SlimFast’s UK and Europe unit from Glanbia for £20.1m, seeking scale in weight management despite GLP‑1 rivals (Wegovy, Mounjaro). SlimFast’s European sales have fallen, weighing on stronger US trading; the unit generated £25.5m sales and £6m–£7m pre‑tax profit last year. Supreme says SlimFast fits its drinks/wellness arm and a market forecast to reach £1.5bn by 2027. The move follows Supreme’s deals for Clearly Drinks (Jun 2024) and Typhoo (2024). SlimFast, founded 1977, sold to Unilever (£1.4bn, 2000), Kainos (2014), and Glanbia ($350m, 2018). Glanbia cited shifting consumer weight‑management. CEO Sandy Chadha touted product innovation to broaden the brand.

articles.title: Secret Cinema company is bought by Hollywood power broker
articles.trailText: Owner of London-based immersive film and TV business sold for undisclosed sum to Ari Emanuel’s Mari
articles.summary: Hollywood power broker Ari Emanuel’s events company, Mari, has acquired TodayTix Group—owner of Secret Cinema—from Great Hill Partners for an undisclosed sum. Mari, backed by Apollo and RedBird (investor in Liverpool FC, AC Milan; pursuing Telegraph), earlier bought Frieze for $200m. TodayTix (20m members; ~200 staff, half London) began as Broadway/West End ticketing, expanded into NYC experiences, and bought Secret Cinema for $100m in 2022. Secret Cinema runs IP-based immersive events with Disney/Netflix (Guardians of the Galaxy, Stranger Things). CEO Brian Fenty stays, joins Mari’s exec team; aims to extend ticketing into sports/art. Emanuel also owns tennis assets Miami/Madrid and oversees WWE/UFC.

articles.title: China’s economic growth slows amid Trump tariff war and property woes
articles.trailText: GDP rises by 4.8% year on year between July and September, down from second-quarter growth rate of 5.2%
articles.summary: China’s Q3 GDP grew 4.8% y/y (5.2% in Q2) and 1.1% q/q, underscoring weak domestic demand amid Trump’s tariff war and a worsening property bust. Sept property investment -13.9% y/y (Aug -12.9%); real retail sales growth slowed to 3.5% (from 4.1%). Industrial output beat at +6.5%. Trade beat forecasts, contributing just over a quarter of growth: exports to US -27%, but EU +14%, SE Asia +15.6%, Africa +56.4%; export orders rose. Growth tracks the 5% target, but fragile confidence, falling new-home prices and a 12.5% drop in transactions keep stimulus in play. He Lifeng meets US Treasury’s Scott Bessent; fourth plenum opens to frame 2026–30 plan.

articles.title: Gucci owner Kering to sell beauty division to L’Oréal for €4bn
articles.trailText: New chief executive Luca de Meo aims to bring down debt burden and refocus on core fashion business
articles.summary: Kering will sell its beauty arm to L’Oréal for €4bn, including Creed and a 50-year exclusive licence to develop fragrances/beauty for Gucci, Bottega Veneta and Balenciaga, effective after Gucci’s Coty deal ends in 2028. New CEO Luca de Meo’s first major move targets deleveraging and refocusing on fashion; net debt was €9.5bn at June-end (plus €6bn in leases). Kering Beauté, built from the €3.5bn Creed acquisition in 2023, lost €60m operating in H1. Gucci revenue fell 25% amid China softness; creative reset now under Demna. Jefferies models €800m sales/€280m op profit; Bernstein deems the sale necessary. Shares: Kering +5%, L’Oréal about +1%.

articles.title: B&M ousts finance chief as it warns again on profits after £7m accounts error
articles.trailText: Discount retailer looks for successor for Mike Schmidt, who is stepping down as chief financial officer
articles.summary: B&M ousted CFO Mike Schmidt after a £7m overseas freight cost misposting (COGS recognition error from a systems update), issuing a second profit warning in two weeks. FY to Mar 2026 adjusted profit cut to £470m-£520m (from £510m-£560m); H1 now £191m (from £198m). Shares fell ~20% Tuesday and are ~50% lower YTD. The flaw is fixed; an external review is planned, with more detail due 13 Nov. Schmidt will stay until a successor is found. New CEO Tjeerd Jegen’s “back to basics” plan targets price cuts, range and on‑shelf availability amid pressure on lower‑income shoppers. B&M runs 1,270 stores, incl. 140 in France.

articles.title: What’s gone wrong at WPP? The crown slips at world’s biggest advertising group
articles.trailText: Exodus of big clients, falling profits and dire forecasts raise prospect of a once ‘unthinkable’ breakup
articles.summary: WPP’s slump deepened after an August profit warning: market cap ~£4bn (vs £25bn eight years ago), risking FTSE 100 ejection. Loss of Mars’s $1.7bn global account prompted CEO Mark Read’s exit after controversial brand consolidations (retiring JWT, Y&R, Wunderman). Despite £300m/year AI spend and 70k staff using WPP Open, margins fell to 8.2% in H1 2025 (11.5% prior); operating profit -35%, raising interest-cover worries. Publicis eclipsed WPP (value €21bn; stock up ~200%/5yrs). New CEO Cindy Rose struck a five‑year $400m Google AI deal (Gemini, Veo). Analysts see a one‑year window before breakup/takeover, though WPP Media, managing ~$60bn, may underpin a turnaround; EV ~£7.5bn; some funds are accumulating.

articles.title: Experiential entertainment is having a gold rush but commercial success is far from certain
articles.trailText: As an immersive Hunger Games show opens in London, producers turn to bankable franchises, with mixed results
articles.summary: London’s 1,200-seat Troubadour debuts an immersive Hunger Games (tickets to £200; John Malkovich on-screen as President Snow), underscoring an IP-led experiential boom. Investor Chip Seelig (TSG) backs Come Alive! (Greatest Showman), extended at the BBC Earth site. Yet costs bite: NYT says none of 18 Broadway commercial musicals profited last season. Quality scandals—Detroit “Bridgerton” ball, Glasgow Willy Wonka, Elvis Evolution at ExCel (£75–£300; no hologram)—erode trust. Gensler pegs the market at £98bn in 2025, £351bn by 2030. Moves: LLE gets 10-year Crystal Maze rights; Ari Emanuel nears a deal for TodayTix (Secret Cinema owner); TodayTix paused 2024 launches.

articles.title: French theme park firm won UK government support despite far-right ties
articles.trailText: Tory trade minister promised to ‘assist’ plans to open £600m Puy du Fou site in Oxfordshire, emails shows
articles.summary: FoI emails show UK trade minister Lord Dominic Johnson met Puy du Fou in Dec 2022, asked the Office for Investment to help site a £600m Oxfordshire theme park, and offered DBT support. The company says government was very supportive. DBT wouldn’t confirm council contact but backed the project and said Russia ties had ended. The plan faces local objections over traffic, water and environment. Labour’s Chris Bryant raised founders’ far-right links and Nicolas de Villiers’s 2014 praise of Putin and ties to sanctioned oligarch Malofeyev. The firm calls objections conspiracies, says it passed due diligence; a planning application was filed in August.

articles.title: The return of ‘Tescopoly’? How Britain’s biggest retailer dominates everyday life
articles.trailText: Supermarket chain has quietly got its groove back to grab even more of shoppers’ spending this year
articles.summary: Tesco has quietly reasserted dominance: 28.3% grocery share (26.5% in 2020; peak ~32%), targeting >30%, and taking >£1 in every £10 of UK retail (vs Sainsbury’s 15.3%). Growth is led by convenience and online: 1,675 Express (+43 YTD), 730 One Stop, and Booker-supplied Premier (4,800), Londis (2,490) and Budgens (452). Online is 14% of sales, up 11% YoY, with 37% share of UK online grocery. Clubcard (24m households) powers personalised pricing, challenges and ads; a marketplace now lists 600,000 non-food SKUs. Critics cite £3.1bn profits and CEO pay (£9.2m); Tesco touts £500m savings and price cuts. Discounters, indebted rivals and potential CMA-enabled consolidation shape the outlook; margins 4.5% on £63.6bn.

articles.title: Ed Miliband needs a plan now to help industry weather UK transition to net zero | Phillip Inman
articles.trailText: Manufacturing is buckling under sky-high energy bills. Time to closely regulate price-gouging gas plants or take ownership of supply
articles.summary: UK manufacturing is buckling under power costs as net-zero rollout bites. ONS: energy‑intensive sectors (paper, chemicals, plastics, food, metals) down one‑third since 2021, lowest since 1990. Bills rise via high electricity, higher network charges, and a 2025 scheme shielding 500 top users funded by all firms. Miliband spent >£2bn this year balancing the grid—curtailing wind and firing gas. Gas supplies 30% yet sets prices ~97% of the time. Reeves resists broad subsidies; Germany similar; US industrial power <¼. Remedies urged: regulate gas ‘scarcity rents’ (Stonehaven/Greenpeace) or nationalise gas; invest now to cut tariffs—or face plant closures/offshoring.

articles.title: What is private credit, and should we be worried by the collapse of US firms?
articles.trailText: First Brands and Tricolor failures raise concerns for wider financial sector, including traditional banks
articles.summary: The collapses of US firms First Brands (auto parts) and Tricolor (subprime auto lender) spotlight private credit—nonbank lenders funded by pensions, insurers and wealthy investors in the shadow‑banking/NBFI sphere. The $3tn market (ACC/EY 2024), dominated by Blackstone, Apollo, Ares and KKR, swelled post‑2008 amid tighter bank rules and cheap funding; BlackRock sees $4.5tn by 2030. Banks are now entwined: Jefferies has $715m exposure to First Brands; JPMorgan lost $170m on Tricolor. Critics cite regulatory arbitrage, opacity and weak underwriting; Jamie Dimon warned of more “cockroaches.” IMF and BoE flag systemic links and data gaps. UK pensions are channeling £50bn into private markets. Global tightening looks unlikely, especially if US deregulates.

articles.title: French customs reject British shellfish shipments after UK ‘reset’ deal with EU
articles.trailText: One of the largest mussel exporters in Britain loses £150,000 after three lorries were prevented from entering EU
articles.summary: Devon-based Offshore Shellfish lost £150,000 after French customs at Boulogne-sur-Mer rejected three of four season-opening blue mussel shipments, forcing destruction of loads. The firm, which has sent hundreds of consignments since Brexit without rejection, says reasons (insufficient washing) were subjective and possibly political after the UK-EU ‘reset’ talks to remove SPS checks by 2027. Live bivalves face strict EU rules; its Lyme Bay farms are mostly Class A. UK government says it sees no spike in rejections and is pursuing an SPS deal worth up to £5.1bn. Exports—processed in the Netherlands, sold largely in Belgium—may resume after agreed rule “flexibility” is tested.

articles.title: If you like a lot of chocolate on your biscuit … look away now
articles.trailText: Club and Penguin bars are now ‘chocolate flavour’ after owner McVitie’s cuts cocoa content amid soaring prices
articles.summary: McVitie’s has reformulated Club and Penguin bars, replacing chocolate with a 'chocolate flavour' coating containing more palm and shea oils than cocoa, so they can no longer be marketed as chocolate biscuits. Owner Pladis cites record cocoa costs after climate-driven harvest failures in Ghana and Ivory Coast; prices more than doubled in 2024 and neared $11/kg in January before easing on better crop outlook and softer demand. Pladis says consumer tests show similar taste; Club’s slogan now 'If you like a lot of biscuit in your break.' Industry tactics include shrinkflation and cocoa reduction. Other reclassifications: KitKat White and McVitie’s white digestives (not 'white chocolate'); Wagon Wheel already 'chocolate flavour.' Nestlé says recipe descriptors are accurate.

articles.title: Bank shares lead global market fall amid jitters over US private credit
articles.trailText: Signs of credit stress send markets in Europe and Asia down, while investors turn to safe haven assets
articles.summary: Bank shares led a global sell-off after US regional lenders flagged bad loans, sending investors into gold at a record $4,378/oz (+8.5% week, biggest since 2008). Europe fell: FTSE 100 −0.9%, Dax −1.8%, FTSE Mib −1.5%, Ibex −0.3%, Cac 40 −0.2%; banks lost €37.4bn (UK big five −£11bn), with Barclays −6%, Banco Sabadell −6.78%, Deutsche Bank −6%. Asia slid: Nikkei −1.6%, Hang Seng −2%. Zions wrote off $50m; Western Alliance pursued a ~$100m bad loan; shares −10%/−9%. Fears of private-credit stress, echoing SVB 2023 and Tricolor/First Brands failures, lifted the VIX +22% Thu, +6% Fri. Wall Street steadied Friday a.m.

articles.title: ‘A foot out in the cold’: leaders huddle at IMF as icy economic winds blow
articles.trailText: Worries over private credit, tax and spend, skittish bond markets and tariff chaos dominate meeting in Washington
articles.summary: At IMF meetings in Washington, Kristalina Georgieva warned markets are complacent despite policy turmoil, flagging three risks: frothy AI/tech valuations, volatile sovereign bonds amid swelling debts, and opaque private credit/NBFIs. Banks hold $4.5tn exposure to NBFIs; recent failures (First Brands, Tricolor) and stress at Western Alliance and Zions stoked cockroach fears per Jamie Dimon. IMF urges tighter oversight. Trump focuses on China trade and a G20 push on imbalances, not regulation. UK’s Rachel Reeves preps tax rises; gilt yields fell amid flight to safety. Andrew Bailey cautioned on stretched valuations. IMF says an AI reversal could sharply dent investment; a crisis would hit debt-laden, fragmented economies.

articles.title: What could a Trump deal on critical minerals mean for Australia – and could Maga be a sticking point?
articles.trailText: Ahead of Anthony Albanese’s White House visit, a ‘price floor’ and US investment in mining ventures have been flagged
articles.summary: Ahead of Albanese’s White House visit, Canberra plans to trade critical‑minerals leverage amid fresh US‑China friction after Beijing tightened rare‑earth exports. Australia mines ~50% of lithium and ~25% of bauxite; China controls ~70% of rare‑earth mining and ~90% of processing, and supplies >50% of US‑listed critical inputs. Proposal: a A$1.2bn strategic reserve with a taxpayer‑backed price floor and access for US/EU investors; Washington may take equity in Australian projects. Goals: secure AUKUS and cushion Trump tariffs. Risks: 90% of Australia’s lithium exports go to China (forecast A$8.2bn by 2030). Domestic processing is thin; a 10% processing tax credit starts July 2027. MAGA’s home‑jobs focus may block US backing for Australian downstream.

articles.title: UK government borrowing costs fall to lowest level since July
articles.trailText: Boost for Rachel Reeves as bond yield falls while she considers tax rises and spending cuts in budget
articles.summary: UK 10-year gilt yields fell ~15bp this week, briefly below 4.5%—lowest since July—boosting Chancellor Rachel Reeves as she shapes the 26 Nov autumn budget. The drop reflects global flight-to-quality on US-China trade tensions and stress at US regional banks (bad loans, alleged fraud), plus Reeves’s IMF signals of tax rises on the wealthy and possible spending cuts, which improved gilt sentiment. IFS warns of a £22bn fiscal hole and likely OBR downgrades; OBR will fix borrowing-cost assumptions using a 10-day October yield snapshot. Despite the fall, UK yields remain above G7 peers. Soft data—jobless rate 4.8%, slower pay, GDP +0.1% in Aug—may bolster BoE rate-cut bets.

articles.title: Gaucho chain to slash waiters’ share of service charge and boost head office pay
articles.trailText: Restaurant group plans to cut share as low as 17% for new waiting staff, with office workers among those benefiting
articles.summary: Argentinian steak chain Gaucho will cut waiters’ share of the automatic 12.5–13% service charge from 1 Oct: existing staff to 25.45–29.4% (from 37%; 45% in early 2024), new hires to 17%; bar staff to 17% (from 20%). Troncmaster WMT will divert tronc to head office, central production and some agency staff, arguing tips reflect the whole experience. Unite questions compliance with the “fair, transparent” tipping code. Staff weren’t consulted, fear all waiters drop to 17% in 2025, and expect £300–£600 monthly losses; one’s net pay to ~£1,600. Owner Rare Restaurants’ Gioma UK lost £15.6m on £68.5m sales. Gaucho says the business doesn’t benefit.

articles.title: ‘Finances are getting tighter’: US car repossessions surge as more Americans default on auto loans
articles.trailText: Wall Street sounds alarm over strain throughout car lending market as experts warn of potential risks for wider economy
articles.summary: US auto-loan stress is surging, pushing repossessions to multi-year highs. JPMorgan took a $170m hit tied to Tricolor's bankruptcy; CEO Jamie Dimon warned "when you see one cockroach..." First Brands got $500m rescue financing amid fears of "lending good money after bad." Repossessions hit 1.73m last year (highest since 2009); subprime 60+ day delinquencies reached 6.5% in January (Fitch). With 100m borrowers and average payments >$750, 85% of new and 55% of used cars are financed; 2023 affordability fell to 42 weeks of income. As the No. 3 consumer credit market, stress matters; repo firms report rising safety risks. Loss of Covid-era health subsidies could deepen strains; Santander's $550m fine underscores subprime risks; Tricolor faces fraud probes.

articles.title: Ferrari cuts number of cars it sends to UK after non-dom tax status scrapped
articles.trailText: Carmaker says reasons for reduction include that some wealthy people ‘are getting out of the country’
articles.summary: Ferrari has cut UK allocations over the past six months to protect residual values after April’s abolition of non‑dom status and higher levies on the wealthy prompted some rich buyers to leave, CEO Benedetto Vigna said. Right‑hand‑drive limits also reduce cross‑market resale. Residuals fell: Purosangue −12.2% Jan–Oct; SF90 −6.6% (AutoTrader), with sales now stabilising. Depreciation‑driven finance raised leasing costs. A new 296 GTB listed at £256,275; used examples at £189,490. Chancellor Rachel Reeves called exodus claims scaremongering, while flagging higher‑earner tax measures (not a wealth tax), e.g., higher CGT, NI on rents/partnerships, higher council tax bands.

articles.title: The ‘messy’ trend behind Australia’s rising unemployment is worrying economists
articles.trailText: The RBA is holding fire on further rate cuts until it is confident that inflation is easing. But the latest jobs data complicates matters
articles.summary: Australia’s jobless rate rose to 4.5%—a near four-year high—overshooting RBA/Treasury peak expectations (~4.3%). This follows a 3.1ppt pandemic-era rise in the employment rate (double the OECD average; US/NZ flat; Canada −0.4ppt; UK −1.1ppt). Economists fear a “messy” handover as public-sector care-economy hiring (80–90% of 2023–24 gains; >1m jobs since 2022) slows and private demand lags. AMP’s Shane Oliver warns of a clear uptrend; Westpac sees 4.8% by early 2026. Markets eye a Melbourne Cup day cut. Ex-RBA’s Jonathan Kearns urges caution: employment still rose in September, but a labour-supply surge lifted unemployment; Oct 29 CPI is pivotal.

articles.title: Australia Post incorrectly charged tariffs on items ordered online being returned to the US
articles.trailText: Trump tariffs are not meant to apply to returned goods if they were manufactured in the US
articles.summary: Australia Post admitted it wrongly charged tariffs on online returns to the US for US-manufactured items after services resumed (business 22 Sep, retail 7 Oct), blaming a miscoded third-party system. The error, surfaced by Guardian Australia (e.g., $57.17 on a $357.30 return ~16%), has been fixed and refunds issued. CBP says Trump’s new regime applies to returns, with duty based on country of origin—so US-ordered but China-made goods can incur China tariffs. The US ended the de minimis <$800 on 29 Aug and set baseline 10% liberation day tariffs; gifts <US$100 exempt. Australia Post uses Zonos; minister Annika Wells says it was promptly fixed and seeks tariff removal.

articles.title: US regional bank stocks fall amid Wall Street concern over credit markets
articles.trailText: Zions and Western Alliance reveal problems with bad loans as scrutiny of regional banks’ lending practices increases
articles.summary: US regional bank stocks fell after disclosures of bad and fraudulent loans. Zions Bancorp took $50m charge-offs over two loans at California Bank & Trust (San Diego); Western Alliance cited a fraudulent borrower. Zions -11%+, Western Alliance -10%+, Jefferies -9% intraday; S&P 500 -0.7%, Dow -0.6%. Scrutiny intensified after First Brands' late-Sept Chapter 11, with $10bn-$50bn liabilities vs $1bn-$10bn assets; creditors say $2.3bn vanished. DOJ probing. Jefferies and UBS have hundreds of millions exposure; Jefferies shares -25% month. Case spotlights shadow-banking invoice-collateral financing. JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon warned: see one cockroach, there are probably more.

articles.title: Thousands in UK take legal action against Johnson & Johnson over alleged talc cancer link
articles.trailText: High court claim says company knowingly sold product containing asbestos and ‘concealed’ risk to public
articles.summary: About 3,000 UK claimants have filed a High Court suit alleging Johnson & Johnson sold asbestos-contaminated Johnson’s Baby Powder that caused ovarian cancer and mesothelioma, seeking over £1bn. Defendants are J&J, J&J Management and Kenvue UK; plaintiffs say J&J knew supplier talc deposits contained asbestos, concealed risks, lobbied regulators and funded studies to downplay harm; powder use allegedly created inhalation clouds. J&J replaced talc with cornstarch and ended talc powder globally in 2023 after earlier US/Canada withdrawal. Kenvue, spun off in 2023 and handling non-US/Canada talc claims, and J&J deny liability, citing compliant, asbestos-free talc and decades of independent testing. Cases include a 75-year-old with ovarian cancer and a widow whose husband died of mesothelioma.

articles.title: Head of IMF says risks in private credit market keep her awake at night
articles.trailText: Kristalina Georgieva urges vigilance over ‘very significant shift of financing’ after collapse of Tricolor and First Brands
articles.summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva warned that the rapid shift of financing to lightly regulated NBFIs/private credit—underscored by failures at Tricolor and First Brands—could become systemic in a downturn. She urged tighter oversight as banks expand lending to private credit funds for higher ROE, raising concentration risks in the US and Europe. Despite stronger post‑2008 frameworks and major‑economy reserves, many countries lack fiscal space and inflation persists. She flagged stretched equity valuations if AI optimism fades. BlackRock sees private credit AUM rising from ~$3tn to $4.5tn by 2030; IMF also warns of pressure on government bonds.

articles.title: UK economy expands as GDP rises by 0.1% in August ahead of crucial budget
articles.trailText: Manufacturing and health sectors boost growth but ONS revises down figures for July
articles.summary: UK GDP rose 0.1% in August, driven by a 0.7% manufacturing rebound (pharma-led) and stronger health output, offset by flat services and a 0.3% fall in construction (maintenance/repair down; new build +0.5%). July was revised to -0.1%, leaving three-month growth at 0.3%. In line with forecasts, the UK is on track to be G7’s second-fastest grower in 2025. Ahead of the 26 Nov budget, Reeves weighs £20bn–£30bn tax rises amid subdued demand and hiring. ONS revisions lift post‑Feb 2020 growth to 5.5%; productivity estimates are higher, implying stronger OBR projections and tax receipts. Inflation easing expected; BoE cuts eyed in 2026; Trump‑Beijing tariff spat clouds trade.

articles.title: ‘When I was a child, everyone used it’: woman blames Johnson & Johnson talc for her cancer
articles.trailText: Sue Rizzello is among thousands in UK suing the firm, which denies selling baby powder containing asbestos
articles.summary: UK ovarian cancer survivor Sue Rizzello, 60, says decades of using Johnson’s Baby Powder caused her disease. Diagnosed in 2012 with stage 3 ovarian cancer, she endured chemo and removal of her uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes and omentum, then went into remission; BRCA genetic tests were negative. She is among about 3,000 UK claimants launching a High court action in London alleging J&J knew its talc could contain asbestos yet sold it in Britain until 2023. J&J and Kenvue (spun off in 2023, handling non-US/Canada claims) deny asbestos, cite regulatory compliance, and say talc doesn’t cause cancer. US talc litigation continues.

articles.title: Cost of taking over British Steel rises to £235m, government says
articles.trailText: Taxpayers have been footing bill for loss-making company since April as minister acknowledges threat of EU tariffs
articles.summary: The UK says the cost of taking control of British Steel has climbed to £235m since April, after emergency legislation to prevent owner Jingye walking away from the Scunthorpe works and to safeguard 3,500 jobs. Taxpayers are funding working capital—raw materials, wages and unpaid SME bills—on top of £604m spent supporting the plant in 2019–20. Ministers aim to boost output; Jingye had said Scunthorpe was losing £700,000 a day amid a global glut. A GMB union backed the spend, contrasting it with £500m to Tata preceding 2,000 redundancies. Sector risks loom as the EU considers raising steel import tariffs to 50%; 78% of UK steel exports go to the EU. London seeks quotas while global coordination on Chinese overcapacity remains elusive.

articles.title: Nestlé to axe 16,000 jobs as new chief targets sales growth
articles.trailText: Almost 6% of global workforce will be cut over next two years, including 12,000 white-collar professionals
