articles.summary: Nestlé will cut 16,000 jobs over two years (~6% of staff): 12,000 white-collar and 4,000 in manufacturing/supply chain, as new CEO Philipp Navratil accelerates restructuring to boost growth. Savings target lifted to CHF3bn by 2027 (from CHF2.5bn), with more automation and tighter resource allocation. Nine-month sales fell 1.9% to CHF65.9bn on -5.4% FX; organic growth +3.3%, led by coffee and confectionery amid inflation-driven price rises (some double-digit) and higher coffee/cocoa costs. All regions grew organically (EM +5.2%, developed +2.1%). Brands include KitKat, Nescafé, Häagen-Dazs, Nespresso, Purina. UK employs ~4,200 (Gatwick HQ, York KitKat plant); country cuts undisclosed. Navratil replaced fired CEO Laurent Freixe; chair Paul Bulcke resigned.

articles.title: 75% of Americans report soaring prices as Trump claims inflation ‘over’
articles.trailText: Exclusive poll: Inflation remains a concern despite president’s pledge to reduce prices on ‘day one’
articles.summary: An exclusive Harris Poll (Sept 11–13, 2025; n=2,093) finds 74% of Americans say monthly household costs rose at least $100 ($100–$749), contradicting President Trump’s “prices are way down” claims. CPI edged from 3.0% in January to 2.9% in August, still above the Fed’s 2% target. 54% believe the US is in recession; 53% say the economy is worsening. Inflation is the top risk for Republicans (31%) and independents (33%); Democrats prioritize tariffs (31%). Yale Budget Lab estimates Trump tariffs add $2,300/year ($191/month). Republicans mostly blame routine inflation (45%); 55% of Democrats/independents cite current policies. Democratic ideas (grocery price gouging ban 45%) outpoll Trump’s; his best is eliminating Social Security taxes (43%).

articles.title: An unexpected unemployment rate rise puts the RBA odds-on to cut the cash rate – but it’s a headache for Jim Chalmers
articles.trailText: A resilient labour market is the jewel in Labor’s crown when it comes to its economic record. Is this month’s data a blip, or the start of something bigger?
articles.summary: Australia’s unemployment rate unexpectedly rose to 4.5% in September (from 4.3%), a four‑year high yet still low historically. Markets now see the RBA odds‑on to cut on Melbourne Cup day: November cut probability jumped from 36% to 64%, with a December cut near certain; talk of a double cut is premature. The RBA had forecast unemployment to peak at 4.3% through 2026 and kept rates steady 2½ weeks ago on inflation worries. The 29 Oct CPI will be pivotal and would need to run hot to forestall easing. Public-sector driven hiring (aged care, NDIS) has faded; private-sector momentum is uncertain. Westpac’s Pat Bustamante warns joblessness could reach ~4.8% early next year. Political headache for Treasurer Jim Chalmers at G20.

articles.title: Adani denies claims it sold ‘below-market coal’ leading to Queensland missing out on hundreds of millions in royalties
articles.trailText: Adani has strongly rejected the Australia Institute’s findings, including that customers paid an average of $102 a tonne in 2022-23
articles.summary: Australia Institute says Adani sold Carmichael thermal coal at about A$100/t on average in FY23–FY25—far below benchmarks (peaked >A$600/t) and even a quality‑discounted A$282/t in FY22–23—reducing Queensland’s progressive royalties (base 7% ≤A$100/t). It estimates A$625m was payable but Adani paid ~A$230m (~A$400m gap). Method infers price from Adani customer revenue and Qld production; 3‑month FY mismatch noted; Adani doesn’t disclose prices; buyers include related parties. Adani denies, says all royalties paid and analysis is flawed. Qld has a confidential royalty‑deferral deal. Tim Buckley urges probes; Guardian found zero corporate tax since 2021–22.

articles.title: Don’t give in to big pharma on drug pricing | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Drug manufacturers may lament the UK’s drug prices, writes Simon Dixon , but the NHS should celebrate them
articles.summary: Former University of Sheffield health economist Simon Dixon defends the UK’s cost‑effectiveness regime for NHS drug pricing, saying it’s globally respected, delivers widespread price cuts and protects overall NHS health gains. He rebuts Eli Lilly’s claim that low UK prices deter investment, arguing recent pauses reflect pharma’s desire to appease Donald Trump. Dixon condemns proposals to raise or index‑link NICE’s cost‑effectiveness threshold, stressing it measures opportunity cost: if a new drug generates less health than what it displaces, the NHS loses. Inflation doesn’t change displacement rates; linking thresholds to inflation is nonsensical. He references Guardian reports on Eli Lilly’s complaint and a plan that could make the NHS pay 25% more.

articles.title: Competition regulator barking up the right tree on vets’ opaque pricing
articles.trailText: Consumers and corporates should welcome CMA proposals to overhaul regulations unchanged since the 1960s
articles.summary: UK CMA’s 18-month probe of veterinary services finds prices rose far faster than inflation (2016–23) without commensurate upgrades, and large chains charge 16.6% more than independents, creating >£1bn customer detriment over five years. Rather than breakups or local caps, remedies target opacity: mandatory price lists, disclosure of corporate ownership, and a £16 cap on prescription-writing fees to spur online pharmacy shopping. A regulatory overhaul would, for the first time, regulate vet businesses (not just individuals), add an ombudsman, and update 1960s-era rules. Six groups, many PE-backed (IVC Evidensia, VetPartners, Medivet, CVS, Pets at Home, Linnaeus/Mars) control 60%+.

articles.title: The IMF reckons the global economy remains ‘in flux’, but the Trump effect is real – and Australians aren’t fooled | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: Even as the government and investors try to treat the Trump situation as ‘normal’, the US has never been less attractive to Australian holidaymakers
articles.summary: Greg Jericho argues Trump’s policies dominate the IMF Oct 2025 World Economic Outlook (Global Economy in Flux, Prospects Remain Dim) despite not naming him. Tariffs sparked chaos yet headline growth was revised up: US 1.8% to 2.0%, Australia 1.6% to 1.8%, helped by front-loaded orders. Still, US trade policy uncertainty is about 50% below April but 3,860% above a year earlier. Australians aren’t normalizing: outbound travel to the US is down 28% vs pre-Covid; August 2025 fell 10% y/y and Jun–Aug down 3%. Tourism Economics flipped 2025 US arrivals from +9% to -8.2%. He cites authoritarian rhetoric and actions driving the shift.

articles.title: Shein warns on Trump tariff uncertainty after profits slip
articles.trailText: Fast-fashion retailer records 20% growth in sales and fees to $37bn but big hit is expected from US changes to import tax rules
articles.summary: Shein’s 2024 revenue rose 20% to $37bn, but pre-tax profit fell 13% to $1.3bn (from $1.5bn) on higher selling and marketing costs. The Singapore-based, China-founded fast-fashion group warned April 2025 US tariff changes closing the de minimis under-$800 import loophole, and their rapid evolution, create material uncertainty and have hit US trade. Shein is pursuing a Hong Kong IPO after stalled US/UK listings (about £50bn). Revenue comes from direct sales and marketplace fees. It paid about $188m income tax; UK tax was £9.6m on £2bn sales. Critics allege profit shifting via Singapore/BVI/Cayman; HQ taxed 5-8% with $74.2m incentives. No 2024 dividend (vs $484.5m 2023).

articles.title: Global government debt on course to hit 100% of GDP by 2029, IMF warns
articles.trailText: Ratio would be highest since aftermath of second world war, with UK among G20 countries forecast to peak above
articles.summary: IMF's Fiscal Monitor warns global government debt will hit 100% of world GDP by 2029, the highest since 1948, after pandemic interventions and ongoing pressures (defense, disasters, tech, demographics, development) amid tax-hike resistance. It urges shifting spending to growth-friendly infrastructure and education. G20 members set to exceed 100% include the UK, US, China, Japan, France and Canada. Emerging and low-income economies face tougher financing; 55 countries are in or at high risk of debt distress. Campaigners call the Common Framework too slow. UK debt is seen peaking at 105.9% in 2029, easing to 105.4% in 2030; after Reeves changed fiscal rules, markets remain wary with higher gilt volatility.

articles.title: Banker bonuses to be paid faster after UK regulators loosen rules
articles.trailText: Bank of England and Financial Conduct Authority reduce deferral period from eight years to four
articles.summary: UK regulators (BoE/PRA and FCA) will halve deferral of senior bankers’ bonuses from eight to four years and shrink the withheld portion: only 60% of any payout above £660,000 must now be deferred, effective Thursday. The move rolls back post‑crisis safeguards introduced in 2015 and follows the UK’s 2023 scrapping of the EU-style bonus cap. Watchdogs say the timeline aligns with peers (EU 3–5 years; US none) and boosts competitiveness; City welcomes it. Deferred pay has enabled clawbacks, e.g., Barclays’ £18m freeze/cancellation for ex-CEO Jes Staley. Chancellor Rachel Reeves is pressing regulators to cut red tape to spur growth.

articles.title: Royal Mail fined £21m by Ofcom for missing delivery targets
articles.trailText: Communications regulator finds ‘millions of important letters are arriving late’ and ‘persistent failures’
articles.summary: Ofcom fined Royal Mail £21m after a six-month probe found only 77% of first-class mail (target 93%) and 92.5% of second-class (target 98.5%) arrived on time in 2024-25, delaying millions of letters. It’s Ofcom’s third sanction on the 509-year-old operator and its third-largest fine. The penalty was cut 30% from £30m after Royal Mail admitted liability. Ofcom ordered an urgent, credible improvement plan or further fines. Context: April 2025 takeover of owner International Distribution Services by Czech billionaire Daniel Křetínský (£3.6bn); stamp prices lifted to £1.70/£0.87; USO eased in July (end Saturday second-class, alternate weekday deliveries). Royal Mail pledges recruitment/training and a new delivery model; pilots show gains.

articles.title: Capita fined £14m for data protection failings in 2023 cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Hackers stole personal information of 6.6m people but outsourcing firm did not shut device targeted for 58 hours
articles.summary: UK ICO fined Capita £14m over a March 2023 cyber-attack that exposed data on 6.6m people, including customers of 325 pension schemes. Capita detected the intrusion within 10 minutes but left the compromised device running for 58 hours, enabling theft of nearly 1TB, ransomware installation and password resets that locked out staff. Penalties: £8m for Capita, £6m for Capita Pension Solutions; a proposed £45m was reduced after remediation and engagement with ICO/NCSC. The ICO found unfixed known vulnerabilities, an understaffed SOC, and inadequate testing; stolen data included criminal, financial and “special category” details. CEO Adolfo Hernandez says cyber defences have been significantly strengthened amid a surge in UK attacks.

articles.title: Vets could be made to cap prescription prices after UK watchdog investigation
articles.trailText: Market ‘not fit’ for purpose, CMA says, as it proposes shake-up including publishing treatment costs
articles.summary: The UK CMA says the £6.3bn vet market is not fit for purpose and proposes 21 reforms: capping prescription fees at £16; mandatory comprehensive price lists and ownership disclosure; itemised bills; written quotes over £500; cremation pricing; care-plan breakdowns; and a national price-comparison site. Owners may pay twice as much at practices as online for common medicines; large groups charge 16.6% more than independents. Vet prices rose 63% between 2016–23; acquisitions lift prices 9% after four years. Provisional findings follow 56,000 responses; submissions due next month, final by March. Groups named: CVS, Pets at Home, IVC, VetPartners, Medivet, Mars’s Linnaeus. Industry reaction mixed; analysts see tougher transparency, limited price controls.

articles.title: A quiet bite in: Charlie Bigham launches £29.95 ready meals for home diners
articles.trailText: Supermarket supplier says new pricier range is still cheaper than bill for a night out at a restaurant
articles.summary: Charlie Bigham is launching a five‑dish premium ready‑meal line priced up to £29.95 to capture at‑home “date night” spend as restaurant bills rise. Dishes include venison bourguignon (wild Scottish venison), duck confit and a salmon wellington with a sashimi‑grade fillet. Debuts this week in 70 Waitrose stores; some items cost triple the £9.95 of its bestselling fish pie. FY to 31 Aug 2024: sales +8.8% to £144.3m; pre‑tax profit +>33% to £7.7m; £2.3m dividend. Sales in 2024‑25 up >14% so far. Bigham says budget “squeeze” is overstated, shoppers want value. Rising meat/fish/labour/packaging costs may force price rises; quality won’t be cut. Supports packaging‑tax goals despite hits to compostable wood cartons; criticises inheritance‑tax changes; wary of 26 Nov budget.

articles.title: JP Morgan boss says more ‘cockroaches’ will emerge after private credit sector failures
articles.trailText: Jamie Dimon expects further weak links in ‘shadow banking’ sector to be revealed after collapse of two US firms
articles.summary: JP Morgan CEO Jamie Dimon warned more losses could surface in private credit/shadow banking after failures at subprime auto lender Tricolor and car parts supplier First Brands. JPM booked a $170m charge on Tricolor, which collapsed amid fraud allegations; it had no exposure to First Brands. Dimon likened the setbacks to seeing “one cockroach… there’s probably more,” citing opaque, lightly regulated risks in a $3tn industry and uneven underwriting standards. He expects weaker links to be revealed as the benign credit cycle ends, with broader credit deterioration. Dimon said JPM made mistakes but is “scouring” exposures and remains cautious.

articles.title: UK faces highest inflation in G7 this year and next, IMF warns
articles.trailText: According to fund’s World Economic Outlook, Britain is on course to average 3.4% this year and 2.5% in 2026
articles.summary: IMF’s WEO says the UK will post the G7’s highest inflation in 2025 and 2026: 3.4% this year and 2.5% next (up from 3.2%/2.3%). Sticky prices are pushing gilt yields higher; markets want clearer fiscal plans amid weak productivity. UK growth is forecast at 1.3% in 2025 (up) and 1.3% in 2026 (down), second-fastest in the G7 after the US (2%). With CPI at 3.8% in August and a 4% peak expected in September, the IMF urges the BoE to ease cautiously; temporary drivers include water and rail fares, but wage and expectations risks persist. Global growth is 3.2% (up), with risks from Trump tariffs, US immigration curbs, stretched equities and an AI correction. Reeves welcomed the upgrades.

articles.title: US raised concerns about Chinese boss of chipmaker before Dutch takeover
articles.trailText: Court papers show Netherlands was warned in June that Nexperia might not be able to export to US with him in post
articles.summary: US officials warned the Netherlands on 12 June that Nexperia could lose US export access unless its Chinese CEO, Zhang Xuezheng, was replaced, court filings show. After Washington put owner Wingtech on the Entity List in 2024 and, on 30 September 2025, extended it to subsidiaries—ensnaring Nexperia by late November—the Dutch invoked the rarely used Availability of Goods Act on Sunday to effectively take control, citing security-of-supply and tech-transfer risks. Zhang was suspended; a court installed Guido Dierick with a deciding vote and moved most shares to a Dutch trustee. China condemned the move, barred exports of China-assembled Nexperia parts, and state media called it “robbery.” Nexperia (Nijmegen HQ; sites in Manchester, Hamburg) is negotiating with the US; the UK earlier forced a Newport Wafer Fab sale.

articles.title: US shares risk ‘sharp correction’ but markets seem complacent, IMF warns
articles.trailText: Government bond markets also under increasing pressure, says Global Financial Stability Report
articles.summary: The IMF’s Global Financial Stability Report, issued during Washington meetings, warns US equities—buoyed by the AI boom—face a sudden, sharp correction as concentration risk surges: the “Magnificent Seven” now comprise 33% of the S&P 500. Valuations aren’t dotcom-level, but any mega-cap return shortfall could rapidly sour sentiment and drag the index lower. Government bond markets are on shakier footing as issuance rises and reliance shifts to price‑sensitive buyers; stress is a tail risk but would be broadly disruptive given bonds’ benchmark/collateral role. The IMF flags tighter bank–NBFI linkages, urges stronger NBFI oversight and full Basel III adoption (delayed in the US/UK), and defends central‑bank independence; G4 safe‑asset status rests on institutional trust.

articles.title: World economy resilient amid Trump tariffs but outlook looks ‘dim’, says IMF
articles.trailText: UK and global GDP growth forecasts upgraded for this year but immigration controls could have negative impact
articles.summary: The IMF’s WEO says global growth remains "dim" despite resilience to Donald Trump’s tariffs. Global GDP is upgraded to 3.2% this year (from 3.0%); next year stays 3.1%. Tariff effects have been smaller and front-loaded; Brexit shows investment lags. Risks: US immigration curbs could cut US GDP 0.3–0.7% and lift prices in construction, hospitality and farm work; "stretched" equities and an AI-led investment correction. UK growth: 1.3% this year; 1.3% next year (downgraded). IMF also sees UK up 2% in 2025, second-fastest G7. UK inflation: 3.4% in 2025, 2.5% in 2026. BoE urged to ease cautiously.

articles.title: EasyJet shares jump after report of potential takeover bid
articles.trailText: Investors including MSC consider offer, with options ranging from majority stake to full control, report says
articles.summary: EasyJet shares jumped up to 12%—their biggest rise in three years—after Corriere della Sera said MSC and other investors are weighing bids ranging from a majority stake to full control. Gains eased to about 4.5% by midday after easyJet declined to comment and MSC denied direct involvement. The FTSE 100 carrier, Europe’s No 2 budget airline, trades at less than half its pre‑Covid level despite £602m pre‑tax profit on £9.3bn revenue last year and guidance for more than £1bn medium term. Founder Stelios Haji‑Ioannou owns about 15% and could push for a higher price; Wizz Air was rebuffed in 2021. A takeover would further dent London listings. Analysts also flag a potential break‑up angle.

articles.title: Tesco steps up UK sales as Asda struggles amid rising inflation
articles.trailText: Marks & Spencer bounces back from cyber-attack as it extends contract of chair Archie Norman
articles.summary: Tesco extended its UK lead as grocery inflation rose. In the 12 weeks to 5 Oct, Tesco’s share was 28.3% (+0.7pp y/y) with sales up ~7%, per Worldpanel by Numerator. Asda fell to 11.8% (-0.9pp) with sales -3.2% despite chair Allan Leighton’s cuts (1,000 items last week; avg 22% reductions on over half its range in the past year). Lidl sales +10.8%, nearing Morrisons (8.2% vs 8.3%). Inflation ticked up to 5.2% (chocolate, fresh meat, coffee up), promotions 29.4% of spend. M&S food +7.7% post-cyberattack; chair Archie Norman extended three years beyond Sept 2026. Online grocery +12% to 12.7% share; >20% households shopped online.

articles.title: Young people are biggest victims of UK’s fragile jobs market
articles.trailText: Firms too scared to take a chance on youngsters when taxes and minimum wages are higher, expert says
articles.summary: UK unemployment rose to a four-year high and vacancies fell in the three months to August, hitting young people. Economists link it to Rachel Reeves's 2024 budget: April's employer NI rise to 15%, a lower NI threshold, and a higher living wage lifted hiring costs, pulling part-timers into NI and choking entry-level roles. Joe Nellis says costs, not AI, are to blame. Public-sector pay is elevated after 2024 awards, but Deutsche Bank's Sanjay Raja sees private pay settling near 3% next year. With a November budget looming, Indeed's Jack Kennedy flags weak employer confidence. ONS sees a bottoming; large firms coping despite US tariffs, SMEs reticent.

articles.title: UK labour market shows signs of stabilising after job losses
articles.trailText: Unemployment rate rises slightly to 4.8% but ONS says falls in payroll numbers and vacancies are levelling off
articles.summary: UK labour market stabilising after earlier tax-linked job losses: unemployment 4.8% in Jun–Aug (up from 4.7%), with August single-month at 5.3%, highest since Oct 2020. HMRC payrolls fell 10,000 in September; ONS says payroll and vacancy declines are levelling. Wage growth mixed: regular pay 4.7% y/y (ex bonuses), private 4.4%, public 6%; total pay 5% after upward revision, likely setting the triple-lock uplift (Aug inflation 3.8%) and adding ~£13 to full new, £7.80 to basic. Survey quality concerns persist. BoE held Bank Rate at 4% after four cuts; strong pay risks inflation, but weakening jobs could hasten cuts. Reeves faces 26 Nov budget; NIC and NLW hikes weighed on hiring.

articles.title: UK retail sales growth cools amid fears over budget tax rises
articles.trailText: Inflation also hitting sales, says industry body, as Barclays says credit card spending fell in September
articles.summary: UK retail sales cooled in September as households braced for Rachel Reeves's 26 Nov budget and inflation. BRC said total sales rose 2.3% y/y (Aug: 3.1%), below August CPI 3.8%. Food up 4.3% y/y, largely price-driven; non-food up 0.7% (12-month avg 0.9%), with mild weather damping autumn/winter apparel. Electricals got a lift from Apple launches. Barclays card spending fell 0.7% y/y (Aug: +0.5%); essential -2.6%, discretionary +0.2%. Nearly half of 2,000 surveyed are tightening finances; one-third building savings. Confidence to live within means hit 78% (4-year high) but caution persists. BCC urged Reeves to avoid business tax rises. Furniture, clothing and beauty remained resilient.

articles.title: Blair’s former policy chief Matthew Taylor to lead Fair Work Agency
articles.trailText: Author of influential report on the gig economy says new watchdog can make progress on workers’ rights
articles.summary: Labour appointed Matthew Taylor—Blair’s former No 10 policy chief and author of the gig‑economy review—to chair the Fair Work Agency, launching next April. The watchdog will consolidate labour-enforcement bodies (including the GLAA), with powers to name-and-shame underpaying firms, issue fines, and litigate for workers. Taylor, ex-head of labour market enforcement (2019–21), said Starmer’s government can “get the balance right”: flexibility without insecurity. The move anchors Labour’s employment rights bill (ban zero‑hours contracts; day‑one unfair‑dismissal rights), despite business warnings of job losses and lobbying before Reeves’s 26 Nov budget. Ministers vow to enact it “in full” amid union pressure; tribunal fees were ruled out. Experts warn the agency will need extra resources.

articles.title: Carmakers chose to cheat to sell cars rather than comply with emissions law, ‘dieselgate’ trial told
articles.trailText: Mercedes, Ford, Renault, Nissan and Peugeot/Citroën face group action in which damages could exceed £6bn
articles.summary: At London’s High Court, a three-month dieselgate group action opened against Mercedes, Ford, Renault, Nissan and Peugeot/Citroen over 2009-on diesels. For 1.6m UK owners, claimants allege illegal defeat devices hid NOx in lab tests while road emissions surged; damages could top £6bn. Lead KC Thomas de la Mare says makers chose “customer convenience” over bigger AdBlue tanks, citing 124,000 premature deaths (2009-24). A ruling will bind parallel claims against JLR, Vauxhall/Opel, VW/Porsche, BMW, FCA/Suzuki, Volvo, Hyundai-Kia, Toyota and Mazda. Carmakers deny wrongdoing, calling the case flawed. Evidence ends before Christmas; legal arguments March 2026; judgment expected summer 2026.

articles.title: Vodafone outage: thousands of broadband and mobile users report problems
articles.trailText: Company apologises and says network ‘recovering’ after many customers say there were unable to access services
articles.summary: Vodafone suffered a UK-wide outage from ~3pm Mon, peaking at 135,000 Downdetector reports by 3.20pm. ~67% of incidents hit home broadband, ~25% mobile data, 8% loss of calls; some couldn’t access the app/website. 4G/5G and broadband were affected, but 2G voice/SMS stayed up. Reports spanned major cities. Vodafone said service recovered late afternoon, ruled out a cyberattack, gave no cause. Three UK users were unaffected; BT/EE and Virgin Media O2 said networks normal. Vodafone has 18m mobile, 700k broadband; its May merger with Three formed a 27m-subscriber operator. Ofcom may pay £9.76/day after 2 days for broadband; mobile compensation varies.

articles.title: China’s Temu more than doubles EU profits to nearly $120m despite having only eight staff
articles.trailText: Online marketplace paid just $18m in corporation tax, leading campaigners to call for government action
articles.summary: Temu’s Ireland-based EU parent, Whaleco, booked 2024 pre‑tax profit near $120m (+171% y/y from $44.1m) on $1.7bn marketplace revenue (commissions/fees), while employing eight staff, and paid $18m corporation tax (incl. ~$3m global minimum top‑up). It now counts 115m EU customers; UK unit also almost doubled. EU is tightening the <€150 de‑minimis (4.6bn parcels in 2024, triple 2022; 91% from China), with customs duty due by 2028; US scrapped its $800 threshold; UK reviewing. Fair Tax Foundation says EU sales facilitated ~$10bn; UK ~$2bn. It alleges tax‑haven structuring; Temu denies avoidance, citing VAT/duties and investment.

articles.title: Markets rebound amid latest US-China tariff spat as traders look to possible ‘Taco trade’
articles.trailText: US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes rise and cryptocurrencies rebound after Trump post on Truth Social
articles.summary: Global risk assets rebounded as Trump's threat of 100% tariffs on China - tied to rare-earth export curbs - was softened by conciliatory posts hinting at a deal. S&P 500 +1.1%, Nasdaq +1.7%; Europe muted (FTSE +0.2% early, then -0.1%; CAC flat; Ibex +0.2%; DAX +0.3%). Crypto bounced: bitcoin >$115,000 (from <$105,000), ether about $4,100 (from <$3,500). Traders tout Taco trade (Trump Always Chickens Out). Haven flows lifted gold to a record $4,078.5/oz. AstraZeneca slipped 0.5% after a weekend drug-price/tariff deal. Asia lagged (Hang Seng -1.5%, Taiwan -1.4%, Shenzhen -0.9%, Shanghai -0.2%). China vowed retaliation; exports +8.3% YoY in September, beating 6%.

articles.title: Greenpeace threatens to sue crown estate for driving up cost of offshore wind
articles.trailText: Environmental group accuses king’s property management company of ‘milking for profit’ its monopoly ownership of seabed
articles.summary: Greenpeace UK threatens to sue the Crown Estate, alleging it exploits its monopoly over seabed around England, Wales and Northern Ireland by rationing sites and running “aggressive” offshore wind auctions that inflate option fees, consumer bills and royal income. It flags £1.1bn profit in FY to March (double in two years) and urges the chancellor to order an independent review before the next leasing round. The Estate rejects this, saying developer bids set fees in open auctions and net revenue returns to the Treasury; it is accelerating wind deployment. Treasury says it operates independently; 12% of profits fund the monarchy (cut from 25%).

articles.title: Lloyds warns motor finance scandal could cost it nearly £2bn as bill rises
articles.trailText: Banking group puts aside extra £800m for compensation claims amid potential for more ‘historical cases’
articles.summary: Lloyds raised its motor‑finance provision by £800m to £1.95bn (redress + ops) amid greater risk more historical discretionary commission (DCA) cases qualify after the FCA’s 360‑page redress consultation. The FCA pegs industry costs at £11bn, rising to £12.4bn if all 14m unfair deals claim; average payout ~£700. Outcome could shift with representations, litigation and Supreme Court implications. Lloyds shares +1%. FLA warns tighter, pricier lending and failures. Other set‑asides: BMW £200m; Hyundai Capital UK £34.5m; Honda Finance Europe £62.2m. Banks may bear 51% of payouts (captives 47%, independents 2%); Santander, Barclays, Close Brothers exposed. Lloyds is among most exposed.

articles.title: One of Europe’s biggest farm machinery firms halts US exports over ‘hidden’ tariffs
articles.trailText: Krone says ‘alarming’ levies on about 400 goods including hair dryers and combine harvesters have forced pause
articles.summary: German farm-machinery giant Krone has paused US exports of large equipment after new US “steel derivative” tariffs on 407 product categories forced exporters to trace and certify the origin, weight and value of every steel/aluminium part—down to bolts. Outside July’s EU-US deal and amendable multiple times a year, the rules expose shipments with imperfect paperwork to 200% duties (e.g., Russian-origin triggers), creating a top-tier compliance burden, per Flexport. Krone (10,000 staff; US sales $130m) halted shipments from 18 Aug, idled lines, and will trial a “test container” of smaller mowers/rakes/tedders instead of £600k forage harvesters. VDMA and Liebherr report similar disruption; costs likely pass to US buyers.

articles.title: ‘Lab to fab’: are promises of a graphene revolution finally coming true?
articles.trailText: Two decades after the material was first produced, some UK firms have reaped its potential but others are struggling
articles.summary: Two decades after graphene’s 2004 Manchester debut, UK outcomes are mixed. China leads production; the UK laid GEIC/Cemex graphene concrete at Northumbrian Water. Cambridge spinout 2D Photonics/CamGraPhIC tout photonic chips with higher throughput, 80% lower energy, easing datacentre cooling. Backed with £25m (Italy’s sovereign wealth fund, Bosch Ventures), it plans a Milan pilot to produce 200mm wafers, seeking €317m by year-end. Paragraf raised $55m (UAE SWF 12.8%) for EV sensors and biosensors. Graphene Innovations Manchester targets 3,000 tonnes of graphene-carbon fibre in Tabuk by 2026. But Applied Graphene Materials collapsed in 2023; Versarien is near liquidation. The lab-to-fab challenge persists.

articles.title: Five million Qantas customers have had personal information leaked on the dark web. Here’s what you need to know
articles.trailText: One expert warns frequent flyer details could be used to create fake flight rescheduling emails or fraudulent redemption offers
articles.summary: Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters dumped Qantas data for 5m+ customers after a missed ransom, alongside leaks from 40+ firms. Exposed: names, emails, frequent flyer numbers; for some, home/business addresses (incl federal MPs), DOB, phones, gender, meal preferences. No IDs, cards, passwords/PINs; FF accounts not breached. Qantas won an NSW Supreme Court injunction, but scams are rising. Officials urge hanging up on unsolicited calls, verifying via official numbers, checking emails end with qantas.com/.com.au, and enabling 2FA. Qantas offers 24/7 support; no compensation. Maurice Blackburn eyes class action. Breach traced to a June call-centre social-engineering attack abusing Salesforce access; no platform flaw.

articles.title: IFS warns Rachel Reeves against ‘half-baked dash for revenue’
articles.trailText: Thinktank says UK could raise significant funds by tackling some of the longstanding ‘inefficiency and unfairness’ in tax system
articles.summary: The IFS warns Chancellor Rachel Reeves against a “half-baked dash for revenue” to plug a £20bn–£30bn budget gap and meet fiscal rules, saying ad hoc tax rises risk harming work incentives, productivity and growth. With income tax, NI and VAT rises ruled out, it urges coherent reform: tax savings/investment income (rents, dividends, interest, self-employment, capital gains); levy employer NI on pension contributions while adding a 10% subsidy (~£6bn/yr); curb 25% tax-free pension access; and narrow the corporation tax gap (SMEs paying ~40% owed) to recoup >£10bn (vs a £24bn 2029–30 shortfall). Reeves also seeks to double a ~£10bn buffer amid high borrowing costs and revolt-blunted spending cuts.

articles.title: Energy firms complete UK’s first ‘hydrogen blending’ trial to power grid
articles.trailText: A 2% blend of low-carbon gas injected into gas grid to fuel Brigg power station in North Lincolnshire is a UK first
articles.summary: Centrica and National Gas completed the UK’s first live-grid hydrogen blending, injecting a 2% green hydrogen mix into Britain’s transmission system to fuel the Brigg power station (North Lincolnshire), which exported power. Unlike prior decommissioned-pipe tests, this real-world trial shows hydrogen (zero CO2 at point of use, made via renewable electrolysis) can cut emissions in hard-to-abate sectors using existing assets. The firms want government approval to allow up to 5% blends. National Gas, which owns the transmission network, says blending unlocks producer investment; GMB backs the move for skilled, union jobs, despite efficiency debates vs heat pumps.

articles.title: UK small businesses and charities say nuclear levy could add thousands to bills
articles.trailText: Charge from next month expected to have disproportionate impact after energy-intensive industries given exemption
articles.summary: UK charities and small firms warn a new electricity levy from November to repay investors in the Sizewell C nuclear project will add hundreds to thousands to annual bills, disproportionately hitting high‑use sites excluded from heavy‑industry exemptions. Social Investment Business says most charities will pay £100–£240 extra, some up to £2,500; Bristol’s Spike Island expects ~£1,000. Households face ~£12. Trade bodies (FSB, UKHospitality) call it a cross‑subsidy to large manufacturers, risking higher bar/restaurant prices, inflation, and slower growth, while deterring heat‑pump adoption and electrification. Government cites extended business rates relief and a clean‑energy “superpower” mission to cut bills and create jobs.

articles.title: William Hill owner says it could shut shops if Reeves raises gambling taxes
articles.trailText: Evoke considering the plans before expected tax increases in budget, with up to 1,500 jobs potentially affected
articles.summary: Debt-laden Evoke (formerly 888), owner of William Hill, is preparing to close 120–200 UK betting shops (9–15% of its 1,300 estate), risking up to 1,500 jobs, if Rachel Reeves’s 26 Nov budget raises gambling taxes. Evoke, which bought William Hill for £2bn in 2022, has £1.8bn debt and a £78m H1 pre-tax loss; it employs 10,000 (5–10 per shop). It warns higher duty would curb UK investment and push bettors to the black market. Entain issued a similar warning. The Treasury says it’s simplifying duties and bringing online betting in line, not changing rates. Advocates cite £3bn–£3.2bn extra revenue and anti-poverty gains; the sector has lobbied hard.

articles.title: UK ministers take control of £10bn Lower Thames Crossing
articles.trailText: Exclusive: National Highways Agency stripped of oversight with project handed to DfT amid Labour government drive for growth
articles.summary: Labour has removed National Highways from oversight of the £10bn Lower Thames Crossing, making it a DfT “Tier 1” scheme overseen by transport secretary Heidi Alexander, amid Treasury-led centralisation and planning reforms by Keir Starmer and Rachel Reeves to boost growth. The tunnel, east of Dartford, has planning consent and £590m for early works; Balfour Beatty holds a £1.2bn roads contract. Full funding awaits a partner to invest up to £2bn for tolling rights; ministers target a start before decade’s end. Critics warn HS2-style overspend, opaque approvals and habitat loss in north Kent/south Essex; supporters tout less M25 congestion, freight resilience. National Highways will develop and report costs; ministers decide scope and funding.

articles.title: AI tools churn out ‘workslop’ for many US employees lowering trust | Gene Marks
articles.trailText: Studies show widespread errors in AI-generated work, as employers fail to train staff properly
articles.summary: Column argues AI “workslop”—low-value AI output—stems from employers, not tools. Cites trust/impact data: KPMG (only 8.5% always trust AI search), Gartner (majority report significant mistakes), McKinsey (80% see no bottom-line impact; 42% abandoned projects), MIT (95% of pilots failed), and HBR (40% of US employees receive workslop). Root cause: poor deployment—no training on prompts, no standardized assistant, no AI policy, no accountable owner, weak vendor support, no plan or metrics. Fix: invest in people, processes, and governance; treat AI as a tool requiring oversight, not a magic button.

articles.title: Urgent calls for debt relief as study shows health and education cuts in developing world
articles.trailText: Influential economists want replenishment of funds and new ways to define countries in need before this week’s IMF and World Bank meetings
articles.summary: At IMF/World Bank meetings, economists incl. Joseph Stiglitz, Mariana Mazzucato, Jayati Ghosh urge “turn debt into hope”: replenish debt relief funds and broaden eligibility for cancellation. Citing Debt Justice, they say African governments devote 17% of revenue to debt service; capping at 10% in 21 countries could finance clean water/sanitation for ~10m and avert ~23,000 under-5 deaths yearly. Debt Justice finds in 11 IMF-program countries (e.g., Sierra Leone, Mozambique, Kenya, Pakistan) classed as “sustainable” yet in distress, real per-capita health spend fell 18% and education 10%. Signatories include Trevor Manuel and Paulo Gentiloni. IMF touts a three-pillar strategy; campaigners decry slow G20 progress.

articles.title: The IMF boss is right to say ‘buckle up’ – the global economy is facing multiple menaces
articles.trailText: Trump’s latest tariff tantrum and rising fears of an AI bubble have quickly borne out Kristalina Georgieva’s claim that ‘uncertainty is the new normal’
articles.summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva warns uncertainty is the new normal as Trump threatens 100% tariffs on Chinese goods over rare earths, jolting markets ahead of IMF/World Bank meetings. Despite resilience from front-loading, supply-chain rejigs, partner capitulation and friendshoring, UNCTAD says global trade grew $500bn in H1 2025, led by developing nations. Yet tariffs are biting poorer countries; US credibility risks mount amid unfunded tax cuts and attacks on the Fed, imperiling Treasuries. An AI investment boom masks weakness; WTO says 20% of H1 goods-trade growth was AI-related, while BoE and Georgieva warn valuations resemble dot-com, risking a sharp, global correction.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves v the OBR: chancellor aims to loosen the watchdog’s grip
articles.trailText: Labour embraced the forecaster’s powerful role, but now finds itself scrambling in the face of gloomy projections
articles.summary: Rachel Reeves seeks to loosen the OBR’s grip after its downgraded productivity assumptions wiped out fiscal headroom: projections now leave 2030 public finances £10bn–£30bn worse than in March, forcing a second tax-raising Budget on 26 November after March welfare cuts. To avoid a 2026 repeat, she aims to bank more headroom, push the OBR to “score” pro‑growth policies, and make the spring forecast indicative only (in line with IMF advice). OBR chief Richard Hughes warns this cuts transparency. Some on Labour’s left want forecasting moved to the Treasury or a CBO‑style remit; Jonathan Portes says market credibility, not the OBR, is the real constraint.

articles.title: Hackers leak Qantas data containing 5 million customer records after ransom deadline passes
articles.trailText: Hacker collective Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters demanded payment in return for preventing the stolen data of nearly 40 companies from being shared
articles.summary: Hacker collective Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters leaked data on 5m Qantas customers after a ransom deadline, part of a broader breach hitting 44 firms and up to 1bn records. Qantas data, stolen in June from a Salesforce database, includes emails, phone numbers, dates of birth and frequent-flyer numbers; no credit cards or passports. Other victims reportedly include Disney, Toyota and McDonald’s. Salesforce says its platform wasn’t compromised and won’t negotiate. Qantas secured a NSW Supreme Court injunction in July and is offering 24/7 support, identity protection and added controls. Experts warn of identity theft and targeted phishing; other stolen data (Apr 2024–Sept 2025) includes purchase histories and passport numbers.

articles.title: Eric Potts obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Industrial economist who worked to bring business to manufacturers in the north of England
articles.summary: Eric Potts, 89, industrial economist and marketing leader in UK engineering, has died. A Rolls-Royce apprentice, he rose at Weir Group, becoming marketing director at Weir Polypac in 1980 before redundancy amid industry upheaval. He secured work for Ingersoll Rand in Gateshead, then founded Middleham Marketing Services. Politically independent, he opposed mining subsidies but condemned Thatcher-era abandonment of manufacturing, widening north–south inequalities and executive pay gaps. He taught at Strathclyde, Stirling and Thames Polytechnic, and rebuked London journalists’ snobbery toward Sedgefield in a Times letter. Oldham-born RAF veteran; Newcastle social studies graduate; widower; later St Albans; survived by a daughter and three grandsons.

articles.title: The false economy of reduced public services | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Jeremy Cross says disjointed policies are trapping people in poverty and isolation, while Monica Hall considers the cost of potholes. Plus letters from Derrick Joad and Colin Burke
articles.summary: Letters back George Monbiot's claim that service cuts are a false economy. Jeremy Cross cites a Kent case: a refugee family of 10 moved ~100 miles with 24 hours' notice; the father lost work, is benefit-capped; despite DWP/Canterbury/Kent help, KCC refused bus passes, so parents could not reach KCC-funded ESOL 3 miles away and were removed - three months without English, jobs, or stability. Monica Hall says outsourcing road maintenance rewards throw-and-go pothole fixes; lowest-bid tenders and pressure to keep council tax down deter durable, long-term value. Derrick Joad blames neoliberalism, evident in the two-child cap and costly inaction. Colin Burke urges transport investment: build a road first.

articles.title: Ryanair flight landed at Manchester airport with six minutes of fuel left, flight log suggests
articles.trailText: Investigation under way after flight during Storm Amy made three landing attempts in Scotland before flying to Manchester
articles.summary: Ryanair flight FR3418 (B737-800) from Pisa to Prestwick during Storm Amy (3 Oct) aborted three landings amid ~100mph winds—twice at Prestwick, then at Edinburgh—before declaring mayday and diverting to calmer-weather Manchester. A photo of a handwritten tech log indicates 220kg fuel on landing, about 5–6 minutes’ endurance; analysis suggests departure with required reserves. The AAIB has opened a serious-incident investigation; Ryanair reported it on 3 Oct and is cooperating. Passengers (737 seats up to 189) arrived at Prestwick about 10 hours late. Pilots reviewing the log called the fuel state perilously close to disaster.

articles.title: Carmakers brace for big payouts over loans scandal after FCA consultation
articles.trailText: Financial Conduct Authority proposes manufacturers’ finance arms foot nearly half of £11bn compensation bill
articles.summary: UK regulator FCA’s consultation on the motor-finance commission scandal proposes ~£11bn redress (£8.2bn compensation, £2.8bn running costs) for 14m unfair loans (~£700 each), following an August Supreme Court ruling upholding one of three consumer complaints. Captive lenders (carmakers’ finance arms such as Ford Credit, Hyundai Capital) would cover 47% (~£5.2bn); banks 51% (Lloyds, Santander UK, Barclays); independents 2%. The bill could reach £12.4bn if all claim, below earlier £18bn forecasts. FCA calls captives relatively resilient, but responses uncertain. FLA warns market disruption. Provisions: Hyundai £34.5m, Honda Finance Europe £62.2m, BMW FS £200m. Legal challenges possible.

articles.title: First Brands: why a maker of spark plugs and wiper blades has Wall Street worried
articles.trailText: Investors fear that the collapse of the car parts company – and the size of its debt – could portend wider problems
articles.summary: Auto-parts conglomerate First Brands (Trico owner; 24 companies) filed Chapter 11 on 29 Sept in Texas, listing $10bn-$50bn liabilities vs $1bn-$10bn assets after heavy use of opaque invoice factoring via private debt 'shadow banking'. Founded by Patrick James (ex-Crowne Group), it allegedly double-pledged receivables; arranger Raistone says up to $2.3bn vanished. Jefferies, which financed receivables via its Point Bonita Capital fund, discloses $715m exposure; who holds the rest is unclear. The speed and opacity echo Greensill/Carillion and coincide with subprime auto lender Tricolor's collapse. Economists warn thin disclosure and non-mark-to-market assets in booming private credit heighten contagion risk to banks and funds, recalling LTCM and 2008.

articles.title: JP Morgan staff told they must share biometric data to access headquarters
articles.trailText: Investment bank had previously planned for such information from New York workers to be voluntary
articles.summary: JPMorgan Chase now requires staff at its new $3bn, 60‑storey Manhattan HQ to enroll biometrics—fingerprint/palm and eye scans—to pass lobby gates, reversing a previously voluntary plan, per emails sent since August. Some exemptions can still use badges; criteria unclear. The building will host about 10,000 employees later this year. Elsewhere, including London, enrollment remains voluntary, using encrypted hand templates the firm can’t access (akin to Apple Face ID). A new Work at JPMC app functions as a digital badge and services hub (guest registration, indoor maps, preordering at 19 vendors). The move follows heightened security after UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson’s nearby shooting, amid worker‑tracking debates and a five‑day office mandate.

articles.title: One of world’s biggest windfarm developers to cut quarter of workforce
articles.trailText: Ørsted plans to shrink company after Trump administration causes share price to plunge to all-time low
articles.summary: Ørsted, the Danish, 50% state-owned offshore wind giant, will cut about 2,000 jobs (25% of 8,000) by end-2027 via redundancies, attrition and divestments. 500 layoffs arrive this year, including 235 in Denmark; it employs 1,200 in the UK. CEO Rasmus Errboe will refocus on Europe and select Asian markets after US political headwinds: a Trump administration halt on a near-complete Rhode Island project crashed shares, forcing a $9bn fundraising. A court has since allowed Revolution Wind to restart. Ørsted also scrapped a major UK project amid inflation and supply-chain costs. Shares hit 99.54 DKK in Aug; now 119 DKK (-2.6% d/d, -53% y/y).

articles.title: The bills are water torture – and so is the regulatory process | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Five suppliers can raise charges but Ofwat is able to celebrate a minor moral victory. The whole process feels surreal
articles.summary: 14.7m customers of Anglian, Northumbrian, South East, Southern and Wessex face steeper bills after CMA provisional redeterminations. Ofwat had already imposed sharp April rises; firms sought much more. Southern got £638 average (vs Ofwat £620 and company £710). Anglian and Northumbrian received ~1% top-ups, driven mainly by updated market data for the cost of equity. Overall, the CMA deemed requests largely unjustified, granting only 21% of extra spending sought—£556m funded by households and businesses—leaving Ofwat a rare moral victory. Pratley decries a surreal process: CMA reruns Ofwat's four-year price control in 12 months amid a looming sector reset abolishing Ofwat. All eyes now on Thames Water's 22 Oct CMA decision or special administration (temporary nationalisation).

articles.title: Pub later-hours plan will not offset costs and wider difficulties, say landlords
articles.trailText: Sector is sceptical over government licensing proposals given ‘ever-rising costs’ and ‘reduced consumer spend’
articles.summary: UK plans to loosen pub licensing in England/Wales—easier late hours, live music, outdoor service, and quicker temporary/pavement licences—win backing from UK Hospitality, the BBPA and Greene King’s Nick Mackenzie, but landlords say it won’t offset costs or weak late-night demand. Tim Martin calls it a 'moderate plus'. Operators seek cuts to VAT on on-trade beer, employers’ NI, energy and business rates; closures average one pub a day in 2025. CGA by NIQ: pre-8pm sales up; 10pm down 5%, after 1am down 15%. Institute of Alcohol Studies: 'charter for chaos'. Treasury may shift rates from small pubs to large retailers; government says no venue will be forced to open late.

articles.title: Gen Z faces ‘job-pocalypse’ as global firms prioritise AI over new hires, report says
articles.trailText: British Standards Institution study across seven countries found quarter of bosses believe entry-level tasks could be automated to reduce costs
articles.summary: BSI surveyed 850+ leaders across the UK, US, France, Germany, Australia, China and Japan, warning Gen Z faces a “job‑pocalypse” as firms prioritise AI over junior hires. 41% say AI enables headcount cuts; 31% look to AI before hiring, rising to ~40% within five years. A quarter think most entry‑level tasks can be automated; 39% have already reduced such roles via AI for research/admin/briefing. 76% expect tangible AI benefits within 12 months. 53% think benefits outweigh disruption, yet many feel lucky to have started pre‑AI. “Automation” appears ~7x more than “upskilling/retraining” in reports. UK jobless rate is 4.7%; economists downplay AI’s role. TUC: half of UK adults fear AI job impacts.

articles.title: HSBC makes £10bn bet on Hong Kong as ‘super-connector’ for China and west
articles.trailText: Deal will mean Hang Seng Bank’s shares are taken off local stock exchange as HSBC doubles down on Asian business
articles.summary: HSBC will spend £10bn to buy the 36.5% of Hang Seng Bank it doesn’t own, taking the Hong Kong lender private and delisting it — the city’s biggest bank deal in over a decade. CEO Georges Elhedery frames the move as doubling down on Hong Kong’s “super‑connector” role with mainland China amid a broader pivot to Asia after last year’s cost cuts and east/west split. Amid criticism over China property exposure, HSBC has pushed Hang Seng to clean up bad debts. To preserve capital, HSBC will halt share buybacks for three quarters, sending London shares down 5%. With chair Mark Tucker’s recent exit, investor pushback marks an early test for Elhedery.

articles.title: Millions in England face higher water bills after regulator backs more price rises
articles.trailText: Competition watchdog agrees to requests from Anglian, Northumbrian, South East, Southern and Wessex to increase charges
articles.summary: Britain’s CMA provisionally okayed five English water firms (Anglian, Northumbrian, South East, Southern, Wessex) to collect £556m extra over five years—21% of the £2.7bn sought—adding about 3% to bills for 14.7m customers, on top of Ofwat’s earlier 24% rise. Most new-project funding was rejected, but higher investor returns were allowed amid elevated rates. Company outcomes: Anglian +1% (£599 avg), Northumbrian +1% (£495), South East +4% (£286), Southern +3% (£638), Wessex +5% (£622). Ofwat’s plan lifts average bills to £597 by 2030 on £104bn spend. Consumer Council for Water and green groups decry rising costs amid sewage pollution. Thames Water paused its appeal, may seek £4bn.

articles.title: Head of largest US bank warns of risk of American stock market crash
articles.trailText: Jamie Dimon, chair of JPMorgan Chase, said he was ‘far more worried than others’ about serious market correction
articles.summary: Jamie Dimon, chair/CEO of JPMorgan Chase, America’s largest bank, warned he is “far more worried than others” about a U.S. stock-market crash, saying the probability over the next 6–24 months is nearer 30% versus ~10% priced in. Speaking to the BBC, he cited uncertainty from geopolitics, heavy fiscal spending and global remilitarisation. Echoing broader cautions, IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva said “uncertainty is the new normal,” and the Bank of England flagged rising risk of a sudden global correction amid lofty AI valuations. Dimon added AI is real but frothy, with sizable investor losses likely even as it pays off.

articles.title: Lloyds says it is facing greater hit than expected from car loan finance scandal
articles.trailText: Banking group predicts bill will top £1.2bn it has set aside, as Close Brothers also says it expects to pay more
articles.summary: Lloyds Banking Group warned motor‑finance mis‑selling costs will exceed its £1.2bn provision, citing uncertainties in the FCA’s proposed redress scheme and saying a further, potentially material, charge is likely. The FCA now expects average payouts of ~£700 on c.14m loans, putting industry compensation at £8.2bn (potentially £9.7bn), versus earlier £9bn‑£18bn. Lloyds shares fell >3% Thursday after rallying; Close Brothers plunged ~10% and said its £165m provision will materially rise. Lloyds’ provisions cut 2024 pre‑tax profit 20% to just under £6bn; RBC once saw a £4.6bn worst‑case. Secure Trust issued a profit warning (shares −16%+), exits vehicle finance; S&U posted H1 PBT £15.6m (+22%), provisions £8m.

articles.title: ‘The debasement trade’: is this what’s driving gold, bitcoin and shares to record highs?
articles.trailText: Investors fear governments will not – or cannot – rein in borrowing so are putting their money elsewhere
articles.summary: Investors are rotating into "debasement" plays in gold, bitcoin and equities on fears governments won’t curb debts, will lean on central banks, and are cutting rates with inflation still above target. Catalysts: US debt near $37tn, a shutdown, France's budget impasse, Japan's pro-spending tilt. Gold hit $4,000/oz (+50% YTD) with record ETF inflows; bitcoin $125,000 (+20%). The dollar is down ~9-10% this year; long bonds face their worst decade as yields rise. JP Morgan cites dollar debasement; Ken Griffin sees de-dollarisation. Deutsche Bank says gold/bitcoin could be on central-bank balance sheets by 2030. Goldman forecasts gold $4,900 by end-2026. AI-driven equity Fomo endures; Paul Tudor Jones warns of a blow-off top.

articles.title: NHS could pay 25% more for medicines under plan to end row with drugmakers and Trump
articles.trailText: UK ministers preparing to raise payments to end standoff with pharma industry, cited as reason for firms axing British investments
articles.summary: UK ministers plan to lift NHS drug payments by up to 25%, likely via a 25% rise in NICE's cost-effectiveness threshold (currently GBP20k-GBP30k per QALY), after talks with the Trump administration and pharma. The DHSC backs higher medicines spend (now 9% of NHS; GBP20.6bn in 2023-24) but Treasury/No 10 resist new budget funds. ABPI wants GBP40k-GBP50k, index-linked. Industry has paused ~GBP2bn UK projects (MSD, AstraZeneca, Eli Lilly). Streeting offered GBP1bn relief over three years; firms cite GBP13.5bn repayments and seek ~GBP2.5bn/year. Trump threatened 100% import tariffs; Pfizer cut US prices up to 85% for a three-year reprieve. Lib Dems and patient groups warn of US-style pricing.

articles.title: Pubs to stay open until early hours in push for UK growth
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Plans for England and Wales would help the ailing hospitality sector but have attracted criticism from health experts
articles.summary: Labour will let pubs, clubs, restaurants and off-licences in England and Wales open later to drive growth and revive hospitality. Backed by Keir Starmer and the Treasury, the industry-led plan (co-chaired by Greene King CEO Nick Mackenzie and ex-minister Gareth Thomas) would add a fifth Licensing Act objective: promoting economic growth, and create a national licensing policy framework. Sadiq Khan has powers to overrule London boroughs. Supporters tout investment and jobs; health groups, police and councils warn of more crime, violence against women, alcohol deaths and A&E burden, while eroding local control and resident objections. Government says it is rebalancing.

articles.title: The AI valuation bubble is now getting silly | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: The broad parallels are genuinely close to the madness of the late-1990s dotcom bubble
articles.summary: Nils Pratley says today’s AI boom closely echoes the late-1990s dotcom mania (Nasdaq +86% in 1999), with signs of a late-cycle phase. Valuations are stretched: CAPE back near dotcom peaks and the S&P 500 on about 25x forward earnings, the BoE’s FPC notes. Risks are amplified by extreme concentration (Magnificent 7 now over a third of the S&P 500) and circular cross-deals: OpenAI paying Nvidia for chips while Nvidia plans a $100bn stake, plus OpenAI’s AMD buys and equity. Macro tailwinds are weaker than the 1990s (inflation, deglobalisation, fiscal strain, populism). Nvidia’s huge quarterly revenue (~£46.7bn) helps, but dependence on one stock worries. Verdict: getting silly.

articles.title: ‘Existential threat’: what do EU’s 50% steel tariffs mean for UK industry?
articles.trailText: Why UK steel sector is alarmed by prospect of punitive tariffs from its biggest customer
articles.summary: Brussels will raise EU steel tariffs to 50% (from 25%) and cut tariff‑free quotas to 18.3m tonnes (-47% vs 2024), with no UK carve‑out; EEA exempt. The UK sends 78%/1.9m tonnes of steel to the EU, threatening competitiveness. A “melted and poured” rule makes Tata’s Indian steel in Wales count as Indian. The EU cites Chinese overcapacity, high energy costs and US 50% tariffs; says measures are WTO‑compliant. UK mills seek country‑specific quotas and renewed UK safeguards. Alternatives: US imports of UK steel face 25% tariff; push for domestic procurement. Stocks: Thyssenkrupp +5.5%, SSAB +4%, ArcelorMittal +5%; carmakers warn inflation. Targets China; top suppliers: India €4bn, S Korea €3.6bn, UK €3.2bn; aim 85% capacity vs 65%.

articles.title: The car finance scandal payouts: what does ruling mean and how much compensation could you get?
articles.trailText: From how much will I get to when will I be paid? All you need to know about the FCA’s motor finance scheme
articles.summary: The UK FCA unveiled a motor finance redress scheme for loans taken 6 Apr 2007–1 Nov 2024 after “secret” commission mis-selling. It deems 14.2m agreements (44%) unfair. Average payout about £700 per agreement (+2% interest). Indicative mean/median payouts: DCA £665/£517 (c.11.4m cases); undisclosed lender exclusivity £686/£526 (3.2m); undisclosed high commission £1,108/£960 (2.9m). Some borrowers may receive multiple payouts. Consultation closes 18 Nov 2025; final rules early 2026. Complainants likely paid sooner in 2026; others later. Firms must contact complainants within 3 months, non-complainants within 6; uncontacted have 1 year to claim. FOS cases proceed separately. FCA urges avoiding CMCs; exit-fee crackdown. Lenders liable; shares rose.

articles.title: UK opens up more driving test slots to help reduce backlog
articles.trailText: Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency says learners booking tests earlier has contributed to rising demand
articles.summary: DVSA is releasing more driving-test slots to cut a severe backlog, with 668,128 learners holding future bookings at end-September 2025, up 15% from 579,138 a year earlier amid higher demand and earlier booking. In September, 168,644 tests were conducted, up 14% from 148,144 in Sept 2024; pass rate fell to a six-month low of 49.9% (50.7% in August). Ministers are incentivising examiners and nearly doubling trainers, and consulted on blocking bots that mass-book and resell slots. Average waits were 21.8 weeks; target is seven by summer 2026. Officials urge learners to book only when ready. Tests are bookable 24 weeks ahead; rolling releases continue.

articles.title: IMF chief warns ‘uncertainty is the new normal’ in global economy
articles.trailText: Kristalina Georgieva outlines mounting risks to economic stability before fund’s annual meetings next week
articles.summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva warned “uncertainty is the new normal” ahead of next week’s IMF meetings, noting the world economy’s resilience—US likely avoids recession despite Trump’s sweeping tariffs—yet rising strains: record gold above $4,000/oz, stretched US equities driven by the ‘Magnificent Seven’ and AI hype. IMF sees global growth ~3% in 2025 (down from 3.3% in 2024), with risks from a potential sharp market correction and tighter financial conditions, especially for developing countries. She urged policy fixes: US to rein in deficits (Trump‑era tax cuts add $3tn), China to boost consumption, and the EU to deepen its single market. Tariff impacts may be delayed by front‑loaded exports.

articles.title: Tour operator Intrepid drops carbon offsets and emissions targets
articles.trailText: Firm will instead invest A$2m a year in ‘climate impact fund’ supporting renewables and switching to EVs
articles.summary: Australian tour operator Intrepid is scrapping carbon offsets and stepping away from its SBTi-verified 2030 emissions targets as unachievable. Instead it will invest A$2m (£980k) annually into an audited Climate Impact Fund for EV adoption, renewable energy and other near-term measures. New science-designed, independently verified goals focus on cutting carbon intensity per trip and reducing long‑haul flying by prioritising domestic/short‑haul, flight‑free and walking/trekking tours. Executives cite governments’ failure on renewables/SAF and admit offsets lacked credibility. Greenpeace welcomed focus on flying cuts, urging a frequent‑flyer levy with the first annual flight tax‑free. Intrepid says customer flights dominate its footprint.

articles.title: Bank of England warns of growing risk that AI bubble could burst
articles.trailText: Possibility of ‘sharp market correction has increased’, says Bank’s financial policy committee
articles.summary: Bank of England’s FPC warns risk of a sudden market correction has increased, driven by stretched AI valuations and potential loss of Fed credibility. OpenAI’s valuation hit $500bn (from $157bn last October); Anthropic’s $170bn (from $60bn in March). MIT finds 95% of organizations get zero ROI from generative AI, heightening disappointment risk and revaluation of high earnings expectations. Bottlenecks in power, data, commodities, or shifts in AI infrastructure could hit firms tied to AI capex. A sharp repricing of US dollar assets is possible amid Trump attacks on Fed independence and trade wars, with spillovers to UK finance.

articles.title: Gold price tops $4,000 for first time as investors seek safe haven
articles.trailText: Precious metal having biggest rally since 1970s amid political uncertainty in US, France and Japan
articles.summary: Gold breached $4,000/oz for the first time, with spot at $4,031.54 in London after a 1.2% jump, capping its biggest rally since the 1970s. Prices are up >50% YTD after gains of 27% in 2024 and 13% in 2023, driven by a US government shutdown, political uncertainty in France and Japan, Trump’s tariffs, war in Ukraine/Middle East, and expectations of Fed cuts. Futures topped $4,000 and trade above spot, signaling strong sentiment. ETFs saw $64bn inflows YTD, including a record $17.3bn in September; central banks, notably China’s, are buying. Ray Dalio urged ~15% portfolio gold. Rally could cool if the US shutdown ends.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves given extra £3bn for budget after VAT error fixed
articles.trailText: ONS says public borrowing estimates have been out by £200m-£500m a month since January
articles.summary: ONS says an HMRC VAT receipts error overstated UK borrowing by £3bn, giving chancellor Rachel Reeves limited extra headroom for her November budget. Borrowing was mismeasured by £200m–£500m a month since January; FY ending Mar 2025 is £1bn lower, and Apr–Aug 2025 £2bn lower after VAT cash receipts were revised up £2.4bn. Borrowing Apr–Aug now £81.8bn (was £83.8bn); the current budget deficit ex-investment £60bn (was £62bn), still above the OBR’s £46.6bn forecast. Tax rises remain likely to plug a £20bn–£40bn gap amid an expected productivity downgrade. OBR’s second forecast arrives 20 Oct; revised public finances 21 Oct. Data quality concerns persist.

articles.title: Qantas among nearly 40 companies facing ransom demand from hacker group
articles.trailText: Hacker collective Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters reportedly threatening to leak stolen personal data from dozens of firms in major extortion attempt
articles.summary: Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters claims it stole customer/employee data from Salesforce databases of 39 firms—including Qantas, Toyota, Disney, McDonald’s, Adidas, Cartier, Chanel, Ikea, Air France‑KLM and Google AdSense—and demands ransom talks by 10 October or it will leak up to 1bn records. Data allegedly taken Apr 2024–Sep 2025 includes DOBs, purchase histories, passport numbers and airline frequent‑flyer IDs; samples include Qantas data from a June breach (up to 6m customers; no card or passport details). Qantas won a NSW injunction and offers 24/7 support. Salesforce says its platform wasn’t compromised and it won’t pay. Google labels the group financially motivated, voice‑phishing focused; experts warn of possible mass leak.

articles.title: Do OpenAI’s multibillion-dollar deals mean exuberance has got out of hand?
articles.trailText: Some market watchers are concerned by the circular nature of deals with chip makers Nvidia and AMD
articles.summary: OpenAI’s multibillion-dollar chip deals with Nvidia and AMD are stoking bubble fears. Critics note a circular setup: OpenAI pays Nvidia for GPUs while Nvidia takes a non-controlling stake in OpenAI—echoing dotcom-era vendor financing, says investor James Anderson. The AMD pact adds hundreds of thousands of chips to OpenAI’s datacentres and gives it an option to buy 10% of AMD. Signals include vertiginous valuations (OpenAI $500bn vs $157bn last Oct; Anthropic $60bn→$170bn), heavy losses (H1 revenue $4.3bn, operating loss $7.8bn), violent stock spikes (AMD +$80bn; Oracle +$250bn), and hyperscaler capex of $325bn. Adoption is uneven (MIT: 95% zero ROI; McKinsey: little bottom-line impact) despite ChatGPT’s 800m weekly users. Deutsche Bank flags red/amber/green lights.

articles.title: Up to 14m car loan scandal victims in line for average £700 payout, City regulator announces
articles.trailText: City regulator unveils compensation scheme for motorists who bought cars via discretionary commission deals from 2007 to 2024
articles.summary: UK's FCA plans a redress scheme for unfair motor finance deals taken Apr 2007-Nov 2024, with about 14m victims due average £700 per agreement. Focus is on discretionary commission arrangements (banned 2021) that incentivised higher interest; FCA deems 14.2m agreements (44%) unfair. Lenders face c.£8.2bn compensation plus £2.8bn admin (~£11bn total). Payouts could start early next year, with statutory interest added (avg 2.09%). Over 4m have complained; lenders will contact them first. Others will be asked to opt in within six months; uncontacted consumers get a year to claim. Prior compensation excludes claims. Despite an August supreme court ruling narrowing liability, FCA proceeds.

articles.title: DPD couriers face substantial earnings loss from cut in delivery payments
articles.trailText: Company vows to force through pay decrease in new year that will cost thousands of drivers up to £25 a day
articles.summary: DPD will impose a 65p-per-parcel rate cut from 5 Jan 2026 after deferring following walkouts by about 1,500 drivers sparked by a 29 Sep email. The reduction, plus axing a £500 Christmas bonus, equates to up to £25/day, over £6,000 a year per driver (as much as £8,000 for peak workers). Most couriers are self-employed ODFs or work under MRF fleets; both are hit, with some MRF operators’ profits potentially wiped out. Drivers cite no holiday/sick pay and rising costs. DPD posted nearly £200m pre-tax profit; its top director earned about £1.5m in 2024 (+£90k). A Leicester meeting secured only a deferment; cuts still planned.

articles.title: EU plan to match Trump steel tariffs spurs ‘existential threat’ to UK steel industry
articles.trailText: Starmer says UK in discussions with EU over Brussels plan to double import tariff to 50%, which unions warn could kill UK steel industry
articles.summary: The EU will match Trump’s steel tariffs, doubling duties to 50%, slash duty-free quotas 47% to 18.3m tonnes, and add “melt and pour” origin rules to block Chinese circumvention. Aimed at protecting EU steel and advancing US talks/a metals alliance, the plan replaces safeguards expiring in 2026 and excludes Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. UK exposure is acute: 80% of exports go to the EU; unions warn of an existential threat and diversionary imports, after a new 25% US tariff. Starmer says the UK is negotiating with Brussels and Washington; the EU may allocate a UK quota post-WTO filing. Approval by MEPs and states is required.

articles.title: Metro Bank customers see red after IT glitch empties accounts
articles.trailText: Bank apologises for payments delay that led to angry complaints about ‘negative balances and missing funds’
articles.summary: Metro Bank suffered an IT outage Tuesday that delayed inbound and outbound payments, triggered duplicate card charges, and displayed inaccurate balances, pushing some accounts unexpectedly into the red (reports up to minus £7,000). Downdetector showed spikes 8–10am, and problems persisted into the afternoon despite the bank saying the issue was fixed. Customers reported missed work and inability to buy food, travel, or pay rent, with unauthorised overdrafts and calls for compensation. Metro Bank apologised, citing a short delay, and said earlier payments and balances may take time to correct. The episode follows recent UK banking tech failures at NatWest, Santander, and Barclays.

articles.title: Ineos to cut a fifth of Hull jobs, blaming ‘dirt-cheap’ imports from China
articles.trailText: Company says more roles will be at risk unless UK government supports tariffs to protect industry
articles.summary: Ineos will cut 60 jobs (about 20%) at its Acetyls plant in Hull, citing sky-high energy costs and “dirt-cheap, carbon-heavy” Chinese imports diverted from the US by Trump-era tariffs. It urged the UK and EU to impose border levies, claiming coal-based rivals emit up to eight times more CO2. Despite a recent £30m hydrogen switch that cut site emissions 75%, Ineos warns of deindustrialisation without action. The Hull site is Europe’s largest maker of acetic acid/anhydride and ethyl acetate. Recent cuts include 400 jobs at Grangemouth and 175 in Rheinberg. Ineos may move Grenadier production to the US to avoid 15% tariffs.

articles.title: Almost a fifth of young UK adults use AI to design holiday, study finds
articles.trailText: Traditional package holiday is still the most common eventual purchase, travel industry body Abta reports
articles.summary: ABTA’s poll of 2,000 UK adults finds AI rising in trip planning: 8% use AI for inspiration (up from 4% in 2024); 18% of 25–34s do so, versus <3% of over-55s. Yet package holidays remain top choice; 25% use brochures. Nearly two in five would trust AI to book. Holiday-taking rebounded to 87%, with breaks the top discretionary spend. Among 25–34s, 90% say holidays aid mental health (80% avg) and 20% factor sustainability (10% avg). Mark Tanzer urges balancing AI with agents’ expertise. Jet2’s Steve Heapy doubts pricier green choices, attacks Spain’s €30m longer-stays pivot, and urges crackdowns on unlicensed Airbnbs.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover launches phased restart at factories after cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Carmaker says sales dropped sharply in ‘challenging quarter’ amid production stoppage
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover will phase a restart more than a month after an Aug 31 cyber-attack halted production. From Wednesday: Wolverhampton engines; Hams Hall batteries; stamping at Castle Bromwich, Halewood and Solihull; plus Solihull body/paint/logistics. Nitra, Slovakia, and Solihull RR/RR Sport lines follow; Halewood update pending. Quarter to 30 Sep: retail -17% to 85,495; wholesale -24%, driven by stoppage, Jaguar wind-down and US tariffs. By market: UK -32.3%, Europe -12.1%, North America -9%, China -22.5%, MENA -15.8%. JLR restored supplier payments and launched prepayment financing (majority on order, balance on invoice), cutting terms by up to 120 days; govt’s £1.5bn loan guarantee not yet flowing.

articles.title: Australia Post releases footage of posties being hit by cars as it urges drivers to ‘keep an eye out’
articles.trailText: More than 280 delivery workers injured in traffic collisions over past year, suffering everything from broken limbs to lacerations
articles.summary: Australia Post released dash-cam footage and data showing at least five posties injured weekly (280+ in FY2024-25) in third‑party crashes, urging motorists to “keep an eye out.” Incidents—where posties weren’t at fault—often involve drivers failing to give way at roundabouts/intersections, dangerous overtakes, corner-cutting, distraction (phones), and rising scooter/bike conflicts on footpaths. With peak Christmas deliveries looming, AusPost has hired 3,500 contractors and is accelerating a fleet safety upgrade: semi‑enclosed electric delivery vehicles with multi‑directional cameras, telematics and duress buttons, which reduce injury severity. Context: transport/postal work has high injury rates; vehicle incidents cause 42% of worker fatalities. Data covers Jul 2024–Jun 2025.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover aims to restart limited production after cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Wolverhampton expected to be first plant to resume output, with some workers understood to have returned
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover began a phased restart after a 31 Aug cyber-attack that crippled design, parts logistics, manufacturing and sales. Workers returned to the Wolverhampton engine plant, the first to resume this week. Limited output at Nitra, Slovakia (Defender) and Solihull, West Midlands (Range Rover) could follow by week’s end; Halewood may take longer. Early builds will validate rebuilt IT; high-volume output remains weeks away. The UK plans to guarantee £1.5bn in private-sector loans to JLR, Britain’s largest automotive employer, and its supply chain, but no deal is signed. JLR will expedite supplier payments amid cashflow strain; SMEs’ funding remains a concern. JLR is working with NCSC and police.

articles.title: As London stock market listings show signs of life, Reeves must add momentum | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: With tentative signs of a revival in IPOs, the chancellor should use the moment to cut the 0.5% charge on share purchases
articles.summary: London’s IPO market shows tentative revival: Shawbrook, a UK-focused lender taken private by BC Partners and Pollen Street in 2017, plans a year-end return at ~£2bn amid buoyant bank valuations (benign impairments, easing rates), despite talk of Rachel Reeves’s bank-tax rises. Recent listings/filings: Beauty Tech Group (£300m LED masks) and Princes (~£1.5bn). What’s missing are marquee, mobile issuers: Arm’s 2023 Nasdaq float hurt. Potential wins: Visma (€19bn) reportedly prefers London; Revolut considers NY–London dual listing enabling FTSE 100 entry at ~£55bn. Pratley urges Reeves to cut the 0.5% stamp duty on share purchases—beyond a mooted three-year IPO holiday—to lock in momentum.

articles.title: France is in crisis but bond markets leave other governments at risk of meltdown too
articles.trailText: Investors rattled by resignation of French PM but country is not alone in trying to grapple with political maths
articles.summary: France’s PM Sébastien Lecornu quit after under a month, highlighting Macron’s gridlock: no majority to pass tax rises/cuts as bond pressure builds. Yields are rising across economies with swollen debts and higher rates. Japan’s long yields jumped as likely PM Sanae Takaichi eyes more spending despite debt ≈250% of GDP. The UK pays £110bn a year in interest; Labour hews to fiscal rules after Truss’s shock. In the US, 10‑year yields reached 4.6% in May; Trump tax cuts add ~$2tn as the deficit runs at 6% of GDP. OECD: interest burdens at 20‑year highs; $25tn borrowed in 2024. Ageing, net zero and defence needs amplify spillovers and political risk.

articles.title: Tax authorities examine finances of key Nigel Farage ally
articles.trailText: Exclusive: HMRC conducts scoping exercise into Reform UK backer ‘Posh George’ Cottrell’s income from business and wealth
articles.summary: HMRC is conducting a scoping exercise into the tax residency and business affairs of George “Posh George” Cottrell, a Farage/Reform UK ally. Scrutiny covers a £4m west London home (90‑day residency tests), gambling-linked cashflows, and crypto activity via Tether.bet. Lawyers say he lives in Montenegro, is unaware of any probe, and has no crypto-company involvement. Records show the house is owned by a firm tied to another Reform backer, yet Cottrell uses the address. His mother gave Reform £750k. Cottrell runs Geostrategy.com and served eight months for wire fraud. HMRC says this is not a formal investigation. Article subject to a legal complaint.

articles.title: UK regulators step up crackdown on firms chasing cut of car finance payouts
articles.trailText: Some claims companies shut down, others told to stop taking on clients and misleading ads ordered to be pulled
articles.summary: UK regulators have escalated enforcement against claims management companies (CMCs) and consumer law firms chasing car-finance commission redress. The FCA, SRA, ICO and ASA cited misleading ads, inadequate disclosure of free routes, and fees up to 30%. The SRA is investigating 76 firms and has shut five; two FCA-regulated CMCs altered exit fees; two others paused client intake/advertising. Since Jan 2024 the FCA has forced 740+ CMC ads to change or be pulled. An FCA £1m campaign warns consumers. Millions may claim after an August supreme court ruling; an official scheme, with details due Tuesday, could pay up to £18bn on loans since 2007 (vs £44bn risk). Payouts begin next year.

articles.title: ‘Open-minded’ dating app Feeld’s profits jump amid influx of ‘vanilla’ users
