articles.trailText: Sales rose 26% last year at the app, whose core market is people in open relationships and kink enthusiasts
articles.summary: Feeld, the 'open-minded' dating app serving ethical non-monogamy and kink communities, founded in 2014 by Dimo Trifonov and now led by CEO Ana Kirova, grew 2024 sales 26% to £48.9m, lifting pre-tax profit to £9.3m (from £6m) despite higher marketing spend. Growth was driven by expansion outside the UK and an influx of 'vanilla' users and monogamous singles as traditional apps lose traction; slower than 2023, when revenue doubled. The company paid a £600,000 dividend, mostly to the founders (>50% owners). Rebranded from 3nder after Tinder legal threats, Feeld faces integration challenges following 2023 security vulnerabilities and initially glitchy tech upgrades.

articles.title: Aston Martin warns on profits amid US tariffs and seeks ‘proactive support’
articles.trailText: Carmaker blames weaker demand on Trump policies amid supply chain pressures after Jaguar Land Rover cyber-attack
articles.summary: Aston Martin issued a second 2025 profit warning, saying losses will exceed the prior £110m low-end forecast, blaming US tariffs and supply-chain disruption after Jaguar Land Rover's cyber-attack, and urging UK ministers for more proactive support. It criticized the Trump-Starmer deal's 100,000-car 10% tariff quota (effective 30 June) as complex versus April's 25% levy, hurting demand and forecasting. Q3 deliveries fell to 1,430 (vs 1,641), shares -7% after -11% intraday. Valhalla $1m hypercar deliveries cut to ~150 in Q4 amid delays. It will trim 2025-29 capex below ~£2bn and drop H2 positive free cash flow. Govt defended the 10% rate. SMMT: Sept UK registrations +13.7%; BEVs 23.3%.

articles.title: He-Man poised to be next retro name to join UK toy ‘newstalgia’ trend
articles.trailText: Films of old favourites help lift toy sales 8% this year, with 2026 Masters of the Universe movie tipped for similar
articles.summary: UK toy sales are up 8% YTD after a 4% drop in 2024, reaching £1.8bn Jan–Jul versus £1.7bn, with more than £100m extra spend, per Circana. Licensed toys rose 14% and now account for about 35% of the market. Newstalgia is driving demand: films like Minecraft and Lilo & Stitch plus retro IPs Care Bears and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Kidults fuel premium Lego and collectibles; anime and manga are rising, with Lego launching One Piece sets. Next big bet: a 2026 Masters of the Universe live action film from Travis Knight, with licensing push at Brand Licensing Europe by Mattel and Amazon MGM, aiming to reignite He-Man across toys and merchandise.

articles.title: Nearly a third of bosses report increase in cyber-attacks on their supply chains
articles.trailText: CIPS survey shows cyber threats have risen up the list of concerns for procurement managers
articles.summary: Cyber-attacks on supply chains surged, with 29% of procurement managers reporting incidents in recent months, per a September CIPS survey of members across 150 countries (64,000 organisations). Cyber risk now rivals geopolitics and tariffs as top board-level concerns, after hacks at Marks & Spencer and the Co‑op cost tens of millions. Jaguar Land Rover shut factories for a month across the UK, Slovakia, India and Brazil, costing ~£120m in profit (~£1.7bn revenue), while Asahi halted operations at 30 Japanese plants. CIPS CEO Ben Farrell warned of hyper‑interconnected supply chains, urging investment in stronger digital defenses and supplier scrutiny.

articles.title: Solo trips abroad take off among women who seek break from work – and their families
articles.trailText: UK travel firms say solo – but not single – travellers make up a growing proportion of customers
articles.summary: Women’s solo overseas travel is surging at UK operators, driven by 45–60-year-olds seeking time away from work and families. Group ‘soft adventure’ tours dominate. Jules Verne says solo travellers are 46% of 2025 departures (40% in 2023); ~70% of its solo bookings are by women. Intrepid reports 62% of solo bookings are women; Explore Worldwide and Intrepid saw 20%+ UK solo growth over two years. Two-thirds of an average Explore group now travel solo. Top picks: Morocco, India, Peru, plus European walking/cycling. Peak months: Sept–Oct. Costs remain higher, though child-free travellers dodge school-holiday premiums. Independent agents report double-digit solo growth. Abta convenes in Magaluf.

articles.title: Boomerang hires are highly valuable. Don’t insult them by paying them less | Gene Marks
articles.trailText: A boomerang hire comes with much less risk because you know what you’re getting. And you’re proposing to low-ball?
articles.summary: Gene Marks argues employers should stop lowballing boomerang hires. Quartz says former employers are offering returning creatives (writers, designers, PR, marketing) and some public-sector staff sharply reduced pay. Excuses cite AI and budget cuts, yet NYT reports 80% of companies using genAI see no bottom-line gains; 42% abandoned pilots by end-2024. MIT finds ~95% of pilots lack P&L impact. Boomerangs cut risk, onboard faster, boost morale, and import knowledge. Under state retaliation laws, testing the waters comments can be smoking guns. With a tight labor market, pay fairly - don’t insult proven talent.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves’s second budget needs a narrative of fairness to justify tax rises | Heather Stewart
articles.trailText: The chancellor should reach for the language of solidarity and social justice that this government tends to recoil from
articles.summary: Rachel Reeves's 26 Nov budget needs a fairness narrative to justify £20bn-£30bn tax rises driven by the OBR's weaker productivity reassessment, and to avoid a repeat of the winter fuel cut backlash. Heather Stewart argues Labour must explain who pays and why, shifting from ad-hoc hikes to reform that narrows the tax bias against employees. IFS's Helen Miller urges a vision; ideas from CenTax/Resolution/Demos include NICs on rental income (~£3bn), equalising CGT with income tax with an investment allowance (~£11bn), extra council tax on >£2m homes, and employer-style NICs on partners. Demos polling showed net +10 support for slashing loopholes, while basic-rate/NICs rises are toxic. Last year's unjoined £8bn from the wealthy lacked framing. Reeves has eight weeks to sell solidarity and contribution.

articles.title: Foreign staff have ‘changed our lives’: Scottish farmers fear for future after changes to skilled worker visas
articles.trailText: Locals say staff from the Philippines and elsewhere have made life better, and plan to take their case to a government body
articles.summary: At Dourie Farm above Port William, Dumfries and Galloway, the Christie brothers now rely on six foreign hires—four Filipinos and a Hungarian—to milk 1,200 Holstein‑Jersey crosses producing ~30,000 litres/day for Lactalis’s Stranraer creamery. After Brexit/pandemic drained local labour, they used Skilled Worker visas despite costs (~£10,000 per hire plus setup) and >£40,000 salaries with housing. July rule changes removed farmer/agricultural contractor from the visa list and raised the bar to RQF6 (degree‑level), effectively closing the route though only hundreds used it annually. Surveys show 84% get few/zero qualified UK applicants; CAS Recruitment placed staff at 36 Scottish farms. Farmers will petition the MAC in December, warning of risks to milk supply, food security and local jobs.

articles.title: ‘Delivery robots will happen’: Skype co-founder on his fast-growing venture Starship
articles.trailText: Ahti Heinla on bringing his tech to small towns, its effects on jobs – and whether he’s still interested in money
articles.summary: Ahti Heinla, Skype co‑founder and Starship CEO, says sidewalk robots already deliver cheaper than humans and can profitably serve small towns. Starship has made 8m deliveries with ~200 staff, operates in UK cities, Finland and Estonia, and partners with Co‑op, Bolt and Grubhub. Originating from a 2014 NASA rover project, it ran unsupervised robots in Estonia (2017) and launched commercially in Milton Keynes (2018). Funding totals €200m+ (Plural-led). Units cost <€10k; per‑delivery costs are lower; deliveries generate cash though it’s not yet profitable. UK rollout is slowed by council approvals; Finland’s national law enables 1m/year. Rivals include Serve, Nuro, Noon, Tesla/Baidu AVs, and Manna/Amazon/Wing drones. Heinla says robots augment labor and aid local retailers; mass rollout is inevitable.

articles.title: ‘This is real progress’: airlines on sustainable aviation fuels and the chances of net zero flying
articles.trailText: The EU and UK have imposed mandates, and investors see its value – but the industry has mixed views
articles.summary: EU and UK SAF mandates start (2% now; EU 6% by 2030, UK 10%), with 70% of aviation’s net-zero pathway hinging on SAF. Supply/cost doubts split airlines: Ryanair’s Michael O’Leary dismisses SAF; Iata’s Willie Walsh doubts even 5% by 2030. UK proposes a revenue-certainty scheme and £63m for 17 projects, yet only Phillips 66 makes SAF at scale; Shell halted a major Rotterdam plant. US incentives are pared back, clouding output. Near-term mandates lean on HEFA; 2G and e-SAF are risky, scarce, and costly, implying fare pass-through. IAG stays committed; Ryanair backs Catagen modular tech; Heathrow used 17% of global SAF in 2024. Activists contest lifecycle gains and feedstock competition; geopolitics may divert UCO to Europe and keep Asian supplies home.

articles.title: UK electric car sales hit record high as taxpayer subsidies help attract buyers
articles.trailText: EVs rise nearly a third in September compared with a year earlier, as plug-in hybrids jump by 56%
articles.summary: UK battery-electric car sales hit a record 72,800 in September, up nearly a third YoY, after July’s reintroduced grants, SMMT says. Plug-in hybrids jumped 56% to 38,300; electrified vehicles topped half of the market as total registrations rose 14% to 312,900 (strongest September since 2020, still below pre-Covid). Grants up to £3,750 apply to sub-£37,000 models, including Citroën, Renault, Nissan and Vauxhall, and exclude most Chinese brands via manufacturing-emissions rules; coverage is ~25% of BEVs. YTD BEV share is 22.1% vs a 28% ZEV mandate headline, eased by April “flexibilities.” New Automotive pegs the real target <22% and warns the 400,000-buyer grant may close early.

articles.title: London stock market boost as beauty group lists and tinned fish brand confirms IPO plan
articles.trailText: Beauty Tech Group picks London for £300m offering while Princes Group, with £2.1bn turnover, also plans possible £1.5bn listing
articles.summary: London’s IPO pipeline brightened as The Beauty Tech Group, owner of CurrentBody, ZIIP, Tria Laser, chose a £300m LSE float, while Liverpool-based Princes Group (tinned fish, Napolina, Crisp ’N Dry; £2.1bn sales) confirmed plans to list at c£1.5bn, raising ~£400m for expansion under owner NewPrinces (bought from Mitsubishi for £700m). Shawbrook is poised to launch, Fermi REIT opted for rare London–US dual listing, and Revolut weighs a dual float (~$75bn). This activity follows three‑decade‑low London IPO proceeds; the Treasury may exempt newly listed shares from the 0.5% stamp duty. Offsetting: AstraZeneca to list on NYSE; Ashtead, Flutter, CRH exited.

articles.title: US ‘flying blind’ at critical moment for economy, experts warn, with no jobs data amid shutdown
articles.trailText: Data was collected for closely-watched jobs report before shutdown, but Trump officials so far defy calls to publish it
articles.summary: Federal shutdown halted release of September jobs report and next week’s inflation data, even though BLS collected and processed them. Ex-commissioners Erica Groshen and William Beach say the report is likely in final draft; Groshen warns the Fed, Treasury, markets and households are flying blind at a potential recession’s onset. The Trump administration has not published the data; Trump fired the BLS chief in August, alleging faked stats. ADP estimates firms shed 32,000 September jobs and revised August to -3,000, versus Wall Street’s +45,000 forecast. Sen. Elizabeth Warren urged release for Fed rate decisions. BLS staff are furloughed; Trump’s nominee EJ Antoni withdrew.

articles.title: Banking industry’s net zero alliance shuts down amid faltering climate commitments
articles.trailText: NZBA had nearly 150 members but banks began leaving when Trump was re-elected on promise to ‘drill, baby, drill’
articles.summary: The UN-convened, bank-led Net Zero Banking Alliance will cease operations immediately after remaining members voted to drop the member model and leave its guidance as a public framework. The group peaked near 150 banks but suffered exits after Donald Trump's re-election and 'drill, baby, drill' agenda; JPMorgan, Citigroup, Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, Wells Fargo and Goldman Sachs quit first to pre-empt anti-woke attacks, followed by European and Japanese lenders. HSBC (after delaying key goals by 20 years) and then Barclays left in the UK. ShareAction called the shutdown 'bitterly disappointing'; Reclaim Finance said alliances were window dressing and urged regulators to end financing of fossil expansion. NZBA documents remain available; no interviews.

articles.title: Wetherspoons boss vows to keep price rises to a minimum as he criticises energy bills
articles.trailText: Beefed-up packaging tax will triple pub chain’s costs from the levy to £2.4m a year, says Tim Martin
articles.summary: Wetherspoons chair Tim Martin vowed to limit price rises, blaming new cost pressures: the extended producer responsibility packaging levy will triple its tax bill from £0.8m to £2.4m as suppliers pass charges on; non-commodity energy levies will add £7m a year, lifting these to 62% of electricity costs, including the nuclear RAB scheme. He said such levies will fuel inflation. The 794-pub group faces £60m extra annually from higher NICs and minimum wage. FY to 27 Jul: like-for-like sales +5.1% to £2.1bn; pre-tax profit +10.1% to £81.4m. Early FY trading slowed (LFL +3.7% in nine weeks); shares fell >5%. Analysts cite energy +57.8% and wages +34.5% vs pre-pandemic.

articles.title: SA Ambulance received no alerts from service meant to notify authorities during Optus triple zero outage last month
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Despite being signed up to a new alert system, the South Australian emergency service was not notified during September’s triple zero outage
articles.summary: SA Ambulance says it enrolled for Optus real-time 000 outage alerts but got none during September's triple-zero failure, caused by a firewall upgrade that blocked Optus emergency calls in SA, WA, NT and parts of NSW, and linked to three deaths (two SA, one WA; an SA infant likely unrelated). Premier Peter Malinauskas said agencies noticed 000 call drops and alerted Optus, defying protocol. A post-2022 review mandates real-time alerts by 1 Nov; Optus alerts have operated since June for enrolled ESOs. NT had not enrolled. Optus is silent pending a Kerry Schott review. Legislation to create a triple-zero custodian is coming; a TIO report sat for months. Optus earlier called alerts a huge staff burden and fought, then lost, to keep a Deloitte breach report secret.

articles.title: Government shutdown could cost US economy billions of dollars a week, analysts say
articles.trailText: According to one report, each week of shutdown could cost up to $7bn, with another suggesting a $15bn loss in GDP
articles.summary: Analysts and the Trump administration warn the ongoing federal shutdown is inflicting multi‑billion‑dollar weekly damage. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said GDP and jobs will suffer. EY-Parthenon estimates each week cuts Q4 annualized GDP growth by 0.1 ppt, a $7bn hit, via furloughed worker pay loss, delayed procurement, and weaker demand. A White House CEA memo pegs losses at $15bn per week; a monthlong closure could add 43,000 unemployed and trim $30bn in consumer spending, while disrupting Social Security, air travel and WIC. Delayed economic data would hamper the Fed and markets. The 35‑day 2018–19 shutdown cost at least $11bn, including $3bn permanent.

articles.title: ‘A paroxysm of disposability’: France’s distaste for Shein’s ultra-fast fashion
articles.trailText: A petition to ban the brand has passed 270,000 names but French shoppers have not been immune to its inexorable rise
articles.summary: Despite graffiti protests and pop‑ups backlash, Shein plans its first permanent French stores via SGM inside Galeries Lafayette in five cities and Paris’s BHV; Galeries Lafayette says this breaches its franchise and values. A ban petition tops 270,000 signatures. The China‑founded giant made about $1bn net profit last year, adds ~7,200 items daily, and launched 1.5m products in the US in 2022–23. France’s senate advanced eco‑taxes, ad/influencer curbs, supply‑chain disclosure, and diverting revenues to sustainable makers, targeting “ultra‑fast fashion” over Zara/H&M. Cultural resistance meets size‑inclusive, low‑price appeal; spokesman Christophe Castaner decries a “tax on the poorest.” Shein denies labor‑abuse claims; critics say overproduction endures.

articles.title: There are no good options at Thames Water. But temporary renationalisation is cleaner
articles.trailText: Creditors may well succeed in their plea for lower standards, but at this point customers deserve to see some proper detail
articles.summary: Thames Water’s creditors propose a “market-led” recap: accept lower environmental standards for up to a decade, write off £4bn (~25%) of debt, and inject £3.15bn equity, targeting 13–14% IRR on the new stake. They tout a 30% pollution cut by 2030—below the government’s 50% goal—even with the Tideway super-sewer live. Details on other targets, fines leniency and governance are murky (only chair Mike McTighe named). Government/Treasury, wary of special administration, are entertaining talks with Ofwat despite past claims leniency isn’t allowed. The columnist argues temporary renationalisation could force deeper debt write-downs and a cleaner, transparent reset.

articles.title: Up to 600 flights a day to be cancelled during French strike, Ryanair says
articles.trailText: Airline claims next week’s air traffic control strikes could affect up to 100,000 passengers as routes over France close
articles.summary: Ryanair warns French air traffic control strikes by SNCTA on 7–10 Oct could force up to 600 cancellations a day, disrupting up to 100,000 passengers, chiefly on UK–France routes and overflights to Spain, Italy and Greece, as capacity is cut across western European airspace. O’Leary renews demands that the EU protect overflights and urges Ursula von der Leyen to act, suggesting Eurocontrol manage them during strikes. Already, 30 Ryanair flights were axed Thursday and 190 delayed on 18 Sept (35,000 pax). Other airlines haven’t quantified impacts; staffing gaps, glitches and war-related airspace closures worsen delays.

articles.title: Thames Water creditors ask for up to 15 years’ leniency from river pollution rules
articles.trailText: Lenders say a ‘full return to legal, regulatory and environmental compliance’ under new rescue plan would not be completed until at least 2035-2040
articles.summary: Thames Water’s creditor-led rescue (London & Valley Water) seeks regulatory leniency, saying full legal/environmental compliance won’t be achieved until 2035–40, implying prolonged illegal sewage discharges. Lenders propose paying fines, scrapping a demand to waive arrears, writing off ~£4bn debt (25%; juniors lose entire £1bn), and injecting £3.15bn equity (+£150m). No dividends under Ofwat oversight and no sale before 31 Mar 2030. Creditors urge lighter penalties and warn of c.£9.5bn extra post-2030 bill-funded costs. Plan aims to avert special administration; Ofwat had signalled a 30% write-off. Mike McTighe slated as chair.

articles.title: Tesco predicts price war before Christmas amid ‘pressure on household budgets’
articles.trailText: Retailer raises full-year profit expectations by £100m after luring shoppers with price cuts over summer
articles.summary: Tesco lifted full-year profit guidance to up to £3.1bn (from £3.0bn) after cutting prices on 6,500 items by an average 9%, gaining share as its inflation lagged the 4.9% grocery rate (Worldpanel). CEO Ken Murphy expects a fiercer pre-Christmas price war, citing squeezed household budgets and Asda’s “war chest.” H1 to 23 Aug: group sales +5.1% to £33bn; UK LfL +4.9%, helped by BBQ weather and home-eating trade-downs; Clubcard users 24m. Pre-tax profit fell 6.3% to £1.3bn on restructuring, bank separation and price investment. Efficiency gains and AI for demand/staffing (and replenishment prompts) offset NI (+£235m) and packaging levy (£90m). Shares +4.8%. Murphy urged relief on planned higher business rates.

articles.title: UK considers stamp duty exemption for newly listed company shares
articles.trailText: As Rachel Reeves’s budget looms, Treasury weighs up proposals to make British markets more attractive
articles.summary: UK Treasury is weighing a 2–3-year stamp duty holiday on trades in newly listed London shares in Rachel Reeves’s November budget, exempting the 0.5% levy to boost IPOs. Investors currently pay the duty (AIM already exempt); the US, China and Germany have no equivalent, Ireland’s is 1%. Stamp duty on shares raised £3.3bn in 2023 (~0.3% of tax receipts), making full abolition unlikely amid tight finances despite City pressure. The move could aid planned London listings (Beauty Tech, Princes, Fermi America; Shawbrook IPO expected). Backers say it would attract capital and support valuations; Treasury cites wider market reforms and PISCES relief.

articles.title: Europe’s air safety at risk amid cost-cutting and staff pressures, study warns
articles.trailText: Researchers find profit chasing has ‘systematically weakened’ safety and workers feel unable to challenge decisions
articles.summary: Ghent University’s survey of 6,900 European pilots and cabin crew warns profit‑driven cost cutting and post‑Covid staffing shifts have “systemically weakened” safety. Over half feel unable to challenge unsafe orders (vs 82% able in 2014); ~30% of pilots fear career harm for safety calls. Fatigue persists: 42% say scheduling trumps safety; nearly one‑third of pilots and almost half of cabin crew hesitate to declare unfit. Cabin crew face pressure to sell onboard goods, creating role conflict. Mental health is poor (68% below threshold; 78% feel dehumanised). Atypical contracts—41% of under‑21s; 52% in eastern Europe—are common. Authors and pilot unions warn low‑cost “race to the bottom” without regulatory and contractual reforms.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover parts makers asked by banks to put up homes as loan security after hack
articles.trailText: Lobby group says urgent government intervention required as small suppliers on brink of collapse during shutdown
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover’s August-end cyber-attack has halted output for over a month, stranding small UK parts makers without cash. Banks are offering emergency loans at around 16% and demanding personal guarantees secured on family homes, suppliers say. Lobby group CBM warns of irreversible supply-chain damage and layoffs, urging direct aid to lower-tier firms, since JLR’s planned advance payments to tier-one suppliers may take up to 60 days to trickle down. Government promised a £1.5bn loan guarantee for JLR (plus £2bn bank debt without state support), but no direct supplier relief. Example: Genex UK has laid off staff. JLR eyes limited restarts, has set up a supplier helpdesk.

articles.title: The government has raised false hopes at Jaguar Land Rover. There has been no ‘decisive action’ | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: If the government is in the intervention game, it should be intervening where need is most urgent – among JLR’s suppliers
articles.summary: Nils Pratley says Peter Kyle’s “decisive action” claim over an 80% UK Export Finance guarantee on JLR’s £1.5bn five-year bank loan is spin: JLR’s liquidity (~£5bn), £2.5bn FY profits and Tata backing mean access to cash wasn’t the problem. The real crunch is suppliers’ cashflow after August’s cyber-attack; relief hinges on how quickly JLR advances payments and money cascades down tiers. He urges direct SME support—British Business Bank loans, HMRC payroll-tax deferrals, and bank forbearance—potentially tied to higher UK battery content. Either let JLR handle it or aid suppliers; the guarantee raised false hopes and looks like conference window-dressing.

articles.title: The RBA seems unlikely to do another rate cut – meaning they’re betting the economy is better than the data says | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: Michele Bullock doesn’t think our current cash rate is ‘very restrictive’. Do the figures back her up?
articles.summary: Greg Jericho argues the RBA under governor Michele Bullock is signalling no further cuts, implying confidence the economy can wear a 3.6% cash rate she says isn’t “very restrictive.” While core inflation (trimmed mean) is within the 2–3% target, activity is weak: August jobs growth slowed to 1.5% y/y (full-time 1.3%), GDP is 1.8% vs 3.1% long-run (2010s 2.6%). Historically ~2.75% GDP is needed to hold unemployment steady, yet the RBA forecasts ≤2.1% through 2027. With no “easing bias” and Cup Day odds of 3.35% fading, Jericho says the bank is betting the economy is stronger than the data.

articles.title: Greggs to put up price of breakfast deals and other items after weak summer sales
articles.trailText: Bakery chain hit by sales growth slowdown as July heatwave led to shoppers shunning hot pastries
articles.summary: Greggs will lift prices from Thursday after weak summer trading: three-part breakfast deal +20p to £4.15; two-part +20p to £3.15; croissant and chocolate star biscuit to £1.40; corned beef bake to £2.20. Q3 like-for-like sales rose 1.5%, slowing from 2.6% in H1 as July heat cut hot pastry demand. CEO Roisin Currie cites inflation; last rise was May. Third Bridge flags higher NI and new employment rules, pushing tiered price rises but risking demand. Earlier, sausage rolls went to £1.30 amid ~4% average hikes; two-thirds of staff got 6.1% pay. Shares +7% early but -40% YTD. Estate: 2,675 shops (2,096 company, 579 franchised); 57 net openings YTD; ~120 expected in 2025 vs up to 150 prior.

articles.title: Selfridges blames slump in tourists shopping for luxury goods as sales fall
articles.trailText: Losses narrow to nearly £16m for 48 weeks to 4 January 2025 but group has not made pre-tax profit since 2019
articles.summary: Selfridges reported a 7% sales drop to £775m in the 48 weeks to 4 Jan 2025 (vs £835m over 53 weeks prior), blaming the UK’s end of tax-free shopping for tourists, luxury price rises, inflation and higher energy costs weakening demand. Losses narrowed to nearly £16m from ~£42m, yet it hasn’t made a pre-tax profit since 2019. The group runs four UK stores (Oxford Street, two in Manchester, Birmingham) plus online. In Oct 2024, Saudi Arabia’s PIF agreed to buy a 40% stake from Signa; Central Group remains in control post-Signa insolvency. Pre-Christmas plans feature Disney-themed windows and hampers priced £85–£600.

articles.title: Airline industry workers: share your experiences
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from pilots, cabin crew, schedulers - anyone who works in the industry - about your experiences
articles.summary: Low-cost airlines have opened affordable travel to millions, but this Guardian callout probes the impact on aviation staff. It invites pilots, cabin crew, schedulers, and other airline workers to share firsthand experiences of job pressures, specifically: adherence to flight time regulations, unrealistic rosters, and reliance on commanders’ discretion to keep services running. The goal is to better understand how current scheduling and operational practices affect those who “keep the show on the road.” Submissions are via an online form; terms of service and privacy policy apply. Responses will help inform coverage of working conditions and regulation across commercial aviation.

articles.title: Marks & Spencer to make staff work Boxing Day for first time in five years
articles.trailText: All workers must cover at least one of 26, 27 or 28 December in cost-cutting move condemned as a ‘slap in the face’
articles.summary: Marks & Spencer is scrapping its five-year Boxing Day automatic holiday, mandating all staff work at least one of 26, 27 or 28 December and be available for all three beforehand. Around a quarter of store staff will work on 26 Dec; big stores remain shut, but the day counts against annual leave with limited bookable slots to cut costs and complexity. The policy, introduced in March before an April cyberattack, follows 2023 shortfalls when 40% of permanent and 30% of seasonal staff skipped a peak day, hindering restocking. Internal posts call it a ‘slap in the face.’ Ops chief Jayne Wall says more staff are needed to reset for 27 Dec.

articles.title: UK house prices return to growth amid ‘broad stability’ in market
articles.trailText: Nationwide says prices rose by 0.5% in September after August drop, lifting average price of property to £271,995
articles.summary: UK house prices rose 0.5% m/m in September after August's 0.1% dip, lifting the average to £271,995; annual growth edged to 2.2%, Nationwide says. Mortgage approvals hover around 65,000/month, near pre-pandemic. Nationwide expects borrowing costs to ease if Bank Rate, held at 4% amid 3.8% inflation, is cut. Budget uncertainty lingers: Rachel Reeves's 26 Nov budget and a floated tax on sales over £500k. Taylor Wimpey’s net private sales rate fell to 0.65 per outlet per week. Market seen as soft landing; sellers discount. Q3: London +0.6% QoQ (£527,694); outer SE +0.3% (£337,201); England annual +1.6%; NI +9.6%; Wales +3%; Scotland +2.9%.

articles.title: Buy now, pay later use exploding among older Britons, data shows
articles.trailText: Almost a third of British adults lived largely cashless lives in 2024, says UK Finance
articles.summary: UK Finance’s 2024 payments report shows BNPL spreading beyond youth: overall users rose from 14% to 25% of UK adults; among 55–64s, usage more than doubled (10%→21%). Average BNPL ticket is £114; fashion takes 46% of spend; Klarna, Clearpay and PayPal dominate a £13bn market. The FCA plans tighter rules, including affordability checks on small loans. Digital wallets surged to 57% of adults (from 42%); mobile banking is now the main account access. Cash fell below 10% of payments; 30% use cash monthly or less; almost a third live largely cashless. Link warns against “sleepwalking” into digital-only.

articles.title: UK business confidence falls to record low amid rising employment costs
articles.trailText: Survey of bosses shows energy prices also a concern, as Bank policymakers warn inflation may take longer to drop
articles.summary: UK business confidence hit a record low in September, the Institute of Directors said, as cost expectations rose to new highs, led by surging employment costs; energy prices also weighed. IoD’s Anna Leach urged Chancellor Rachel Reeves to deliver a growth-focused November budget underpinned by fiscal credibility. At the Bank of England, Clare Lombardelli and Catherine Mann warned inflation may prove persistent—exacerbated by food prices—into 2026; both opposed August’s rate cut, unlike the MPC majority expecting inflation to fall to 2% next year from a likely 4% September peak. Reeves touted five rate cuts this year, but sticky inflation could curb further easing and her fiscal headroom. MPC’s Sarah Breeden struck a more dovish note, seeing a temporary “hump.”

articles.title: Rachel Reeves gets a warm reception but business chiefs are wary of another tax raid
articles.trailText: Questions grow over how chancellor will raise cash in the autumn budget to meet her fiscal rules
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves signalled further tax rises in November to meet fiscal rules after 2024’s £40bn hike. Pressures include a £3.5bn lift to the two‑child cap and £7bn/year welfare reversals. Manifesto pledges not to raise VAT, income tax or employee NICs stand, though Darren Jones left wiggle room. Likely levers: higher gambling duties and inheritance/CGT tweaks. If OBR gap is ~£20bn: pro‑growth moves such as NICs on landlords’ rents; if >£30bn: property taxes, pensions relief, even pledges at risk. CBI chief Rain Newton‑Smith warned the tax burden is at highs, attacked the £25bn employer NICs rise, and urged planning follow‑through on big projects.

articles.title: Future of Ovo Energy in doubt after failing financial stress tests
articles.trailText: Firm, founded by green energy entrepreneur Stephen Fitzpatrick, says there is “uncertainty” around plan to improve capital position
articles.summary: Ovo Energy warned its ability to continue as a going concern is in doubt after failing Ofgem's new financial resilience "capital adequacy" tests, with uncertainty over an agreed plan to bolster its capital. The supplier serves c.4m UK homes and is one of three firms missing the standards introduced post-energy-crisis; Octopus also missed the target despite earlier claiming compliance, while a third, smaller supplier is unnamed. Accounts filed at Companies House flagged the risk. Founder Stephen Fitzpatrick is reportedly seeking up to £300m via a share sale and exploring a merger of Ovo's supply arm with Scottish Power; both companies declined comment.

articles.title: Optus’s triple-zero outage could boost Telstra’s customers – and allow it to charge even more
articles.trailText: No longer competing on price, Telstra is benefitting from consumer inertia, a strong regional network and Optus outages, consumer advocates say
articles.summary: Optus’s September triple-zero outage—its third major failure after a 2023 network collapse and 2022 data breach, and linked to three deaths—has sparked churn that could lift Telstra’s customers and let it charge more. Telstra’s SIM-only 50GB plan is $70/month (>20% since 2022) versus Optus’s $55 (+12%); Vodafone similar. Despite cheaper 50GB plans from MVNOs (~$29) and Telstra-owned Belong ($35/40GB), Telstra benefits from consumer inertia and stronger regional coverage. It added 560k net postpaid handheld users in FY2024 and holds 41.6% wireless share (Optus 24.7%, TPG/Vodafone 14.1%). Telstra, which has periodically lifted prices citing investment, and TPG are seen as outage winners.

articles.title: Tata bought slabs from rival British Steel as it sought to beat Trump tariff plans
articles.trailText: Sale of product from Scunthorpe plant came when Indian-owned firm tried to avoid US rules that were later dropped
articles.summary: Tata Steel bought steel slabs from rival British Steel’s Scunthorpe works, home to the UK’s last ore-based blast furnaces, in recent months to navigate proposed US 'melted and poured in UK' rules tied to a Trump-backed 0% tariff. The rules were later dropped as talks collapsed; UK exports now face a 25% tariff (vs 50% for others) without origin restrictions. British Steel is under UK government control; Whitehall injected £180m and pushed output amid Jingye exit fears. Tata shut Port Talbot blast furnaces in 2024 for EAFs and is rerolling imported slab. Jingye seeks up to £1bn to exit, seen unlikely.

articles.title: Almost a third of Prax Lindsey oil refinery workers to lose jobs
articles.trailText: Insolvency Service says 125 roles to go at Lincolnshire plant, which went into administration in summer
articles.summary: UK Insolvency Service will cut 125 jobs at Prax Lindsey oil refinery, North Killingholme, leaving 255 staff, after its summer collapse into administration. Redundancy support is offered; director conduct remains under investigation. A court froze £150m of assets tied to owner Winston Soosaipillai (aka Sanjeev Kumar), who is being sued by administrators and is missing. Energy minister Michael Shanks says most jobs remain and seeks a long-term solution. Unite says at least two credible bids exist and blasts premature redundancies. The official receiver named Teneo administrator and FTI to run the site; bids will be independently assessed. A buyer search failed in July.

articles.title: The RBA dithers on its next interest rate cut – but it’s not the political flashpoint it once was
articles.trailText: Despite signs of rising prices, economists believe the Reserve Bank’s choice is still when, not whether, to cut rates further
articles.summary: The RBA kept the cash rate at 3.6% and offered no firm guidance. Governor Michele Bullock said rates could stay on hold or be cut, aiming to return inflation to the 2–3% band. Monthly CPI hit 3% y/y in August (volatile); the board warned inflation may be more persistent as private demand recovers faster than expected. With three earlier cuts still filtering through, market odds of a November cut fell to ~35% from ~55% (NAB); some economists now see cuts slipping to 2026. Politics has cooled: Chalmers voiced disappointment; the Coalition blamed spending. Cuts are increasingly viewed as fuelling housing unaffordability.

articles.title: Royal Mail owner to rebrand thousands of Collect+ stores as it buys stake
articles.trailText: International Distribution Services to create Royal Mail Shops for collecting, sending and returning parcels
articles.summary: Royal Mail parent IDS, acquired by Daniel Křetínský’s EP Group for £3.6bn in April, bought 49% of Collect+ for £43.9m and will rebrand thousands of convenience-store sites as Royal Mail Shop. The move adds 8,000+ high-street pickup points, open evenings/weekends, offering in-person Tracked 24/48 postage, collections and returns; 500 stores live, wider rollout pending. Sites still handle prepaid parcels for other carriers; Vinted is first partner for collections. It expands Royal Mail’s 24,000 out-of-home points (2,000 lockers, 11,500 Post Office branches, 1,200 customer service points) as IDS pivots from letters (Saturday 2nd-class scrapped from 28 Jul) after delivery target misses.

articles.title: Optus boss ‘has a lot of work to do’, Anika Wells says after meeting telco in wake of triple-zero outages
articles.trailText: Minister asks parent company to appoint external reviewer in attempt to restore Australians’ faith in emergency calls
articles.summary: After meeting Singtel CEO Yuen Kuan Moon, Optus chair John Arthur and CEO Stephen Rue, communications minister Anika Wells called Optus’s triple‑zero outages “completely unacceptable”, urged Singtel to appoint an external reviewer, and said Rue “has a lot of work to do.” A 18 Sept firewall upgrade blocked emergency calls in SA, WA, NT and parts of NSW; three deaths linked. A 29 Sept Illawarra tower fault hit nine calls. Optus’s board hired Kearney for oversight/QA, reporting to Rue and the board. ACMA is investigating; penalties may follow. Albanese blasted Optus; opposition/Greens push wider inquiry/licence review. Government will fast‑track a triple‑zero custodian.

articles.title: Retailers say tax rises could further fuel inflation as shop prices jump
articles.trailText: BRC says households are finding shopping increasingly expensive after annual shop price inflation rises to 1.4%
articles.summary: UK shop price inflation accelerated to 1.4% in September (0.9% August), BRC/NIQ report, as home‑improvement and gardening prices rose while food costs stabilised. Non‑food deflation is fading (prices -0.1% YoY vs -0.8% in August), with falling back‑to‑school laptop prices tempering DIY. Food inflation held at 4.2%; retailers see easing late this year or from early 2026. BRC’s Helen Dickinson said energy, wage and employers’ NICs rises—and an October packaging tax—are lifting input costs; further tax hikes could keep prices higher. NIQ’s Mike Watkins said weak confidence will force promotions. The BoE paused rate cuts amid headline inflation risks. Retailers face £7bn extra costs in 2025. Chancellor Rachel Reeves signals possible tax rises/spending cuts to plug up to £30bn.

articles.title: Jim Chalmers’ budget victory lap outpaces reality as Australia’s debt continues to climb
articles.trailText: The treasurer celebrated an outcome that could have been worse, but a structural challenge remains as workers are left with the burden of repair
articles.summary: Australia posted a $10bn deficit in 2024-25, far better than the $27.9bn pre-election forecast due to stronger company and wage tax receipts. Chalmers and Gallagher claimed a win, yet debt and interest costs are still climbing; interest is the fastest-growing major outlay, rising about 9.5% a year over the decade. The deficit is 0.4% of GDP and debt about 50% (incl. states), outperforming peers (US deficit 6.4%, G20 debt >100%). CBA's Luke Yeaman warns a structural gap: spending growth is funded by bracket creep; PBO projects average worker tax rates rising 25% to 27% and income tax's revenue share 48% to 53% by mid-2030s, forcing choices on taxes vs services.

articles.title: Emma Walmsley steadied GSK – but doubts linger over growth targets
articles.trailText: The outgoing chief executive reshaped the drugmaker, yet scepticism persists over promised revenues
articles.summary: Emma Walmsley exits GSK after eight years having demerged consumer health as Haleon (2023), doubled pharma/vaccine R&D, cut dividends and debt to free investment/licensing. Elliott’s 2021 revolt failed, but the share price sits near where she started (~£15.25). Shingrix uptake was hit by Covid; US Zantac litigation created turbulence. Strategy hinges on £40bn+ 2031 revenue target, assuming most of 15 potential blockbusters land; the City models ~£35bn, citing an HIV patent cliff, leaving a ~£5bn credibility gap. Pipeline priorities include vaccines, oncology and respiratory; investors await durable growth and margin expansion. COO Luke Miels is the expected successor; sustained delivery will determine her legacy.

articles.title: AstraZeneca’s listing rejig spells long-term danger for London | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: It’s not skipping off entirely to New York, but pharma giant sets a worrying precedent for UK stock market
articles.summary: AstraZeneca will upgrade its NYSE listing to equal footing with London and Stockholm, retaining UK HQ and FTSE 100 slot, billed as easing access for US funds barred from ADRs. Nils Pratley warns this sets a template for FTSE multinationals (Shell, BP, Unilever, Diageo, Relx) to add US listings, pulling trading to New York and sidestepping the UK’s 0.5% stamp duty—AZN says UK buyers won’t pay as trades settle under the US system. He urges Rachel Reeves to scrap stamp duty, replace revenue, and rebuild equity demand, not fixate on private assets. US firm Fermi listing in London aside, gravity favors the US.

articles.title: GSK’s Emma Walmsley to step down as chief executive after eight years
articles.trailText: Chief commercial officer Luke Miels to take over as CEO at Britain’s second-biggest drugmaker
articles.summary: GSK said CEO Dame Emma Walmsley will step down after eight years, exiting the board end-2025 and serving notice until 30 Sep 2026. CCO Luke Miels becomes CEO Jan 1. Walmsley led the 2022 consumer spin-off (Haleon), refocused on specialty medicines and vaccines, and lifted R&D spend to £6.4bn. She faced Elliott in 2021 and rejected Unilever’s £50bn bid. Pay: £10.6m last year, up to £21.6m potential. Miels’ package up to £16.6m. GSK targets 15 blockbusters by 2031 and >£40bn sales (vs £31bn), but shares lag on HIV patent risks. BoA expects sentiment to improve amid US tariff threats and UK pricing disputes.

articles.title: ‘I wanted it all’: Claire’s shoppers on what the store has meant to them
articles.trailText: Sparkly memories of the accessories stores, 156 of which will be rescued from administration in the UK and Ireland
articles.summary: Modella Capital, owner of Hobbycraft, will rescue 156 Claire’s stores in the UK and Ireland, safeguarding about 1,000 jobs, after the chain fell into administration in August amid falling sales and fierce competition. Roughly 145 stores weren’t acquired, leaving around 1,000 roles at risk, with further closures likely. The news triggered nostalgia: fans praise Claire’s as a glittery tween rite-of-passage for in-person browsing, accessories and ear-piercing; an ex-employee recalls a supportive, women-led workplace; others remember emo/goth phases sparked by studded belts and band wallets. Critics cite chaotic, overcrowded shops and a shrinking “tween” market as kids shift to Sephora-style spending.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover cyber-attack: what’s the latest news?
articles.trailText: How is the government helping the carmaker? Will jobs be protected? And when will production restart?
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover’s UK, Slovakia, India and Brazil plants have been idle nearly a month after a cyber-attack forced IT shutdowns. Core systems to pay suppliers and ship vehicles/parts are back, but full production may be weeks–months away; suppliers face 6–7 weeks with no revenue. Estimated impact: c.£1.7bn lost sales and £120m profit hit for a month; Creditsights sees up to £2.6bn 30‑day cash burn. Government guaranteed £1.5bn UKEF-backed loans; JLR also secured £2bn from Citi, MUFG and Standard Chartered (total £3.5bn). Limited restarts start with Wolverhampton engines. Tiered supply chains and jobs remain at risk; temps already laid off.

articles.title: AstraZeneca to upgrade US listing in ‘knock-back for London’
articles.trailText: UK’s biggest drugmaker will put its US shares on a par with its London-based stock but says HQ will stay in Cambridge
articles.summary: AstraZeneca will directly list on the NYSE, replacing its Nasdaq ADRs, putting US shares on par with its LSE stock. The £170bn FTSE 100 group says HQ and primary listing stay in Cambridge/London, but the move—subject to a shareholder vote—broadens access to US investors, including pension funds. The US, already 43% ($23.2bn) of revenue, is expected to hit ~50% by decade-end. Analysts call it a knock-back for London and a possible step toward a future shift. Scrutiny has grown after AZ paused a £200m Cambridge expansion and scrapped a £450m Liverpool revamp amid UK drug-pricing rows. Govt welcomed clarity; LSE faces ongoing departures.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover to restart some manufacturing after cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Wolverhampton engine factory is likely to be the first to resume work following month-long closure
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover, owned by Tata, will begin a controlled, phased restart in the coming days after an Aug 31 cyber-attack shut factories and retail for nearly a month. Wolverhampton’s engine plant is expected to be first back online. To bolster liquidity during recovery, JLR obtained a £1.5bn UK Export Finance-backed loan guarantee (via private banks) and a separate £2bn facility from Standard Chartered, Citigroup and MUFG. Analysts see low default risk after almost two years of strong profits. Suppliers welcome a partial restart but say the guarantee won’t push cash to a fragile supply chain, where layoffs have begun. JLR employs 33,000, anchoring West Midlands auto output.

articles.title: Half of Claire’s stores in UK and Ireland bought in rescue deal but jobs still at risk
articles.trailText: Modella Capital warns of ‘inevitable’ closures and job losses at accessories chain while administrators run remaining stores Business live – latest updates
articles.summary: Modella Capital, owner of Hobbycraft and buyer of WH Smith’s high-street arm (renamed TG Jones), has acquired 156 Claire’s stores in the UK and Ireland from administrators Interpath, safeguarding about 1,000 jobs and securing a local brand licence from Ames Watson. The firm warned “inevitable” closures and redundancies as landlord talks determine which sites survive. Another 145 stores and c.1,000 jobs remain with administrators after the US parent’s August collapse; Claire’s UK entered administration amid online/TikTok competition. Interpath will keep trading remaining sites while options are explored. The US and Canada filed for bankruptcy for the second time in seven years.

articles.title: Bullion bonanza: why is gold hitting record highs?
articles.trailText: Interest rates, inflation and geopolitical crises are providing the metal with its strongest annual performance since 1979
articles.summary: Gold is on track for its strongest year since 1979, up 45% YTD to a record $3,831/oz, fueled by haven demand amid slowdown fears, Russia-Nato tensions, and Trump-era risks (Fed independence, tariffs, fiscal plans). Dollar weakness (>9% in 2025), falling rate expectations, and record inflows ($17.6bn over four weeks; $5.6bn last week, per BofA) are boosting prices. WGC says western investors lead; central banks—especially China—keep buying as de-dollarization builds. Supply rises ~1.7%/yr; scarcity underpins value. BofA calls gold tactically overbought but underowned (0.4% AUM). Deutsche Bank sees $4,000 in 2026. ETFs, physical, or miners offer exposure; pullback risk remains.

articles.title: Anika Wells to meet Singtel’s boss as Optus experiences second triple-zero outage in less than two weeks
articles.trailText: Optus says it confirmed the welfare of all callers who called triple zero after an issue affected Illawarra region in NSW
articles.summary: Australia's government is resisting calls for a sweeping independent inquiry into triple-zero after Optus's second outage in under two weeks. Communications minister Anika Wells will meet Singtel CEO Yuen Kuan Moon Tuesday about the 18 Sep firewall upgrade failure that blocked emergency calls across SA, WA, NT and parts of NSW; three deaths have been linked. A new outage Sunday in NSW's Illawarra (3am-12:20pm) affected nine 000 calls; Optus says all callers' welfare confirmed. ACMA is investigating; Optus hired Kerry Schott to report by year-end. Coalition and Greens want a system-wide probe and Optus licence review. Singtel called Sunday's tower fault routine.

articles.title: Optus triple-zero outage: NSW police check welfare as 000 emergency service calls fail in Illawarra region
articles.trailText: Telco says nine 000 emergency services calls failed during outage in Dapto region and apologises to customers
articles.summary: Optus is probing a new 000 outage in NSW’s Illawarra after a Dapto tower fault blocked calls 3am–12.20pm Sunday. Nine 000 calls failed; one ambulance‑seeker reached services via another phone. Four numbers sent to NSW Police for welfare checks; all callers confirmed, no emergency response required. Optus apologized and said it offers opt‑in outage alerts ahead of mandatory notifications from November. The incident follows a firewall‑update outage two weeks earlier affecting 600+ households in SA/WA/NT, with three callers dying (baby’s death likely unrelated). Finance minister Katy Gallagher called it disappointing; Anika Wells to meet Optus; opposition demands inquiry, alerts.

articles.title: Isle of Wight festival increases profits despite fall in attendance
articles.trailText: Festival made £3.4m profit in 2024, generating £2.6m dividend for its parent company, part of Live Nation
articles.summary: Isle of Wight festival grew profit to £3.4m in 2024 despite attendance falling 4.5% to just under 144,000. A £2.6m dividend was paid to immediate parent UK Festival Holdings (up from £1.9m), within Live Nation’s UK network. LN-Gaiety Holdings reported nearly £34m dividend income over the past two years and paid nearly £49m to Irish holding LNGH Ireland in 2023. 2024 headliners were Pet Shop Boys and The Prodigy; 2023 profit was £2.8m (Pulp, Chemical Brothers). 2026 headliners: The Cure, Lewis Capaldi, Calvin Harris. Live Nation’s 2017 acquisition was CMA-cleared; it faces US antitrust/touting suits and UK Ticketmaster ad changes.

articles.title: Alternative data suggest uneven inflation amid Trump’s numbers skepticism
articles.trailText: With BLS figures under scrutiny, indices from Truflation, Zillow, Adobe and ISM show a more nuanced picture of prices
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s skepticism of BLS inflation data coincides with reports of staffing-driven cutbacks in price collection. A PIIE study deems CPI methodology robust but urges updates: fresher weights, alternative data, and subgroup indexes. Alternative gauges show mixed signals: BLS annualized 2.9%; Truflation 2% (down from 3% YTD start); Zillow rent 2.44%; Adobe online prices -3% YoY; Bloomberg Commodity Index +3.6% YTD. Yet ISM prices for manufacturing and services are up >15% YTD, and NFIB’s net price raisers at 21% (above 13% average). Author infers near-term inflation uptick, citing tariffs. Piece argues alternative datasets offer a more impartial read than federal figures.

articles.title: Why Trump is backing Argentina’s Thatcherite economics | Heather Stewart
articles.trailText: While Javier Milei’s shock therapy to tame inflation has won support from Washington and the IMF, ordinary Argentinians seem less impressed
articles.summary: Donald Trump endorsed Javier Milei and signaled US help as a currency crunch loomed. Scott Bessent said Washington could offer a $20bn Fed swap line or buy Argentina’s bonds. Milei’s Thatcher-style shock therapy—union curbs, deep cuts, privatizations—reduced pensions and public pay; 48,000 public jobs lost. IMF praised reforms, approving a $20bn program. Yet recession, falling real wages, import liberalization hurting industry, rising debt, wider gender gap, and hidden gig joblessness persist. Milei ditched full dollarization, then devalued the peso >50%. After a poor Buenos Aires vote and corruption claims vs sister Karina, the peso slid; the central bank burned >$1bn. US backing also counters China; volatility ahead of October midterms.

articles.title: Pfizer sued in US over contraceptive that women say caused brain tumours
articles.trailText: US class action lawsuit alleges company failed to warn about risks of using contraceptive injection Depo-Provera
articles.summary: Pfizer faces US multidistrict litigation in Pensacola, Florida, alleging Depo‑Provera (medroxyprogesterone acetate) caused intracranial meningiomas and that the company failed to warn of risks after >1 year of use. Filed cases have tripled since May to 1,300+ and could reach 5,000–10,000, with several billion dollars at stake. Monday’s hearing tests federal pre‑emption in five pilot cases: Pfizer says FDA blocked a tumor warning; plaintiffs say its request was overbroad and hid Depo‑Provera’s higher risk. A March 2024 BMJ study tied prolonged progestogen use to meningioma; Depo‑Provera showed a 5.6x risk. Labels were updated in 2024 in the US, Canada and Europe. Usage: 247m hormonal users globally; ~25% US women tried Depo‑Provera; 15% in the UK. Berger Montague is probing board fiduciary duties.

articles.title: UK government will underwrite £1.5bn loan guarantee to Jaguar Land Rover after cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Britain’s largest automotive employer plans to restart engine manufacturing in early October, report says
articles.summary: UK will underwrite a £1.5bn loan to Jaguar Land Rover via its export development guarantee, repayable over five years, after an Aug 31 cyber-attack halted UK production until at least 1 Oct. A Sunday Times report says JLR plans to restart its £500m Wolverhampton Engine Manufacturing Centre on 6 Oct, subject to tests. JLR is working with NCSC and police and has restored some IT to pay suppliers, ship parts and deliver finished cars. Ministers say the move safeguards SME-heavy supply chains and 34,000 UK jobs in the West Midlands/Merseyside; opposition demands faster support, cyber‑reinsurance, possible furlough, and tougher cybersecurity.

articles.title: Profiteers or keeping the lights on? The power plants that make millions a day
articles.trailText: Concerns over whether gas generators are making fair profits are prompting fresh proposals to reform the system
articles.summary: Rye House gas plant in Hertfordshire—Britain’s longest‑serving CCGT (1993), owned by Vitol’s VPI—drew ire for scarcity prices: £6,000/MWh in winter 2022 and over £6m for a few January hours. NESO’s balancing market permits such bids when supply is tight. Operators say high per‑MWh prices cover costs for plants running 5–10% and providing inertia. The 2012 capacity market pays for availability via 1‑ and 4‑year auctions, yet profits still hinge on rare runs. RWE’s Tom Glover likens gas to a “fire brigade,” favoring beefed‑up capacity payments. A Greenpeace‑commissioned report by ex‑official Adam Bell urges a strategic reserve for gas, claiming £5bn/yr savings; critics fear weaker signals for batteries and demand response. UK targets 5% gas by 2030.

articles.title: FCA faces battle over £1m ad campaign rejecting car loan claims firms
articles.trailText: City watchdog aims to tell drivers they will not need to use companies to apply for share of £18bn compensation scheme
articles.summary: The FCA will spend £1m on online/radio ads telling motorists they can claim free under its proposed £18bn motor-finance redress, without CMCs/law firms that take up to 30%. The scheme follows an August supreme court ruling on dealer–lender commission. FCA says typical payouts may be ≤£950 per complaint and has hired influencers (e.g., Cameron “Cazza” Smith). CMCs and firms (Courmacs Legal, Slater & Gordon, Bott & Co) accuse FCA of aiding banks and pushing “low-ball” offers; legal action mulled. FCA cites misleading CMC marketing; only ~50% know they can self-claim. Provisions: Lloyds £1.2bn; Santander £295m; Close Brothers £165m; FirstRand/MotoNovo £122m; BMW FS £200m.

articles.title: Harrods warns customers their data may have been stolen in IT breach
articles.trailText: Luxury department store says passwords and payment details were not affected in the ‘isolated incident’
articles.summary: Harrods warned some e-commerce customers that personal data may have been taken after a third-party provider’s system was compromised. Exposed information is limited to basic identifiers (names and contact details); account passwords and payment details were not affected. The provider says the “isolated” incident is contained; Harrods’ own systems were not breached. Harrods is working with the vendor and has notified authorities. The retailer said it is unrelated to a May attempted intrusion that prompted restricted internet access. In July, four people were arrested over cyberattacks on M&S, the Co-op and Harrods; they’re on bail. M&S’s April attack shut its online store nearly seven weeks.

articles.title: Kitchen sink drama: Trump’s latest tariffs leave experts scratching heads
articles.trailText: President places new duties on cabinets, vanities and sofas but national-security justification prompts puzzlement
articles.summary: President Donald Trump announced new Section 232 tariffs: 50% on imported kitchen cabinets and bathroom vanities and 30% on upholstered furniture, effective next month, citing national security and “flooding” by foreign firms. Experts, including Cornell’s Eswar Prasad, question any security nexus and warn the executive end-run around Congress is wearing thin. The White House says a forthcoming Section 232 report will justify the move. Industry reaction is muted; the National Kitchen & Bath Association is “reviewing implications” while keeping global manufacturing ties. The administration already faces an IEEPA tariff lawsuit; critics say these actions inject uncertainty that will ultimately hurt US consumers and businesses.

articles.title: Bank of England should not be ‘overly cautious’ on interest rate cuts, says policymaker
articles.trailText: Rate-setter Swati Dhingra denies high inflation is a ‘particularly British problem’ and says short-term factors are to blame
articles.summary: Swati Dhingra, an external MPC member, urged the Bank of England not to be overly cautious on further rate cuts, arguing the UK inflation spike is driven by fading, short-term factors rather than a uniquely British problem. She cited regulated utility and transport prices and consumption patterns—such as chocolate’s larger UK basket weight amid cocoa shocks—plus olive oil and beef; just 10 items account for three-quarters of the UK–eurozone food inflation gap. The MPC held Bank Rate at 4% this month; Dhingra voted for a 25bp cut. Rates have been cut five times since last summer. Inflation was 3.8% in August. She downplayed wage-growth pressures, noting UK and eurozone earnings have converged since 2024. Her stance contrasts with Megan Greene’s caution. Next decision: 6 November.

articles.title: Trump’s latest tariff threat raises concerns for UK pharmaceuticals
articles.trailText: Britain will ‘actively engage’ with US over possible 100% duties, with truck and cabinet makers also in firing line
articles.summary: Donald Trump will impose from 1 October new US import tariffs—100% on branded drugs, 25% on heavy-duty trucks, and 50% on kitchen and bathroom cabinets—reviving UK pharma fears. The sector was excluded from Keir Starmer’s earlier US tariff deal (covering cars, steel, aerospace), and Trump’s May pledge of preferential treatment has not materialised. UK officials say they’re actively engaging Washington. Analysts expect drug duties to target firms lacking US manufacturing; Novo Nordisk, Novartis, Roche and AstraZeneca have US plants underway. The EU’s 15% blanket tariff covers drugs; medical devices face a Section 232 probe. Truck tariffs hit EU makers; Daimler Trucks and Traton fell. Mexico is most exposed, supplying 78% of US heavy-truck imports; USMCA exemptions are unclear.

articles.title: VW to pause production at two plants as electric vehicle sales stall
articles.trailText: German factories to halt work for one week next month in blow to EV switchover
articles.summary: Volkswagen will halt EV production for one week in mid-October at Dresden and at Zwickau (Saxony) (its EV plant building six VW, Audi, Cupra models), and cut one workday a week at Osnabrück; closure days are weighed at Emden (ID.4/ID.7). Weekend shifts will be added in Wolfsburg. The move follows slowing EU EV demand (EVs 16% of sales vs hybrids 37%), infrastructure and range anxieties, and competition from Chinese brands (BYD +~250% YTD). Stellantis has similar pauses. CEO Oliver Blume cites a clear drop in BEV demand; tariffs have hurt the ID.4. VW says Zwickau makes nearly half its EVs.

articles.title: UK retailers accused of ripping off motorists as fuel margins ‘remain far above historic levels’
articles.trailText: Watchdog ‘deeply concerned’ that firms have ramped up petrol and diesel prices at expense of consumers
articles.summary: The UK CMA says retailers are overcharging motorists, with fuel margins still far above historic levels despite only part of recent pump price rises being due to higher oil; Brent near two-month highs. From late May–Aug, petrol rose 1.9p to 133.9p/litre; diesel +3.5p to 141.9p. Supermarket margins climbed to 8–9.1% in Q2; other retailers 9.9–10.6%, versus 2017’s 4% and 6.4% (H1 2025 averages: 8.4% and 9.8%). Monitoring excludes operating costs; a full review is due year-end. AA and RAC decry weak competition and “postcode lottery.” Government’s year-end fuel finder will force daily price reporting. CMA says motorists overpaid £1.6bn in 2023.

articles.title: Treasury ‘putting the squeeze’ on OBR over Labour growth plans amid tensions over downgrade
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves may have to find up to £30bn in tax rises or spending cuts if forecaster revisits expectations
articles.summary: Treasury officials, alarmed the OBR will cut long‑run productivity by ~0.2pp, are pressing it to credit Labour’s growth plans (planning reform; India/EU trade deals). The downgrade adds ~£20bn to an existing ~£10bn gap (welfare U‑turns, higher borrowing), leaving Rachel Reeves seeking up to £30bn in tax rises or cuts for 26 Nov. In March the OBR credited planning with a 0.2% GDP lift by 2029‑30; economists doubt more. Ministers may make only the autumn forecast bind fiscal rules; OBR chief Richard Hughes resists. Charlie Bean blames Reeves’s slim £10bn headroom; economists call the OBR an outlier. Treasury denies tensions.

articles.title: £500m Thames Water desalination plant has provided just seven days’ water over 15 years
articles.trailText: Plant in Beckton has run only five times and has been beset by multiple problems since it was built
articles.summary: London’s £270m Thames Gateway desalination plant has cost ~£518m since 2010 (≈£200m interest, £45m idle upkeep, £3m ops) yet ran only five times, producing 7.2bn litres—about seven days of London’s demand—at 7p/litre (28x normal). Mothballed amid chemical leaks and safety failures; currently offline pending reservoir safety works, maintenance and DWI approval. Upgrades aim for 50Ml/d this investment cycle and 75Ml/d in droughts by 2031. Thames Water proposes the £359m–£535m TDRA, funded by customers: abstract at Teddington, backfill with treated Mogden effluent. Critics cite river impacts; TW pledges no untreated sewage. Leaks were 570.4m l/day in 2023–24. Defra backs recycling/reservoirs amid a 5bn l/day 2055 shortfall.

articles.title: George Soros foundation hits back at Trump after report that DoJ plans to target group
articles.trailText: New York Times reports justice department is pushing attorneys to investigate as Trump ramps up attack on rivals
articles.summary: Open Society Foundations (OSF) blasted “politically motivated attacks” after a New York Times report that the Justice Department told prosecutors to map cases against the Soros‑funded charity. A memo from a lawyer in Deputy AG Todd Blanche’s office allegedly floated charges—RICO, arson, wire fraud, and material support for terrorism—to offices in California, New York, Washington DC, Chicago, and Detroit. Trump has vowed to target Soros and leftwing groups, citing RICO. OSF said its work is lawful and protected speech. Separately, Trump ousted a Virginia U.S. attorney, installed aide Lindsey Halligan, and prosecutors are reportedly nearing charges against James Comey.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover restarts some IT systems as suppliers call for urgent support
articles.trailText: Carmaker can make payments and send spare parts but some suppliers say they face permanent closure
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover has restarted limited IT after a crippling cyber-attack, restoring supplier payments (clearing invoice backlogs), parts logistics for repairs, and wholesale systems to ship finished cars to retailers. Assembly remains halted at plants in the UK, Slovakia, India and Brazil since the start of the month. Suppliers, facing cashflow freezes, warn of permanent closures and seek urgent government aid. A proposal for the state to buy parts was rejected; alternatives include a furlough scheme through 31 Dec and HMRC tax deferrals. JLR reportedly lacks cyber insurance (The Insurer). Layoffs are mounting (e.g., Linamar 40). Ministers in near-daily contact.

articles.title: Starbucks to cut 900 jobs and close dozens of North American stores as sales struggle
articles.trailText: Restructuring comes after six quarters of falling sales and growing pressure from unions over working conditions
articles.summary: Starbucks will cut ~900 non-retail jobs and close about 100 North American cafes (~1% of company-operated units) in a $1bn restructuring after six consecutive U.S. sales declines. Citing inflation-squeezed consumers, employees will be notified Friday. It earlier axed 1,100 corporate roles and will close many open/vacant posts. About 90% of charges hit North America: $150m in severance, $850m tied to closures. CEO Brian Niccol aims to refocus investment and uplift 1,000+ stores in next 12 months. He didn't mention unions. Talks faltered after Niccol became CEO in Sep 2024; Workers United (650 stores) decried cuts, threatening strikes. Shares fell ~1%.

articles.title: BP predicts higher oil and gas demand, suggesting world will not hit 2050 net zero target
articles.trailText: Conflict in Ukraine and Middle East as well as trade tariffs are making states focus on energy security
articles.summary: BP’s 2025 outlook raises fossil demand, implying 2050 net zero unlikely. Oil use now seen at 83m b/d in 2050 (prev 77), gas at 4,806 bcm (prev 4,729). Peak oil 103m b/d in 2030, five years later; today ~100m. Net-zero path would need ~85m by 2035 and ~35m by 2050. Geopolitics (Ukraine, Middle East) and tariffs shift focus to energy security, domestic supply, and potential “electrostates.” Oil still ~30% of primary energy in 2035; renewables rise 10% (2023) to 15%, overtaking oil late 2040s. Emissions exceed 2C budget by early 2040s. BP pivots under CEO Auchincloss, Elliott pressure. Wind/solar meet >80% of added power demand by 2035—half in China.

articles.title: United Utilities underspent £52m on vital work to reduce sewage pollution, FoI reveals
articles.trailText: Privatised water company criticised over efforts to connect private septic tanks to mains and cut pollution
articles.summary: Ofwat, via FOI, said United Utilities spent £76.7m of £129m allocated since 2000 in NW England to connect non‑mains systems, leaving £52m unspent. Campaign group Save Windermere says only one Windermere scheme in two decades connected 27 properties and urges a proactive drive to sign up septic‑tank owners under Water Industry Act s101A. Sewage from UU assets is the principal phosphorus source in England’s largest lake; UU estimates 30% of loading comes from non‑mains drainage. Bathing water was poor across most of summer. Mapping flags south‑basin shorelines (>5 miles) reliant on non‑mains. UU cites demand, viability and willingness‑to‑pay; it’s canvassing three areas.

articles.title: Farage steps up calls for Bank of England to halt bond sales
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader presses governor Andrew Bailey over quantitative easing in meeting at Threadneedle Street
articles.summary: Reform UK’s Nigel Farage, after a Threadneedle Street meeting with BoE governor Andrew Bailey alongside MP Richard Tice, urged the Bank to halt quantitative tightening bond sales and cut interest paid on QE reserves. Tice argued ministerial “steer” could curb budget tax rises and sought an urgent Commons debate. Shadow chancellor Mel Stride warned politicising rates imperils BoE independence and inflation control. Bailey earlier said ending reserve remuneration is a de facto bank tax for elected governments. The MPC plans c.£21bn gilt sales, £49bn maturing, slowing QT. Critics cite Treasury losses and higher gilt yields. IPPR backs a bank windfall tax; QT costs £22bn/yr.

articles.title: Co-op says ‘malicious’ cyber-attack has hit profits by £80m
articles.trailText: Retailer says it needs to focus on weaknesses in food business that led to gaps on shelves in its stores
articles.summary: Co-op fell into the red after an April cyberattack forced IT shutdowns, causing product gaps and paper-based funeral operations. It estimates £206m lost revenue and an £80m hit to H1 operating profit, guiding to a £120m full-year profit impact (net of limited insurance). H1 revenue fell 2.1% to £5.5bn and pre-tax swung from £58m profit to a £50m loss. Data for all 6.5m members (names, addresses, contact details) was stolen; no payment data. Attackers used social engineering to impersonate a colleague. Co-op is addressing food business weaknesses and still plans 30 new stores, including On the Go expansion.

articles.title: First new Qantas Airbus jets come with one toilet for every 90 economy passengers – worse than Jetstar, Scoot and Ryanair
articles.trailText: Full service carrier says it will add additional toilets to its first three new Airbus 321XLR models – but they will be in service for three years beforehand
articles.summary: Qantas has begun flying its first three Airbus A321XLRs on Sydney–Melbourne and Sydney–Perth with a tight economy toilet ratio: two toilets for 180 economy seats (1:90) plus one for 20 business (three total). That’s worse than budget rivals: Ryanair 737 (3 for 197; 1:66), Scoot A320 (3 for 180; 1:60), Jetstar A320 (3 for 186; 1:62). Qantas will retrofit a fourth toilet to the first three within about three years; new A321XLRs arriving from December will include four. The jets replace 737-800s (12J/162Y), and are touted for wider cabins, seats, more luggage space, and better fuel efficiency. Qantas is first in Asia-Pacific, fourth globally, to operate the type.

articles.title: Ed Miliband looking into more North Sea drilling despite Labour pledge
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Energy secretary examining ways to allow oil and gas exploration without breaking manifesto promise
articles.summary: Energy secretary Ed Miliband is devising a North Sea strategy to raise output while honouring Labour’s pledge of no new licences on new fields. Options include “bespoke” permits tied to existing infrastructure, incentivising returns to abandoned prospects, tie-backs from current sites, and curbs on routine flaring. Inspired by Prof John Underhill, the plan seeks to extend asset life, protect about 30,000 north-east Scotland jobs, and meet Treasury growth aims. Industry claims >7bn extra barrels; climate groups call gains negligible. Miliband may decide Rosebank and Jackdaw environmental approvals without breaching the pledge. Government insists manifesto met “in full,” amid union lobbying and Trump’s UN push to “drill, baby, drill”.

articles.title: Australia, along with other OECD countries, is mired in mediocrity – and the RBA seems intent on keeping us there | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: If the Reserve Bank won’t drop interest rates next week, it will be another example of one of our institutions aiming low
articles.summary: Greg Jericho argues OECD/IMF couch severe risks in blandness—downplaying Trump’s tariffs (US effective rates highest since the Depression) and climate change (barely mentioned). Their forecasts show Australia “doing well” yet stuck in mediocrity: OECD GDP ~2.3%; IMF sees no return to long‑term growth through 2030. He says the RBA embodies this timidity, likely holding the cash rate at 3.6% next week despite unemployment >4%, headline CPI 3% y/y and underlying easing 2.7%→2.6%, and consumption still below trend. Governor Michele Bullock warns of excess demand. Jericho contends the bank favors “vigilance” over jobs, refusing stimulus and settling for middling outcomes.

articles.title: Bank of England urged to do more to tackle climate crisis
articles.trailText: Environmental groups mark 10 years since Mark Carney’s ‘short-term horizons’ speech with plea to act ‘while there’s still time’
articles.summary: Ten groups including Greenpeace and WWF urge the Bank of England to act on climate, 10 years after Mark Carney’s 2015 “tragedy of the horizon” warning. They seek a monetary-policy review for climate shocks, tolerance of temporarily higher inflation, and buffer stocks of staples. They argue rate hikes raise decarbonisation costs, noting the UK’s inflation was fueled by fossil spikes. The BoE cut rates 25bp to 4%, says climate risk is in remit, and warns on weather-hit food. Campaigners want climate-weighted bank capital rules and discounts on fossil collateral. Carney, now Canada’s PM, has axed carbon tax and backs gas.

articles.title: Moderna boss defends UK in drug-pricing row as he opens £150m Oxfordshire facility
articles.trailText: ‘We’re here to invest,’ says Darius Hughes as he calls comments by other pharma companies ‘a little harsh’
articles.summary: Moderna UK GM Darius Hughes defended Britain after rivals called it Europe’s worst on pricing, as he opened a £150m mRNA vaccine plant at Harwell. Despite MSD, AstraZeneca and Eli Lilly pausing UK plans amid VPAG disputes, he said Moderna will invest under its £1bn, 10-year partnership; vaccines sit outside VPAG with strong NHS uptake via central contracts. The site employs 140 (80 manufacturing, 60 R&D), can make 100m doses/year (250m in a pandemic), has a Covid licence, will seek flu, and research cancer, rare and immune disorders. CEO Stéphane Bancel cited 20+ UK trials. BMS priced Cobenfy at $22,500.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover is a rich company – it can pay to support its own supply chain | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: As the government explores options to support suppliers it should ensure that the carmaker foots the eventual bill
articles.summary: After a cyber-attack halted Jaguar Land Rover, Nils Pratley argues ministers should make the cash-rich carmaker fund its own direct suppliers and shoulder much of any wider rescue. JLR, owned by Tata Motors, posted £2.5bn pre-tax profit last year and had £3.3bn cash plus a £1.7bn undrawn RCF (total liquidity £5bn) in August. With c700 direct suppliers, restart now pushed to 1 October, government aid should target indirect suppliers to prevent lasting damage and layoffs. An ITV-floated scheme—state buys parts now, sells to JLR on restart—beats blanket loans, but Treasury shouldn’t underwrite cyber-risk; JLR should contribute.

articles.title: Salmon farmer accused of blocking UK investigations into alleged animal rights breaches
articles.trailText: Faroese firm Bakkafrost wants to ban campaigner Don Staniford from going within 15 metres of its fish farms
articles.summary: Faroese salmon giant Bakkafrost (about 20% of UK farmed salmon) asked Dunoon sheriff court to impose an “extended interdict” barring campaigner Don Staniford—and anyone acting for him—from coming within 15m of its 200+ farms, vessels, barges, factories, docks, hatcheries and its Edinburgh HQ. Civil liberties groups call it a SLAPP chilling scrutiny; breaches risk contempt and jail. Staniford already has stay-away orders from Mowi and Scottish Sea Farms; Mowi’s 15m buffer was overturned and it seeks £123k costs. Staniford’s lawyer says the case lacks precision/evidence; Bakkafrost says it defends property rights. Hearing continues.

articles.title: Government looks at buying up Jaguar Land Rover parts to protect jobs at suppliers
articles.trailText: Plans reportedly being made to mitigate the effect of a production freeze caused by a severe cyber-attack
articles.summary: The UK is weighing emergency support for Jaguar Land Rover’s supply chain after a 31 Aug cyber-attack froze production into October. Business secretary Peter Kyle is considering a scheme for government to buy parts from JLR’s 700 direct suppliers and sell them back when output resumes—though storage limits complicate it. Unions want furloughs; no formal aid yet. JLR has advanced about £300m to partners and redeployed 50 staff to manual payments. The shutdown has cost hundreds of millions and forced some suppliers to halt. JLR employs 32,800 in the UK; profits fell 49% to £351m in Q2. New CEO PB Balaji starts November.

articles.title: BT boss says costs ‘inflicted’ by UK are 10 times those faced by European sector
articles.trailText: Allison Kirkby warns that the November budget could be ‘very difficult’ for the chancellor
articles.summary: BT chief executive Allison Kirkby said UK telecoms face “government‑inflicted” costs up to 10x higher than peers in Germany and the Netherlands, citing business rates, energy levies and compliance. She warned the 26 November budget could be “very difficult” for chancellor Rachel Reeves amid a £20bn fiscal hole, after last year’s measures added £100m to BT’s costs.
